The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n\"You could see blood all over the parked car. The horses come down this route every day, but today the horse looked stressed or panicked.\"\n\nTracy, 20, from London, said: \"It was the street from Tower Bridge towards Limehouse Tunnel ... just running past cars and an unmarked Range Rover following them.\"\n\nA taxi driver waiting outside the Clermont Hotel had the windows of his car smashed after a spooked horse collided with the Mercedes people carrier.\n\nLBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who was waiting outside the hotel when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or four horses near the vehicle and that one member of military personnel had been thrown off and injured.\n\nA horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus smashing the windscreen.\n\nThe Ministry of Defence confirmed seven Household Cavalry horses were on the loose in central London.\n\nAn Army spokesman said all of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\nCity of London Police said officers had contained two horses and were preparing to transport them to veterinary care.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service described it as an \"ongoing and complex situation\".\n\nIt said paramedics had been called to three separate incidents involving the loose horses so far.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman said: \"We are aware of a number of horses on the loose in central London.\n\n\"We are working with colleagues in the Army to locate them.\"\n\nA City of London Police spokesman said: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n\"Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\n\"We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: \"We were called at 8.25am today (April 24) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n\"We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n\"Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.\n\n\"The incident is still ongoing and we are working with our emergency services partners.\"\n\nA Big Bus Tours spokesman said: \"We confirm that one of our stationary buses sustained damage this morning during an incident involving horses from the Household Cavalry.\n\n\"One of the horses ran into the front of our parked vehicle. Fortunately, none of our team members were injured.\n\n\"Our primary concern lies with the welfare of the riders and animals involved in the incident.\n\n\"We are currently co-ordinating closely with Emergency Services to assist in any way possible.\n\n\"At this stage, we have no further comments to provide.\"\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses become loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical {"uri": "2024-04-334463986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:30:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:30:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:30:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.herald.co.zw/4-injured-as-spooked-horses-bolt-through-london-rush-hour/", "title": "4 injured as 'spooked' horses bolt through London rush hour", "body": "LONDON. - Four people have been injured after runaway military horses - spooked by noise from building work - bolted through London. Three soldiers, a cyclist and horses were hurt and vehicles damaged after chaos broke out during rush hour.\n\nTwo horses were seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nThe Ministry of Defence said the horses from the Household Cavalry were being exercised ahead of an inspection due to take place tomorrow in Hyde Park.\n\nDuring the exercise, the horses were \"spooked\" by nearby building works. Four soldiers were thrown from their saddles and five horses ran loose through London.\n\nIn a statement Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Matt Woodward said: \"Every morning, the Household Cavalry Mounted regiment in London exercises some 150 horses in the parks and on the roads.\n\n\"This keeps them fit and helps inoculate them to city noise so they're less easily panicked on parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them. The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders. \"Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses.\"\n\n\"Three of our soldiers have incurred injuries which are not deemed to be life-threatening and they're receiving treatment in hospital, while our horses have all returned to Hyde Park barracks and are undergoing veterinary care.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare, we continue to strive to minimise the risk of this recurring.\"\n\nA taxi driver waiting outside the Clermont Hotel in Buckingham Palace Road had the windows of his car smashed after a spooked horse collided with the Mercedes people carrier. A horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nOne eyewitness told ITV News he saw five horses running along the street \"like crazy\", adding: \"One of them crashed into the bus - they ran like crazy!\n\n\"One guy (was hit) and the ambulance came. One of the horses was white and covered in blood.\n\n\"People were scared and ran away.\"\n\nAnother eyewitness, Daniele Torrisi added: \"My colleague heard a bang then I looked outside and saw this horse bleeding and the bus was cracked - so the horse hit the bus.\n\n(The horse) was bleeding quite badly. You could see people around trying to calm him down - he was a bit agitated.\"\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. \"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nPictures and videos of two of the animals running amok around London were shared on social media, one of which showed a black 4\u00d74 with blue lights following two of the animals between Tower Bridge and Limehouse tunnel.\n\nA worker for tour bus company, Big Bus, Mr Mahmood, said three horses got \"out of control\" from Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nHe said: \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control.\n\n\"I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down.\n\n\"An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.\"\n\nTwo horses were captured by officers from the City of London Police.\n\nThe force said on X: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City. \"Our officers have contained two horses on the highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it was called at 8.25am to reports of a person being thrown from a horse in Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nA spokesperson said: \"We were called at 8:25am today (April 24) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n\"We sent Blood was seen on the road\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe Met Police said: 'We are aware of a number of horses that are currently loose in central London and are working with colleagues, including the Army, to locate them.'\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. {"uri": "8095747174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:27:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:27:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:27:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/515182/military-horses-break-free-rampage-through-london", "title": "Military horses break free, rampage through London", "body": "Four people have been taken to hospital after five runaway horses of the Household Cavalry threw off their riders and raced through London.\n\nThe horses, one of which was covered in blood, caused chaos as they roamed the city centre and collided with vehicles, including a double-decker bus and taxi.\n\nThey initially became spooked by loud construction during a routine military exercise in Belgravia, the Army said.\n\nOfficers said the horses had been recovered and returned to camp.\n\nTwo of the animals were finally recovered in Limehouse in east London, more than eight kilometres from where the incident began. The Army said they were undergoing veterinary care.\n\nAn army spokesperson told the BBC that three soldiers were receiving treatment for non-life threatening injuries. The fourth person injured in the incident is believed to be a cyclist and member of the public.\n\nThe chaos began while members of the Household Cavalry - members of the military who carry out ceremonial duties around Buckingham Palace - were taking part in a rehearsal for a Major General's Inspection - which was due to take place on Thursday in Hyde Park, the Army told the BBC.\n\nEvery military unit taking part in the King's birthday parade, which takes place in June, must pass a Major General's Inspection in advance. An Army spokesman said the group included six soldiers and seven horses. Four soldiers were thrown from their saddles, and five horses ran loose through London.\n\nLt Col Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said: \"Building materials were dropped from height right next to\n\nthem.\n\n\"The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders.\"\n\nHe expressed \"heartfelt gratitude\" to the emergency services and the public who helped in securing the horses.\n\nOne serviceman was thrown from his horse on Buckingham Palace Road, before one of the loose animals collided with a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said four people were treated by paramedics in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street. All four were taken to hospital.\n\nIt said all three incidents took place within 10 minutes, between 8:25am and 8:35am.\n\nAn Army spokesperson added: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nGrace Whitaker, 23, told the BBC she had just got off a bus on her way to work when she saw several emergency services vehicles near Victoria Station.\n\n\"I saw about five fire engines, six ambulances,\" she said. \"I saw one of the horses that was involved, saw some members of the army. It was quite the scene with lots of emergency services around, putting up cordons.\"\n\n\"One of the black horses was there. I thought maybe it was a police horse that had come to attend to the scene but obviously I now know it was one of the horses that had escaped.\n\n\"I saw what looked like a taxi van that had damage to it, a smashed window. I think everyone's immediate impression was that somebody had been hit by a car. We were quite surprised when we realised it was to do with horses.\"\n\nWhitaker added that she witnessed at least one person being treated for injuries.\n\n\"There was a blue tent around what I assume was an injured person.\"\n\nMegan Morra told the BBC she was walking to work when she saw police officers \"running through the street\", and another walking a \"very bloody\" black horse down the path.\n\nShe said the horse appeared to be suffering from a large head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she says. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nBlack cab driver Robbie told BBC Radio London he narrowly avoided being hit by the horses.\n\nHe said: \"I was just outside Buckingham Palace on the Mall and heard loads of galloping and looked behind and there were about three or four horses.\n\n\"Two of them were sprinting up towards Trafalgar Square and there was a white one covered in blood as well.\n\n\"I looked in the rear mirror and saw them coming right up behind me, and at the time I had two punters in the back so I was worried about them.\"\n\nInsp Myles Hilbery, of City of London Police, praised the two officers who helped catch the horses in Limehouse.\n\n\"Police constables Lucy Hawes and Daniel McKeown risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses,\" he said.\n\n\"They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive.\"\n\nLondon Fire Brigade said it had used its drone team to help locate the animals.\n\nThe incident is unusual, as the horses of the Household Cavalry are specifically chosen by the army.\n\nAccording to forces.net, the horses are chosen for their height (at least 168cm) and strength as they need to be able to carry a soldier plus kit for a long period of time.\n\nThe horses are trained for several months and ridden on the streets of London to get used to heavy traffic and loud noises, including gun salutes and military bands.\n\nEach horse is usually assigned to one specific soldier.", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": It is not fully clear whether more horses were still on the loose.\n\nAt least two horses seen pacing through the streets of central London have been recaptured, the City of London police said on Wednesday.\n\nThe animals, wearing saddles and bridles, were seen racing along the road near Aldwych this morning, which is in between London's historic financial center and the West End, the hub of the capital's entertainment industry.\n\nThe two horses belonged to one of the most senior regiments in the British Army and it is not fully yet clear how many horses were on the loose.\n\nThe animals skirted rush hour traffic this morning, but the spooked horses also hit a taxi and a number of other vehicles, according to British media outlets. {"uri": "8095686985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:14:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://au.news.yahoo.com/several-military-horses-run-wild-113648571.html", "title": "Several military horses run wild in London, injuring four people", "body": "Several military horses bolted during routine exercises near King Charles III's main residence in London on Wednesday and ran loose through the centre of the city, injuring at least four people and colliding with vehicles during the morning rush hour.\n\nChaos erupted when about seven horses from the Household Cavalry became spooked by noise caused by nearby construction workers while the animals were taking exercise in Belgravia, a swanky neighbourhood just to the west of Buckingham Palace, British media reported.\n\nThe riderless horses galloped down main roads in central London, running into vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests, officials said.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial centre and the busy West End theatre district.\n\nOne of the horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint. The Army has not yet confirmed whether it was blood or what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw one of the horses had a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed by a spooked horse, while a parked double-decker tour bus had its windshield damaged.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of ten minutes after the horses ran amok around 8:30 a.m.\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear what happened, but it appeared that seven horses had bolted from their barracks in central London and ran amok.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" an army spokesperson said.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. The horses were all captured shortly after and and are undergoing medical tests, officials said.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nOne of the horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint. {"uri": "8096559518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:45:14", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:45:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:44:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12547132/mystery-what-spooked-cavalry-horses-new-clip/", "title": "Mystery over what spooked cavalry horses as clip shows one throw off rider", "body": "MYSTERY surrounds what spooked cavalry horses before their rampage in London yesterday - as a clip shows one throwing off a rider in a separate incident.\n\nFive Household Cavalry horses bolted and ran six miles after fleeing a \"routine exercise\" in Belgravia on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour people were injured and two horses were said to be in a serious condition following the incident at around 8.20am.\n\nIt was claimed the animals had been spooked by builders dropping rubble from a great height close by.\n\nHowever, new video was then posted to YouTube channel London City Walks - claiming to have been shot later the same day - in which a horse appears to bolt and throw a trooper to the ground at Horse Guards Parade.\n\nThe daily changeover ceremony takes place at 11am.\n\nThe man filming is heard saying moments before the incident: \"The horses are having a bit of a dance show this morning, they're not settling down as quick as they usually do.\"\n\nSeconds later, there is a commotion among the crowd as an unsettled black horse moves frantically.\n\nOther horses are also seen tugging against their harnesses, and the first horse bucks, throwing the rider to the ground.\n\nThe man filming then says: \"Oh a trooper has been thrown, oh good lord.\"\n\nThe rider remains lying on their back.\n\nThe man adds: \"What is going on with the horses today?\"\n\nThe video also shows the riders trying to control their horses.\n\nPolice then step over to check the fallen trooper is okay, as he begins to move around.\n\nA soldier runs into the courtyard in an effort to recapture the rogue horse, with a woman heard telling onlookers to stay still.\n\nOnce the other horses are moved back into formation they seem distressed, tossing their heads.\n\nThe crowd applauds as the fallen rider gets to their feet after being checked by a medic.\n\nYesterday morning, five rampaging Household Cavalry horses had to be retrieved with the help of police after leaving a trail of destruction.\n\nThe loose animals, wearing saddles and bridles, were seen running down the road near Aldwych.\n\nA spokesperson said the \"routine\" exercise had involved a group of seven horses and six soldiers in total, with four service personnel thrown to the ground in the commotion.\n\nFive horses got loose, smashing into vehicles.\n\nIn an update, defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News this morning: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition.\n\n\"Obviously we will be monitoring that condition. They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nThe minister said the two injured cavalry horses are named Vida and Quaker.\n\nMr Cartlidge went on to say it was an \"exceptional\" situation, explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day.\n\nAsked about the condition of the two seriously injured horses by LBC, he said he \"wouldn't want to say more\".\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nThe Army later said two horses involved had undergone operations.\n\nIn a statement on X, formerly Twitter, the Army said one of those operated on had been taken to equine hospital.\n\nThree soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\", it added.\n\nThe statement said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n\"Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nPictures and videos of the horses were shared on social media, one of which showed a black 4x4 with blue lights following the animals.\n\nFootage posted by users showed a saddled white horse covered in blood running through the street alongside a black one.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nA City of London Police spokesperson also said yesterday: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n\"Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\n\"We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nThe Sun has The front of one of the horses, which was white, was covered in red.\n\nThe British Army said that the horses escaped during routine exercise this morning but had been recovered and returned to camp. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" it said.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said they were called around 8:25 a.m. (0825 GMT) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse near Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nCity of London Police, the force in charge of the capital's financial district, said they were called at around 8:40 a.m. (0740 GMT) to reports about horses on the loose.\n\nIt later said in a statement that officers have \"contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse,\" adding that they were \"waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nLondon's Metropolitan Police said in a statement \"We're pleased to confirm that all of the horses have been accounted for. The first was at 8.25am about a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road. The patient was taken to hospital.\n\nTwo minutes later medics were called to nearby Belgrave Square and found two people injured by horses and took them to hospital.\n\nA further call was made at 8.35am at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street and a fourth person was taken to hospital.\n\nA taxi driver waiting outside the Clermont Hotel in Buckingham Palace Road had the windows of his car smashed after a spooked horse collided with the Mercedes people carrier.\n\nA horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. through central London", "body": "Four people were taken to hospital after spooked army horses broke loose during morning exercises in central London and galloped through the streets at rush hour, the wearing saddles and bridles, with one covered in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" an army spokesman said.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nThe seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\n\"Five of the horses ran off and two remained in place,\" the army said.\n\n\"Four soldiers were unseated and three injured.\"\n\nThe three soldiers were taken to hospital where they were being assessed but none was in a life-threatening condition.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 8.25am (0725 GMT) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nTwo of the horses were recaptured by the City of London Police, which polices the Square Mile financial district.\n\nOfficers contained two animals while \"an army horse box had collected the horses and transported them to veterinary care\".\n\nThe driver of a Mercedes car told LBC radio he had been waiting outside a hotel in Buckingham Palace Road when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or {"uri": "8095213603", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:46:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:46:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:45:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/2906518-five-military-horses-loose-in-london-create-stir-among-residents", "title": "''Five Military Horses Loose in London Create Stir Among Residents'' | Business", "body": "In central London, five runaway military horses caused chaos, injuring four people and colliding with vehicles. The incident occurred near Buckingham Palace during a routine exercise, with the horses spooked by construction noise. The Household Cavalry's horses were recovered and returned for medical attention. London Ambulance Service treated and transported the injured. Police officers assisted the horses and ensured public safety. The police praised their constables for providing first aid and guiding the horses to safety.\n\nFive riderless military horses that bolted during a routine exercise on Wednesday morning unleashed rush-hour mayhem on the streets of central London near Buckingham Palace, injuring at least four people.\n\nScenes of one blood-covered horse galloping along Aldwych near the High Commission of India and the West End theatre district were shared widely on social media after the horses collided with cars and smashed into a tourist bus.\n\nThe British Army later confirmed that all its horses had been recovered and returned to their camp, where they were receiving medical attention.\n\n''All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. Several personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,'' a spokesperson said.\n\nThe chaos is said to have erupted when the horses became alarmed by construction noise from builders working nearby.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off from where the exercise was taking place in Belgravia, a posh neighbourhood to the west of Buckingham Palace -- the residence of King Charles III.\n\nThe ceremonial exercise was part of preparations for the monarch's annual birthday parade, known as Trooping the Colour, next month.\n\nAccording to reports, several soldiers were thrown off after the horses were spooked and three of the soldiers had to be taken to the hospital with injuries.\n\n\"We responded to several calls regarding an incident with horses on the loose in central London this morning. We sent multiple resources to the three scenes, treating four patients in total and taking them all to the hospital. We have since been stood down,\" a London Ambulance Service statement said.\n\nThe horses belonged to the Household Cavalry, which is the ceremonial guard of the British monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed in the mayhem, while a parked double-decker tourist bus had its windshield damaged.\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public,\" said Inspector Myles Hilbery from the City of London Police.\n\nHilbery praised his police constables who he said had risked their safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses.\n\n\"They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive,\" he added.\n\nThe police force took control of the traffic, with officers on motorbikes creating a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is The first paramedic was on the scene within five minutes.\n\nPictures and videos of two of the animals, one white and the other black, circulated widely across social media. One of the horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint.\n\nThe two horses were later contained in Limehouse, around 6km east of central London, City of London police said.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear what happened, but it appeared that seven horses had bolted from their barracks in central London and ran amok.\n\nAll the animals were contained shortly after.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" an army spokesperson said.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. {"uri": "2024-04-333902608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:44:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:44:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:55:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/uk/escaped-army-horses-cause-chaos-in-central-london", "title": "Escaped Army Horses Cause Chaos in Central London", "body": "A number of individuals, as well as the horses themselves, sustained injuries during the incident.\n\nA scene of commotion unfolded in the heart of London on Wednesday morning as several horses belonging to the Household Cavalry broke free from their confines, triggering a dramatic pursuit through the city streets.\n\nAccording to a report from CNN news, a number of individuals, as well as the horses themselves, sustained injuries during the incident, though specific details about their conditions remain undisclosed.\n\nAll the horses have now been recovered\n\nIn a statement provided to CNN via email, a spokesperson for the British Army addressed the situation, stating, \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service confirmed to the PA Media news agency that four individuals had been transported to the hospital for treatment.\n\nThe incident occurred early in the morning\n\nThe events unfolded early in the morning, prompting the City of London Police to take to social media to report the situation. In a statement shared on X platform, they detailed, \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had become loose and were traveling through the City. Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nShortly after, Westminster Police provided an update confirming that all the horses had been located and that coordination with the Army was ongoing.\n\nOne of the horses collided with a taxi\n\nVideos circulating on social media captured the chaotic scene, with two horses, one visibly injured, galloping through Aldwych in central London. Reports indicate that during their flight, one of the horses collided with a Mercedes taxi parked outside the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, shattering its windows. Additionally, another horse reportedly struck the windshield of a double-decker tour bus.\n\nThe Household Cavalry, responsible for ceremonial duties and safeguarding the King, is headquartered at Hyde Park barracks, in close proximity to Buckingham Palace.\n\nWhile the exact circumstances leading to the horses' escape are yet to be clarified, the incident serves as a reminder of the unexpected twists that can occur even in the most regimented environments. Efforts to ensure the welfare of both the animals and affected individuals are currently underway, as authorities work to assess the aftermath of the event in central London.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-334052703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:45:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:45:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T06:08:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/london-police-catching-horses/507-13ff74a6-d366-4977-9f0d-520ffb78afd3", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "LONDON, UK -- Five military horses bolted during routine exercises near King Charles III's main residence in London on Wednesday and ran loose through the center of the city, injuring at least four people and colliding with vehicles during the morning rush hour.\n\nChaos erupted when the horses, which were conducting an extended exercise to practise for a major upcoming military parade, became alarmed by construction noise from a nearby building. Five of the seven horses ran off from where the exercise was taking place in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of Buckingham Palace.\n\nFour soldiers were thrown off, and three of them were taken to the hospital with injuries.\n\nThe riderless horses then galloped down main roads in central London, running into vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nOne of the horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint. The Army has not yet confirmed whether it was blood or what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw one of the horses had a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed by a spooked horse, while a parked double-decker tour bus had its windshield damaged.\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an Army spokesperson said. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical {"uri": "8096058656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "05:16:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T05:16:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T05:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/watch-royal-military-horses-go-on-rampage-in-london-injure-4-people-13763471.html", "title": "Watch: Royal military horses go on rampage in London, injure 4 people", "body": "Two horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych. Source: AP\n\nMajor chaos ensued in London after Household Cavalry horses galloped through the streets, leaving four people injured. The horses started to go on a rampage on the streets of Central London after being spooked by noisy construction work.\n\nWhile the builders were busy moving construction rubble from the area, five military horses from a group of seven bolted during an exercise in Belgravia. After the mayhem came to an end, a number of people and horses were taken to the hospital and are currently being treated for injuries.\n\nIn the video that is circulating online, two horses were seen running across the road near Aldwych. One of the white horses was drenched in blood as it ran through the rush-hour streets.\n\nThe horses smashed a double-decker tour bus\n\nThe horses that charged through the streets smashed into a double-decker tour bus and a Mercedes-Benz people carrier. Some even galloped five miles through rush hour traffic to the east of the capital.\n\nWhile conducting the rampage, the animals threw their riders, Lifeguards and Blues and Royals servicemen. The horses went out of control while they were participating in rehearsals for the King's birthday parade in June, The Telegraph reported.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a British army spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" the statement further reads.\n\nAs per the reports, two of the horses were caught near Limehouse tunnel, about five miles away. London Ambulance Service mentioned that it received three calls from separate locations about the incident: the first at 8:25 am (local time) of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road; the second two minutes later at nearby Belgrave Square where two people were injured; and a third at 8:35 am (local time) at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8094914772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:41:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:41:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:40:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/04/24/1246807622/runaway-horses-central-london", "title": "Runaway horses gallop through central London, blazing a path of mayhem and injuries", "body": "Five military horses -- including one seemingly covered in blood -- got loose in central London early Wednesday, galloping through rush hour crowds, smashing into vehicles and injuring several people before being recaptured.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" a spokesperson for the Ministry of Defence told NPR. \"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\"\n\nAccording to the ministry, six soldiers and seven horses from the Household Cavalry -- specifically the Life Guards, the most senior regiment of the British Army -- were conducting an \"extended exercising of horses\" around London, known as the Watering Order.\n\nAbout a mile into their journey, as they passed by a construction site in the Belgravia area, the sound of concrete hitting the ground \"caused the horses to spook.\"\n\nFive of the horses bolted, unseating four soldiers. Three soldiers were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, and the horses kept running.\n\n\"We are aware of a number of horses that are currently loose in central London and are working with colleagues, including the Army, to locate them,\" Westminster police wrote on X (formerly Twitter) just after 9 a.m. local time.\n\nOver roughly two hours, the horses wove a destructive path across some 6 miles of the city.\n\nBystanders and British news outlets flooded social media with footage of two saddled horses -- one black and one white, with bright red liquid covering its chest and legs -- hurtling through busy city streets.\n\nReports and photos emerged of horses smashing into vehicles, panicking commuters and knocking at least one person to the street.\n\nA cab driver named Sean told BBC Radio London that he saw a parked Mercedes \"with its side smashed in and covered in blood.\" The company Big Bus Tours said a horse had run into one of its parked double-decker buses. No one was injured, but photos show a massive crack in the bus' front window.\n\nEyewitness Bashir Aden told The Telegraph he saw a soldier fall to the ground, \"screaming in pain,\" after one of the horses ran into a car.\n\n\"The horses come down this route every day, but today the horse looked stressed or panicked,\" he added. \"I saw the horse run away after it hit a bus. People were screaming and running all over.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London Ambulance Service confirmed to NPR that four people were injured across three separate incidents, and all were taken to the hospital for treatment.\n\nThe first, at 8:25 a.m. local time, involved a person being \"thrown from a horse\" on Buckingham Palace Road. Two minutes later, responders were alerted to reports of \"an incident with a horse on Belgrave Square\" involving two victims. And they got a third call at 8:35 a.m. about another incident with a horse, this time at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street -- over 2 miles east of Belgrave Square.\n\nThe London Fire Brigade said in a statement that its crews helped respond after a person fell from a horse in Belgrave Square. They also responded to the scene of two collisions, \"including one near Victoria Railway Station where a horse was involved in a collision with a taxi.\"\n\nShortly before 10 a.m. local time, City of London police tweeted that officers had contained two horses on the highway near Limehouse -- which is in London's East End, about 6 miles away from Buckingham Palace -- and were waiting for the Army to transport them for veterinary care.\n\nAbout half an hour later, Westminster police said the rest of the horses had been accounted for -- concluding a frenzied search but leaving many unanswered {"uri": "8094952716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:07:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:07:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:03:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/national-world/cnn-world/2024/04/24/escaped-army-horses-run-amok-in-central-london/", "title": "Escaped army horses run amok in central London - KION546", "body": "A number of people and horses are currently being treated for injuries incurred during the incident, though further details about their conditions are unavailable.\n\nIn a statement emailed to CNN, a spokesperson for the British Army said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nSix soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards, part of the Household Cavalry, were conducting an extended exercise on Wednesday morning, the army said.\n\nThe animals were spooked when some concrete fell off a conveyor belt being used in nearby construction work and hit the ground, the army added.\n\nFive of the horses bolted, while two remained in place.\n\nThe army said four of the soldiers were unseated and three were injured. These three are currently being assessed in the hospital but are not thought to be in a life-threatening condition.\n\nEarlier Wednesday, the City of London Police - the force that oversees London's financial district - reported the events on social media.\n\nIn a statement posted on X, it said: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n\"Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.\"\n\nLess than an hour after that was posted, colleagues at neighboring Westminster Police posted an update to say that \"all of the horses have been accounted for\" and that they were \"continuing to liaise with the Army.\"\n\nStartling footage emerged on social media showing two horses - one apparently covered with blood - running through Aldwych in central London.\n\nAccording to PA, a Mercedes taxi that was waiting outside the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road had its windows smashed by the spooked horses, while one of the animals shattered the windscreen of a double-decker tour bus.\n\nThe Household Cavalry acts as the King's official bodyguard and take part in ceremonial duties. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News.\n\nThe British Army later wrote on X (formerly Twitter) that the injured horses, named Vida and Quaker, were operated on late Wednesday, with one transferred to an equine hospital.\n\nThe other horses involved are \"being closely observed\" but are expected to return to duty \"in due course,\" it added.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses, with five of the animals bolting and four getting loose, reportedly after they were spooked by concrete being moved by builders hitting the ground.\n\nTwo horses then ran along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nThree of the unseated soldiers were taken to hospital but all are expected to make a full recovery, the army tweeted Thursday.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge stressed that Wednesday's events were \"extremely unlikely\" to be repeated.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day,\" he told LBC radio.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 8:25 am (0725 GMT) in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" an army spokesman said.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nThe seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\n\"Five of the horses ran off and two remained in place,\" the army said.\n\n\"Four soldiers were unseated and three injured.\"\n\nThe three soldiers were taken to hospital where they were being assessed but none was in a life-threatening condition.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 8:25 am (0725 GMT) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nTwo of the horses were recaptured by the City of London Police, which polices the Square Mile financial district.\n\nOfficers contained two animals while \"an army horse box had collected the horses and transported them to veterinary care\".\n\nThe driver of a Mercedes car told LBC radio he had been waiting outside a hotel in Buckingham Palace Road when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or four horses near the vehicle, and that an army rider had been thrown off and injured.\n\nOne horse crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nOne commuter shared a video on social media platform X, formerly Twitter, showing a black horse and a white horse being pursued by a black car.\n\n\"It was the street from Tower Bridge towards Limehouse Tunnel... just running past cars and an unmarked They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News.\n\nThe names of the injured horses are Vida and Quaker, he added.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses, with five of the animals getting loose, reportedly after they were spooked by concrete being moved by builders hitting the ground.\n\nTwo horses then ran along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nThree of the unseated soldiers were taken to hospital where they were being assessed but none was in a life-threatening condition.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge stressed that Wednesday's events were \"extremely unlikely\" to be repeated.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. United Kingdom - Escaped army horses bolt through central London, four people injured", "body": "Four people were taken to hospital after spooked army horses broke loose during morning exercises in central London and galloped through the streets at rush hour, the army and emergency services said.\n\nPhotos and video posted on social media and by British news outlets showed the horses running along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nBoth were wearing saddles and bridles, with one apparently covered in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\nLondon's Metropolitan Police said it was \"working with colleagues in the army to locate them\".\n\nA number of prestigious army regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service was called at 8:25am (local time) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road in central London, a spokesperson for the service said.\n\nNo details were released on the injured people or the exact circumstances of their injuries.\n\nThe driver of a Mercedes car told LBC radio he had been waiting outside a hotel in Buckingham Palace Road when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or four horses near the vehicle, and that an army rider had been thrown off and injured.\n\nOne horse also reportedly crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nUp to seven horses initially got loose, Britain's domestic Press Association news agency reported, with police working with the army to recapture them.\n\nThe army said in a statement that \"a number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning\".\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. {"uri": "8095393421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:51:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:51:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:51:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/major-update-blood-soaked-horses-32664249", "title": "Update on blood-soaked horse's condition after running loose in London", "body": "British Army share update after escaped horses recaptured in London\n\nBlood-soaked horses spotted running through central London this morning, causing havoc in the nation's capital, are \"safe\" and undergoing veterinary care, the army has confirmed.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an exercise in Belgravia when chaos erupted. The powerful animals were scared when concrete was dropped by builders which landed next to them, causing four service personnel to be thrown from their steeds.\n\nFive of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries. They were seen running through busy areas of the city, one of them bloodied, before they were finally brought under control.\n\nIn an update on X, formerly Twitter, Lieutenant Colonel Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said: \"This morning, a small group of horses were spooked by construction works on a quiet side road where building materials were dropped from height next to them.\n\nTwo of the horses spotted running through London\n\n\"The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders. Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses. Our horses have all returned to Hyde Park Barracks and are undergoing veterinary care. Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and number of horses involved this type of incident is extremely rare.\"\n\nThree soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious. A white horse collided with a Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen. The animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nOne of the horses collided with a bus in London\n\nIn a Tweet, the British Army said: \"Thank you to Met Police, City of London Police, London Ambulance Service, London Fire Brigade and members of the public for reacting as quickly as they did. This enabled the swift treatment of our soldiers and helped us to bring our injured horses to safety.\"\n\nWitness Tula, a management consultant from south London, said: \"I got off the 172 bus which ends at Aldwych and two horses went flying past. One black, one white. The white one was drenched in blood from the chest down and they were galloping through the traffic at speed.\n\n\"People were stopping in the street shocked. The horses were running into fast-moving traffic and seemed terrified. Some unmarked police cars were chasing after them, which didn't seem to be helping. I felt shocked. It was pretty gruesome. Felt like a weird dream.\"\n\nWhere the horses were spotted in London\n\nA London Ambulance Service spokesperson said: \"We were called at 8:25am today (April 24) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W. We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast-response car, and an incident response officer. Our first paramedic arrived on scene in five minutes.\"\n\nInspector Myles Hilbery, City of London Police added: \"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public.\n\n\"Police Constables Lucy Hawes and Daniel McKeown risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses. They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive.\n\n\"PCs Brett Daniels and Chris Wilson took over management of traffic control on the busy arterial road enabling PCs Rob Bray and Shaun Gurney on motorbikes to create a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care. Our thoughts are with those people and horses injured in the incident.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": Five bolted and two remained in place. Four soldiers were unseated and three were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nHowever, onlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nIs is believed that horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, on Wednesday\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nREAD MORE: LIVE: Horses covered in blood rampage through central London with one soldier left injured as five animals smash into oncoming traffic Advertisement\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nLondoners were seen avoiding one of the horses as it ran along the pavement. One horse reportedly ran into a black cab\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was shocked when a horse collided with his car, lifting it up into the air on one side\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the startling incident (pictured: A crumpled police accident sign at the scene)\n\nPassersby were shocked to see the incident unfold\n\nThe horses were running at some pace after they became spooked while exercising\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nREAD MORE: Taxi driver reveals his 'shock' at the moment a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his Mercedes near Buckingham Palace and left the car splattered in blood Advertisement\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes on Wednesday\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it became apparent that the animal had injured its leg\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages stemming the bleeding\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, \"I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back\".'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household Three of the soldiers were hospitalized with injuries.\n\nThe riderless horses then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nWATCH: In Connecticut, these horses are helping veterans cope with the trauma of combat\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an army spokesperson said. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it
