{"uri": "8097030081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:37:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:37:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:37:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/spooked-horses-bolted-through-streets-32671613", "title": "Horses that bolted through streets of London undergoing life-saving surgery", "body": "Spooked cavalry horses injured as they ran amok in central London have undergone surgery to save their lives, defence chiefs have revealed.\n\nTwo animals were said to be in a \"serious condition\" after falling rubble saw them flee a \"routine exercise\" in Belgravia. They were among five Household Cavalry horses that went on a six-mile rampage and left four people injured. One of the horses - named as Vida - was seen soaked in blood as it galloped through central London, alongside a black horse, called Quaker.\n\nTwo of the other animals were named as Trojan and Tennyson. Service personnel were thrown to the floor and five of the animals broke loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\". In a statement a spokesman said one of those operated on had been taken to an equine hospital.\n\nTwo horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych\n\nHe said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\" Asked about the condition of two of the horses, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\n\"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nQuaker (left) and Vida (right) are understood to have undergone life-saving surgery\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents. Injuries were reported in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square and the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, at around 8.25am.\n\nA serviceman was thrown to the ground in Buckingham Palace Road and one of the loose animals smashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nThe driver said a white horse collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side. Two horses, wearing saddles and bridles, were seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nThey were later spotted near the Limehouse tunnel, before being recaptured by City of London Police. A horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen, and one crashed into a taxi, but no one was hurt. during morning exercises in central London and galloped through the streets at rush hour, the army and emergency services said.\n\nPhotos and video posted on social media by British news outlets showed two horses running along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nBoth were wearing saddles and bridles, with one apparently covered in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 8:25 am (0725 GMT) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nNo details were released on the injured people or the exact circumstances of their injuries.\n\nThe driver of a Mercedes car told LBC radio he had been waiting outside a hotel in Buckingham Palace Road when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or four horses near the vehicle, and that an army rider had been thrown off and injured.\n\nOne horse also reportedly crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nOne commuter shared a video on social media platform X, formerly Twitter, showing a black horse and a white horse being pursued by a black car.\n\n\"It was the street from this morning\".\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. {"uri": "8094650120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:06:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:06:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:05:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/04/24/london-escaped-horses-household-cavalry/", "title": "Escaped army horses careen through London, crashing into vehicles", "body": "According to British media reports, the horses were from the Household Cavalry and threw their riders during a morning exercise. Several army regiments keep their horses in stables in central London.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a military spokeswoman told The Washington Post. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nPictures and footage of the horses were shared widely on social media. At least two horses were seen bolting through the streets and sidewalks. One smashed into a double decker tourist bus.\n\nCity of London police force, which covers London's financial district, said that they had contained two horses and were waiting for the British Army to collect the animals.\n\n\"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had become loose and were traveling through the City. Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care,\" the statement said.\n\nOne of the horses appeared to have blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\n\"I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police,\" Bashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told the Telegraph. \"The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.\"\n\nA double decker bus tourism company said that a horse ran into one of its buses, which was parked at the time. {"uri": "8094961429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:08:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:08:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:08:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/military-horses-run-loose-in-central-london-injuring-4-people-and-causing-havoc/", "title": "Military horses run loose in central London, injuring 4 people and causing havoc - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Several military horses bolted during routine exercises Wednesday and ran loose through central London, injuring four people and damaging vehicles during the morning rush hour.\n\nA spokesperson for the London Ambulance Service said it was called at 8:25 a.m. to reports of a person being thrown from a horse in Buckingham Palace Road, and the first paramedic was on the scene within five minutes.\n\nPictures and videos of two of the animals, one white and the other black, circulated widely across social media. One of the horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint.\n\nThe two horses were later contained in Limehouse, around 4 miles (6 kms) east of central London, City of London police said.\n\nIt wasn't immediately clear what happened but it appeared that seven horses bolted from their barracks in central London and ran amok. All the animals were contained shortly after.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning,\" an Army spokesperson said.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" the spokesperson added.\n\nBritish media reported that a taxi driver waiting near Buckingham Palace had his car window smashed by a spooked horse, while another horse crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus and damaged its windshield.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8095007856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:36:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:36:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:35:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/loose-horses-were-seen-bolting-32661022", "title": "Why loose horses were seen bolting through London - and where they ended up", "body": "A white horse was seen bloodied as it bolted through the streets of London\n\nBaffled members of the public looked on this morning as seven horses raced through the centre of London - with one of the animals seen covered in blood.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes as the animals ran amok. The bizarre sight instantly prompted the question of how they had ended up loose on the streets of the capital - and it turned out they had escaped during a military exercise by the Household Cavalry.\n\nFour of them are said to have thrown off their riders. Three soldiers have been taken to hospital for their injuries, but were not seriously hurt. Multiple horses have also been given veterinary attention after being recaptured.\n\nDid you see the horses? Email webnews@mirror.co.uk\n\nThe horses escaped during an exercise by the Household Cavalry\n\nThe horses are understood to have escaped during the cavalry exercise after being spooked by the noise of builders moving rubble down a rubbish chute. Two of them were seen shortly afterwards seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood, and later near the Limehouse tunnel, before they were located by City of London Police.\n\nAll horses were confirmed to have been recaptured by around 10.30am, and have since been returned to camp. They have undergone medical tests, officials said.\n\nA timeline of the loose horse incident in London\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it received three horse-related calls during the incident on Wednesday. A taxi cab was damaged by a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, and the windscreen of a tour bus seen shattered a short while away.\n\nThey were all recaptured by 10.30am and given medical attention\n\nBBC Radio 2 travel presenter Bobbie Pryor, who has experience with horses, described desperately wanting to help after witnessing two horses rampaging as she left Charing Cross station. She said: \"It was horrendous - we all just stood watching thinking 'how are we going to help those horses'? Horses being loose is a huge fear - anyone who has been around horses knows just how terrifying it is, they've got tack, they've got loose reins. The best thing I could do if I couldn't catch them - and I couldn't safely do that - was just to get out of their way.\"\n\nOne witness described the scene as 'terrifying'\n\nA photographer meanwhile described the sight of a blood-soaked horse running past him in the capital as the \"most unusual thing I have seen in central London\". Jordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said: \"There were two horses which came hurtling past. The horse on the right, as I was looking towards it, was jet black and had a saddle on it. The one to the left, which also had a saddle, was a really distinct white colour.\n\nA bus windscreen was shattered by one of the horses\n\n\"It had a really distinct red underbelly which we later found out was blood but it was so sharp and vivid that it seemed unlike blood as it was so saturated and rich. It was just two bright colours hurtling down this road and it went straight past me.\n\n\"It is probably the most unusual thing I have seen in central London so far. Seeing two riderless horses bolting down an empty A road in London is certainly unique and took me very much by surprise today.\"\n\nIn a statement, a Ministry of Defence spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses become loose during routine exercise this morning. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News.\n\nThe British Army later wrote on X (formerly Twitter) that the injured horses, named Vida and Quaker, were operated on late Wednesday, with one transferred to an equine hospital.\n\nThe other horses involved are \"being closely observed\" but are expected to return to duty \"in due course,\" it added.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses, with five of the animals bolting and four getting loose, reportedly after they were spooked by concrete being moved by builders hitting the ground.\n\nTwo horses then ran along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nThree of the unseated soldiers were taken to hospital but all are expected to make a full recovery, the army tweeted Thursday.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge stressed that Wednesday's events were \"extremely unlikely\" to be repeated.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It was called at 8.25am to \"reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road\".\n\nTwo minutes later medics were called to nearby Belgrave Square and found two people hurt by horses.\n\nA further call was made at 8.35am at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, where a fourth person had been injured.\n\nCity of London Police previously said it had contained two escaped horses on the highway near Limehouse and officers had been waiting for an Army horse box to take the animals to a vet.\n\nThe force said it was called at around 8.40am about \"horses that had become loose and were travelling through the City\".\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said its first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes and was joined by ambulance crews.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the incident.\n\nIn a video shared by a commuter on social media platform X, formerly Twitter, a black horse and a white horse, the latter spattered with what appeared to be blood, were seen being pursued by a black car.\n\nTracy, 20, from London, said: \"It was the street from Tower Bridge towards Limehouse Tunnel... just running past cars and an unmarked Range Rover following them.\"\n\nWhat we know so far\n\n- at least two horses were seen on the loose in central London - It is believed the animals were alarmed when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, two of the horses were said to be in a serious condition.\n\nFootage taken by a Brazilian tourist shows people calming one of the escaped horses down. In the clip, the horse can be seen standing still in the middle of the road and was surrounded by a group of people who are stroking the horse gently, as one person held on to its muzzle. Beside them a double decker tourist bus can be seen with a smashed windscreen that one of the horses ran into.\n\nThe end of the clip shows blood on the floor underneath the animal, though it is not clear whether the blood is from the horse or from one of the four people injured during the incident.\n\nA second video shows a person lying on the ground in the middle of the road as people gather round them to shield them from traffic approaching in both directions as a paramedic attends to the injuries. A car is also seen with a large dent on its side and smashed windows, with broken glass covering the floor beside it.\n\nClick below to see the latest London headlines\n\nA second horse can be seen being calmed by people as it stands next to a bus stop.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes. It is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama had begun near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows. A management consultant from south London who saw two of the horses galloping near Aldwych said the sight was \"gruesome\" and \"like a weird dream\". The pair were captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nAn Army spokesman said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. {"uri": "8094968775", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:13:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:13:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:12:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/taxi-drivers-shock-after-loose-32661128", "title": "Taxi driver's 'shock' as loose Cavalry horse 'smashes' into car during escape", "body": "A shocked taxi driver has told how an Army horse \"smashed\" into his car in central London raising part of it into the air.\n\nThere have been chaotic scenes after seven Household Cavalry horses got loose with four soldiers thrown off them during an extended exercise in Belgravia today. Ambulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes as the animals ran amok.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals smashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nFarez, who was driving the Mercedes taxi, has said how he had just dropped off a passenger when suddenly he was confronted by a horse that ran into the car and damaged it, but fortunately he was not harmed. The people carrier was left with large dents and shattered windows after the incident.\n\nThe damage to the side of the Mercedes taxi Farez said he was shocked by the incident\n\nFarez did not see the horses and so was left \"shocked\" by the sudden impact and he believes that it was a white horse that was seen bloodied, that hit his car.\n\n\"I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see. When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash,\" he told LBC. \"I was okay but it (the car) is damaged.\"\n\nTwo if the escaped horses near Aldwych\n\nHe said how the force of the impact led to one side of the car being raised up. He continued: \"I saw about three, four horses which I see. I think the white horse hit my car.\" It is understood that three Household Cavalry personnel have been assessed at hospital for their injuries, but they were not seriously hurt.\n\nA white horse was seen covered in blood\n\nTwo horses were seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood, and later near the Limehouse tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police. A horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen, and one collided with a taxi, but no-one was hurt.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company Tootbus, described the chaotic scenes near Victoria. \"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said. \"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nA damaged bus needed to be towed away\n\nA second tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, said: \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control. I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down. An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.\"\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nPictures and videos of two of the animals running loose around London were shared on social media, one of which showed a black 4x4 with blue lights following the horses between Tower Bridge and Limehouse tunnel.\n\nCity of London Police said on X: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City. Our officers have contained two horses on the highway near Limehouse. {"uri": "8096332752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:30:28", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:30:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:29:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/two-of-five-rampaging-household-cavalry-horses-are-in-serious-condition-but-still-alive-as-it-emerges-white-runaway-called-vida-has-history-of-being-spooked-and-kicked-soldier-in-head-during-ki/", "title": "Two of five rampaging Household Cavalry horses are in 'serious condition but still alive' - as it emerges white runaway called 'Vida' has history of being spooked and 'kicked soldier in head during King's coronation'", "body": "Two horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'.\n\nHousehold Cavalry horses Vida and Quaker were two of five that bolted as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am yesterday and heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor from a builder's travelator.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours.\n\nIt emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked white horse, reportedly has a history of being spooked and even allegedly kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nYesterday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said Vida and Quaker were 'in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive'.\n\nTwo horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nHe told Sky News today: '[They] are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.'\n\nThe military horses who ran loose through London was an 'exceptional' situation, the minister added, explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day.\n\nHe told LBC: 'Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n'You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n'So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.'\n\nAn Army source told The Sun that the white horse that was drenched in blood, Vida, was 'lively' and had a history of being spooked.\n\nVida is thought to have kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nUsually Household Cavalry horses are black, however the regiment's state trumpeters always ride white or grey horses such as Vida.\n\nFour soldiers were unseated as the spooked horses bolted and three servicemen were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nHowever, onlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, on Wednesday\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nLondoners were seen avoiding one of the horses as it ran along the pavement. One horse reportedly ran into a black cab\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was shocked when a horse collided with his car, lifting it up into the air on one side\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the startling incident (pictured: A crumpled police accident sign at the scene)\n\nPassersby were shocked to see the incident unfold\n\nThe horses were running at some pace after they became spooked while exercising\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes on Wednesday\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it became apparent that the animal had injured its leg\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages stemming the bleeding\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Commanding Officer Matt Woodward said: 'Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household Army horses are stabled at the Hyde Park Barracks in London and spooked horses were seen charging as far away as Victoria (1 mile away), Aldwych (2.5 miles), Tower Bridge (5 miles), and Limehouse (7 miles), reports London broadcaster LBC.\n\nUpdate 11:30 -- Four hospitalised\n\nFour people were taken to hospital this morning after a group of five horses ran riderless through London. How many of these are thrown Army riders and how many were members of the public remains unclear.\n\nThe original story continues below\n\nPhotographers caught the moment bloodied horses, which are reported to have collided with vehicles and members of the public in their panic, coursing through the streets. Ambulances responded to injured individuals in three locations, it is stated, and at least one of those cases may have been to respond to thrown Army riders. Footage of the incident posted online shows a horse making its way towards apparently oblivious cyclists.\n\nPer reports, one horse charged into the front of a stationary bus, smashing the windscreen, and elsewhere a horse struck a van. The Army said in a statement: \"A number of military working horses become loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nSome horses were recovered by police, while in other cases members of the public were able to approach and calm the injured animals, possibly preventing further incidents. One witness told newspaper The Daily Telegraph: \"I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police. The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.\n\n\"The horses come down this route every day, but today the horse looked stressed or panicked. I saw the horse run away after it hit a bus. People were screaming and running all over.\"\n\nDespite the passage of time horses remain a reasonably familiar sight in central London. The Metropolitan Police used mounted patrols, and the British Army keeps a large number of horses in central London for ceremonial duties. {"uri": "8096636949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:33:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:33:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:31:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/2-runaway-uk-military-horses-undergo-surgery-soldiers-recover-4517111", "title": "2 runaway UK military horses undergo surgery, soldiers recover", "body": "London, Apr 25 (PTI) Two of the four riderless horses that bolted during a routine exercise causing mayhem on the streets of central London have undergone surgery but are expected to return to duty in due course, the British Army said in a statement on Thursday.\n\nScenes of a blood-covered horse galloping alongside another along Aldwych near the High Commission of India and the West End theatre district were shared widely on social media on Wednesday after the horses collided with cars and smashed into a tourist bus.\n\nThe Army said three soldiers injured when they were unseated from their horses are on the road to recovery as they named the four runaway horses from the Household Cavalry.\n\n\"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four - Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson - broke loose. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed,\" the Army statement said.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon,\" it said.\n\nQuaker is the horse still in hospital, according to the Ministry of Defence (MoD).\n\nEarlier, the Household Cavalry said the horses undergo regular \"routine exercise\" to get them used to loud city traffic sounds so they are well trained for major military parades and it was during one such exercise in the Belgravia area near Buckingham Palace on Wednesday morning that a few of them were spooked by builders dropping rubble from a height \"right next to them\".\n\nFirefighters assisted emergency services following the incident, using drones to locate the runaway horses.\n\n\"Due to reports that several horses were unaccounted for, the Brigade's response for large animal rescues was also alerted, along with the drone team and National Interagency Liaison Officers to assist in the search and the horses were quickly accounted for,\" said Assistant Commissioner Keeley Foster, who helped coordinate the London Fire Brigade's response.\n\nThe horses belonged to the Household Cavalry, which is the ceremonial guard of the British monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London. A taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed in the mayhem, while a parked double-decker tourist bus had its windshield damaged.\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public,\" said Inspector Myles Hilbery from City of London Police.\n\nHilbery praised his police constables who he said had risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses.\n\n\"They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive,\" he added.\n\nThe police force took control of the traffic, with officers on motorbikes creating a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care. {"uri": "2024-04-335025055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:27:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:27:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:13:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.kentonline.co.uk/news/national/two-military-horses-undergo-operations-after-running-loose-in-london-army-116013/", "title": "Two military horses undergo operations after running loose in London - Army", "body": "Two military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday have undergone operations, the Army has said.\n\nIt comes after defence minister James Cartlidge said the animals were in a \"serious condition\" on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Quaker.\n\nIn a statement on X, formerly Twitter, the Army said one of those operated on had been taken to an equine hospital.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nThe statement said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a with speckles of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, named Farez, revealed today how he was completely unaware of the horses' presence until one slammed into his car while waiting for a passenger.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was {"uri": "8095743413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:22:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:22:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:22:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/uk-military-horses-run-amok-causing-chaos-in-rush-hour-after-getting-spooked-during-exercise/2VHZRLT7LNESNMXIB6CKBFC3A4/", "title": "Military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "Two horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych on April 24. (Jordan Pettitt/PA via AP)\n\nFive military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which was conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighbourhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalised with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial centre and the busy West End theatre district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added. He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the incident erupted around 8.30am.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", {"uri": "2024-04-334442023", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:48:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/news/leicester-news/four-people-taken-hospital-after-9243553", "title": "Four in hospital after loose military horses bolt through London", "body": "Four people were left needing hospital treatment after loose military horses bolted through central London on Wednesday morning. The injured included a serviceman who was thrown from his horse.\n\nChaos erupted after seven animals got loose. The London Ambulance Service said it had treated four people across three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square and the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, after the horses ran amok.\n\nA serviceman was thrown from his horse in Buckingham Palace Road and one of the loose animals smashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows. LBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who said a white horse had collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side.\n\nTwo horses were seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood, and later near the Limehouse tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police. London Ambulance Service said it received three horse-related calls. The first was at 8.25am about a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nThe patient was taken to hospital. Two minutes later medics were called to nearby Belgrave Square and found two people injured by horses and took them to hospital. A further call was made at 8.35am at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street and a fourth person was taken to hospital.\n\nThe casualties were treated in three incidents that took place in the space of just 10 minutes. A horse also crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen, and one crashed into a taxi, but no one was hurt. Roland, a worker for tour bus company, Toot Bus, said the scene was \"total mayhem\".\n\n\"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said. \"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nPictures and videos of two of the animals running amok around London were shared on social media, one of which showed a black 4x4 with blue lights following two of the animals between Tower Bridge and Limehouse tunnel.\n\nCity of London Police said on X: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had become loose and were travelling through the City. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also reportedly hit, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent has been put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nThe Met Police said: 'We are aware of a number of horses that are currently loose in central London and are working with colleagues, including the Army, to locate them.'\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. Several personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" a spokesperson said.\n\nAlso Read | Japan: Smoke Seen as ANA Flight Carrying About 200 People Lands Safely in Northern Japan, Public TV Says.\n\nThe chaos is said to have erupted when the horses became alarmed by construction noise from builders working nearby.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off from where the exercise was taking place in Belgravia, a posh neighbourhood to the west of Buckingham Palace -- the residence of King Charles III.\n\nThe ceremonial exercise was part of preparations for the monarch's annual birthday parade, known as Trooping the Colour, next month.\n\nAccording to reports, several soldiers were thrown off after the horses were spooked and three of the soldiers had to be taken to the hospital with injuries.\n\n\"We responded to several calls regarding an incident with horses on the loose in central London this morning. We sent multiple resources to the three scenes, treating four patients in total and taking them all to the hospital. We have since been stood down,\" a London Ambulance Service statement said.\n\nThe horses belonged to the Household Cavalry, which is the ceremonial guard of the British monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed in the mayhem, while a parked double-decker tourist bus had its windshield damaged.\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public,\" said Inspector Myles Hilbery from the City of London Police.\n\nHilbery praised his police constables who he said had risked their safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses.\n\n\"They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive,\" he added.\n\nThe police force took control of the traffic, with officers on motorbikes creating a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care.", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Four service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a white one drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London. The pair were captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nTwo horses on the loose through the streets of London near Aldwych\n\nIt has now emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked white horse that was injured following the incident, might have a history of being spooked, including at the Coronation last year. The two horses were \"in a serious condition\" after the incident, Defence Minister James Cartlidge said this morning.\n\nThe Army then confirmed the two military horses have undergone operations, adding that three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\". The statement said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n\"Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed. Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\nThe horses were finally captured in Limehouse\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\" Jordan Pettitt, 26, said Vida was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets. In an update on X, formerly Twitter, Lieutenant Colonel Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said on Wednesday: \"This morning, a small group of horses were spooked by construction works on a quiet side road where building materials were dropped from height next to them.\n\n\"The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders. Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses. Our horses have all returned to Hyde Park Barracks and are undergoing veterinary care. Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and number of horses involved this type of incident is extremely rare.\"", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, {"uri": "8095174332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:19:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:19:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13344873/Londons-Cavalry-chaos-Moment-distressing-moment-five-army-horses-threw-riders-rampaged-six-miles-capital.html", "title": "How five horses broke away and rampaged through London", "body": "Chaos erupted in central London today as five horses threw off their riders and ran amok after being spooked by building works.\n\nFour soldiers lost their mounts at just after 8.20am before the animals fled through busy city streets, injuring four people in three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes.\n\nHorses slammed into a tour bus parked on Buckingham Palace Road and a taxi outside the Clermont Hotel - smashing their windows - before two were seen running through Aldwych with their chests covered in blood.\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back with the Army.\n\nBelow, MailOnline provides a minute by minute breakdown of how the dramatic incident unfolded.\n\nFour soldiers lost their mounts at just after 8.20am before the animals fled through busy city streets, injuring four people in three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes\n\n8.25am: Horses spooked\n\nThis morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nAs they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am, builders were using a travelator with concrete when some of the concrete came off and hit the floor, causing a noise.\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nThis caused the horses to spook. Five bolted and two remained in place. Four soldiers were unseated and three were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nOnlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\n8.25am - 8.35am: 'Total mayhem' unfolds\n\nOver the next 10 minutes the horses bolted around the streets, slamming into pedestrians and parked vehicles.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nLBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who said a white horse had collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\n8.35am onwards: Bloodied horses head east\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJournalist Jordan Pettitt, 26, said a white horse was 'vividly' stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nHe said: 'The A4 at the Aldwych is usually pretty busy and it suddenly just fell silent.\n\nTwo of the horses - one with its chest covered in blood - Aldwych bolt east through the streets of London near Aldwych\n\nJournalist Jordan Pettitt, 26, said a white horse was 'vividly' stained red with blood\n\n'There was no traffic on the roads and all of a sudden we could hear some clattering of hooves just at the top of the road. Then coming down the top of the road were these two horses.\n\n'They were coming down at quite a speed. They bolted southbound down the A4. Then as they came past me at some speed, they went straight down to the bottom of the road where it meets Fleet Street.\n\n'The traffic lights were at red with a few buses and some taxis waiting there. These horses came hurtling down past the pedestrian crossing at that moment. Then the black horse collided with a black taxi.\n\n'It was not to a great degree of power but it hit it strongly enough that we could hear it at the top of the road. You could hear the contact. Then it veered behind the taxi, went past the bus and headed eastbound on Fleet Street.\n\n'The white horse that was with it looked like it doubled back on itself and then followed the black one as it went eastbound.'\n\n10.30am: The final horses are captured\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company Tootbus, described the chaotic scenes near Victoria.\n\n'I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,' he said. 'People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.'\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nA second tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, said: 'One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control.\n\n'I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down. An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.'\n\nAn Army spokesman said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk",
