{"uri": "8095317267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:55:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:55:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13346155/household-cavalry-horse-spooked-captured-london.html", "title": "Moment escaped Household Cavalry horse is finally captured", "body": "This is the moment the Household Cavalry horses which were 'spooked' by builders were finally captured and loaded into a horsebox after the six-mile rampage.\n\nA builder's truck moving rubble is believed to have spooked five Household Cavalry horses that ran loose in central London this morning.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage that lasted two hours.\n\nThis morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nOnlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nThey were finally caught in Limehouse, east London.\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse began bleeding out onto the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nThe injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse this morning\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes today\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages for the bleeding\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it the animal had injured its leg\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel)\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nREAD MORE - Pictured: Builder's truck 'that spooked Household Cavalry horses with noise from moving rubble' as animals rampage across London for six miles, smashing into vehicles and pedestrians and leaving four injured\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army at around 9.30am.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water - there was that much blood.\n\n'They asked us but we didn't have any so they had to call a fire engine in.'\n\nMany residents of Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nOthers had no idea the horses had been recovered so close by.\n\n'I thought it looked familiar in the videos!' said one man.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\n'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse,' he added.\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes this morning\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nFive Household Cavalry horses ran loose in central London after throwing their military riders\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London today\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses smashed into cars and a bus\n\nAs they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am, it is believed builders were using a travelator with concrete when some of the concrete came off and hit the floor, causing a noise.\n\nThis is thought to have caused the horses to spook. Five bolted and two remained in place. Four soldiers were unseated and three were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, late this morning\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nLondoners were seen avoiding one of the horses as it ran along the pavement. One horse reportedly ran into a black cab\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses as they fled through the city\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was shocked when a horse collided with his car, lifting it up into the air on one side\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the startling incident (Pictured: A crumpled police accident sign at the scene)\n\nPassersby were shocked to see the incident unfold this morning\n\nThe horses were running at some pace after they became spooked while exercising\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose\n\nREAD MORE: Taxi driver reveals his 'shock' at the moment a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his Mercedes near Buckingham Palace and left the car splattered in blood Advertisement\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces this morning\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News.\n\nThe names of the injured horses are Vida and Quaker, he added.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses, with five of the animals getting loose, reportedly after they were spooked by concrete being moved by builders hitting the ground.\n\nTwo horses then ran along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nThree of the unseated soldiers were taken to hospital where they were being assessed but none was in a life-threatening condition.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge stressed that Wednesday's events were \"extremely unlikely\" to be repeated.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day,\" he told LBC radio.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 08:25 to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nTwo of the horses were recaptured by the City of London Police, which polices the Square Mile financial district.\n\nOfficers contained {"uri": "8095277472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:26:39", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:26:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.spectator.co.uk/article/was-the-london-horse-rampage-avoidable/", "title": "Was the London horse rampage avoidable?", "body": "The sight of runaway military horses - one covered in blood - wasn't what any Londoner expected to encounter on their commute this morning. Five horses from the Household Cavalry bolted during a rehearsal, having been frightened by noisy builders near Buckingham Palace. At least four people were hurt and several vehicles smashed. Two of the animals travelled five miles to Limehouse, in east London, before they were rounded up.\n\nIt's no wonder people were surprised. If you live in London, you're unlikely to see horses regularly - and, if you do see them, they'd usually be behaving themselves and on duty, not galloping blind and riderless through the roads.\n\nWhile the horses that the army and police use for their respective duties are subject to thorough training and exposed to all kinds of sights and sounds before they're allowed out on public duty, we need to remember that horses will always be horses. They are flight animals, whose instincts will tell them to run away from any dangerous situation. They're also herd animals; if one animals gets scared and runs, the others are naturally inclined to follow.\n\nAlthough the vehicle-packed London of today is not naturally suited to horses, it hasn't always been this way. Only 150 years ago, the streets of the capital would have been equally packed with horses: some pulling private carriages; others harnessed to forms of public transport such as horse-drawn omnibuses or wagonettes pulled by two or three horses, and other horses carrying riders. Many houses in the suburbs had their own stable, as did most pubs - particularly coaching inns. The mews houses of central London which today sell for several million pounds a pop were built as stabling and grooms' accommodation. And London's street names still pay homage to equines: Dray Walk, Stable Way, Cheval Place, and so on.\n\nPeople may well complain about air pollution caused by vehicle emissions today, but while there was no Ulez (Ultra-low emission zone) charge in the 1800s, there were plenty of equine emissions. In London alone, an army of around 8,000 road sweepers worked through the night to clear up horse manure, toiling in the darkness to tidy the streets in time for the morning rush. Wagons which had brought food and produce from the countryside to London returned home carrying horse manure back to the fields where it could be put to use.\n\nThe London of then was a very different place from today. After this morning's furore, many people have been asking why there are still horses in London today, and questioning whether they ought to be there.\n\nIt's true that, if given a choice, a horse would probably prefer to be in a green pasture somewhere far from the hustle and bustle of the capital than treading over tarmac every day. But the few horses that are still here in London do play an important role.\n\nThe horses of the Met's Mounted Branch are housed at one of eight stables across the capital. The City of London Police also maintain a mounted branch. Just yesterday, as the police clashed with protestors at a St George's Day rally on Downing Street, mounted police were on crowd-patrol duty. While being on a horse provides a better vantage point at events like this or at football matches, a policeman on horseback can also act as more of a physical deterrent to any would-be troublemakers.\n\nThe Army horses on the other hand - mainly those of the Household Cavalry - are mainly used for ceremonial purposes. There will almost always be two horses from the King's Life Guard division on guard duty at Horse Guards: the official entrance to Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace. At events like Trooping the Colour, State Visits and the State Opening of Parliament, as well as at other ceremonial occasions, Household Cavalry horses will take pride of place at the centre of proceedings. The Army argue that the use of horses in their ceremonial duties sends a message to the rest of the world about their operational capabilities: 'For a country with global interests these roles offer a powerful symbol of our operational military heritage, whilst enhancing the standing of the Sovereign and the Nation before both national and international audiences.'\n\nPerhaps the London of 2024 isn't the ideal home for a horse; but it's both important to remember and a huge tribute to these animals that, 99 per cent of the time, these horses and the daily cacophony of London life go hand in hand with little or no disturbance to the daily grind.\n\nThe horses are wonderfully treated, and all those involved in today's incident have already been seen by the vets and are being treated accordingly. During the summer, the Army horses travel to Norfolk for an annual training camp and enjoy a beach ride at Holkham Bay. Similarly, the horses of the mounted police regiments don't live in London permanently, and regularly enjoy 'time out' in the countryside for a change of scenery.\n\nIt's also important for some of the specific breeds of horse who suit police or army service that they continue to have a role. There are fewer than 3,000 Shire horses in Britain today, and the breed is classed as being officially 'At Risk', as many of the jobs that they were bred to do are now carried out by machines or tractors. Most people who want a horse these days don't need anything of that size or strength. But the Household Cavalry's drum horses are typically Shires, meaning that, as long as horses continue to carry out ceremonial duties, Shires will still have this role. Similarly the Irish Draft horses and crosses used by the Police and Army are less in demand as riding horses, but can continue their lines as long as the Mounted Regiments exist.\n\nThe sight of horses running amok in London was shocking, and we should hope that those injured are recovering well. But while there will be questions about how this incident was allowed to happen - and about why it took so long to bring the horses under control - the truth is that we'd miss these animals if they vanished for good from the streets of London.", "source": {"uri": "spectator.us", "dataType": "news", "title": "Spectator USA"}, "authors": [{"uri": "camilla_swift@spectator.us", "name": "Camilla Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. A taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed in the mayhem, while a parked double-decker tourist bus had its windshield damaged.\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public,\" said Inspector Myles Hilbery from City of London {"uri": "8096557378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:43:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:43:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:42:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/two-military-horses-undergo-operations-29058215", "title": "Horses 'undergo operations' after running loose through city", "body": "Two military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday have undergone operations, the Army has said. It comes after defence minister James Cartlidge said the animals were in a \"serious condition\" on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson. Vida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Quaker.\n\nIn a statement on X, formerly Twitter, the Army said one of those operated on had been taken to an equine hospital. A group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries. The Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nThe statement said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition. He added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen. Two horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to {"uri": "8095537297", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:53:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:53:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:53:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13346607/horse-hurt-household-cavalry-London-vets.html", "title": "Horse seen badly hurt in London today is being looked after by vets", "body": "The white horse which was seen badly injured among the Household Cavalry animals who bolted through London this morning is now back at its barracks being looked after by vets.\n\nEarlier today five horses from the regiment caused mayhem in London, running loose through the capital after throwing off their military riders during their morning exercise.\n\nA British Army spokesperson confirmed this afternoon that the animals were 'spooked by construction works' when building materials were 'dropped from a height'.\n\nSix soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nBut the animals were startled and they fled through the city leaving five people, including three soldiers riding the horses, injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage that lasted two hours.\n\nThey were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. Held at the side of the road by officers, the white horse began bleeding out onto the road, drenched in blood.\n\nSpeaking after the incident, Lieutenant Colonel Matt Woodward, the Commanding Officer of the Household Calvary Mounted Regiment, said the horses are 'undergoing veterinary care' and were all safely returned to Hyde Park Barracks to recover.\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes this morning\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel)\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London today\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete spooked the horses\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages for the bleeding\n\nOnlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nREAD MORE - Moment escaped Household Cavalry horse 'spooked by builders' is finally captured: Bleeding animal with badly injured leg is loaded into horsebox after six-mile rampage\n\nAdvertisement\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army at around 9.30am.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.'\n\nThere was so much blood that there wasn't enough water to clean it up, and a fire engine had to be called in to hose down the area.\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nThe Commanding Officer of the regiment said: 'Every morning, the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment in London exercises some 150 horses in the parks and on the roads.\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse this morning\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one\n\n'This keeps them fit and helps inoculate them to city noise so they're less easily panicked on parades.\n\n'This morning however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia, where building materials were dropped from height right next to them.\n\n'The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders. Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of all soldiers, members of the public and our horses.\n\nREAD MORE - Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards\n\nAdvertisement\n\n'This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped us to bring our injured horses to safety.\n\n'Three of our soldiers have incurred injuries which are not deemed to be life threatening and they're receiving treatment in hospital, while our horses have all returned to Hyde Park Barracks and are undergoing veterinary care.\n\n'Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare.\n\n'We continue to strive to minimise the risk of this recurring. As ever, we are grateful for the due consideration given by the members of the public to not making loud noises around our horses.\n\n'We appreciate your concern, understanding and patience as we work through this matter.'\n\nIf the horse is injured to the point it can no longer work, it may be places in a 'retirement' home of sorts, similar to what happens when military horses get old.\n\nAccording to the British Army website, after reaching 18 years of age, most military working horses retire to carefully screened, loving families or farms.\n\nThey enjoy new life as hunters or hack ponies, or 'just live out their days peacefully with former soldiers with whom they struck up a powerful bond'.\n\nCaptain Skip Nicholls explains on the website: 'Most military working horses will serve an eighteen-year career. It's not heavy work but they do have to carry a lot of weight with all the ceremonial uniforms, and we will never work a horse to the point they can't continue at peak performance.\n\nFive Household Cavalry horses ran loose in central London after throwing their military riders\n\n'We want them to retire with some quality life left in them so they can enjoy a happy 5-10 years retirement in a nice home'.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nREAD MORE - Household Cavalry horses that ran amok across London today are famed as the unflappable King's bodyguard trained to ignore artillery fire - and as favourites of tourists keen for a picture Advertisement\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said earlier today: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nREAD MORE - Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\nOur officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier (pictured)\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nREAD MORE - London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing.\n\nThis experience inspired his song No Bravery.Meanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: horses are in a 'serious condition' after running loose", "body": "Two horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'.\n\nHousehold Cavalry horses Vida and Quaker were two of five that bolted as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am yesterday and heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor from a builder's travelator.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours.\n\nYesterday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said Vida and Quaker were 'in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive'.\n\nTwo horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, on Wednesday\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nHe told Sky News today: '[They] are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.'\n\nFour soldiers were unseated as the spooked horses bolted and three servicemen were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nHowever, onlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nREAD MORE: LIVE: Horses covered in blood rampage through central London with one soldier left injured as five animals smash into oncoming traffic Advertisement\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nLondoners were seen avoiding one of the horses as it ran along the pavement. One horse reportedly ran into a black cab\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nREAD MORE: Taxi driver reveals his 'shock' at the moment a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his Mercedes near Buckingham Palace and left the car splattered in blood Advertisement\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes on Wednesday\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it became apparent that the animal had injured its leg\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages stemming the bleeding\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/animals/spooked-horses-cause-rush-hour-chaos-in-london-c-14433558", "title": "Spooked horses cause rush hour chaos in London", "body": "Spooked horses cause rush hour chaos in LondonStaff WritersAPThu, 25 April 2024 4:56AM\n\nFive military horses spooked by noise from a nearby building site have bolted during routine exercises near Buckingham Palace, unseating four riders and causing chaos as they galloped through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nIt is believed the chaos erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighbourhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off with four soldiers thrown off.\n\nThree of them were hospitalised with injuries.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nThe riderless horses then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work.\n\nThe horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses - one white, one black - running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historical financial centre and the busy West End theatre district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood.\n\nA British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said.\n\n\"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an army spokesperson said.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the horses ran amok about 8.30am.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the qrmy has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt (26), who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a {"uri": "8095182919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:25:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:25:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:24:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/5-runaway-military-horses-cause-mayhem-in-london-4510099", "title": "5 runaway military horses cause mayhem in London", "body": "London, Apr 24 (PTI) Five riderless military horses that bolted during a routine exercise on Wednesday morning unleashed rush-hour mayhem on the streets of central London near Buckingham Palace, injuring at least four people.\n\nScenes of one blood-covered horse galloping along Aldwych near the High Commission of India and the West End theatre district were shared widely on social media after the horses collided with cars and smashed into a tourist bus.\n\nThe British Army later confirmed that all its horses had been recovered and returned to their camp, where they were receiving medical attention.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. Several personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" a spokesperson said.\n\nThe chaos is said to have erupted when the horses became alarmed by construction noise from builders working nearby.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off from where the exercise was taking place in Belgravia, a posh neighbourhood to the west of Buckingham Palace -- the residence of King Charles III.\n\nThe ceremonial exercise was part of preparations for the monarch's annual birthday parade, known as Trooping the Colour, next month.\n\nAccording to reports, several soldiers were thrown off after the horses were spooked and three of the soldiers had to be taken to the hospital with injuries.\n\n\"We responded to several calls regarding an incident with horses on the loose in central London this morning. We sent multiple resources to the three scenes, treating four patients in total and taking them all to the hospital. We have since been stood down,\" a London Ambulance Service statement said.\n\nThe horses belonged to the Household Cavalry, which is the ceremonial guard of the British monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed in the mayhem, while a parked double-decker tourist bus had its windshield damaged.\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public,\" said Inspector Myles Hilbery from the City of London Police.\n\nHilbery praised his police constables who he said had risked their safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses.\n\n\"They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive,\" he added.\n\nThe police force took control of the traffic, with officers on motorbikes creating a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care. {"uri": "8095217946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:48:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:48:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.adn.com/nation-world/2024/04/24/rush-hour-chaos-in-london-as-5-military-horses-run-amok-after-getting-spooked-during-a-drill/", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during a drill", "body": "LONDON -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a nearby building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, unseating four riders and causing chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nIt is believed the chaos erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off with four soldiers thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries.\n\nThe riderless horses then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head Three soldiers were injured but are expected to recover fully and return to duty, the army added.\n\n\"What I can say is that five horses have been recovered to the army - three of those are fine, but unfortunately two of them are in quite a serious condition and we'll be continuing to monitor them,\" UK defense procurement minister James Cartlidge told local radio station LBC Thursday.\n\nHost Nick Ferrari asked if the pair would \"pull through,\" to which Cartlidge responded that he \"wouldn't want to speculate,\" but the animals were in a \"serious condition.\"\n\nCartlidge went on to emphasize that an incident like this is \"very exceptional,\" adding that the army has horses out on exercise in London every day.\n\nThe two horses are said to be in a \"serious condition.\" Jordan Pettitt/PA\n\nThe minister had separately told Sky News that the two horses are called Vida and Quaker.\n\n\"Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital,\" said the British Army on X Thursday.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\"\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. one apparently covered in blood on its chest and forelegs\n\nLONDON: Four people were taken to hospital after spooked army horses broke loose during morning exercises in central London and galloped through the streets at rush hour, the army and emergency services said.\n\nPhotos and video posted on social media by British news outlets showed two horses running along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nBoth were wearing saddles and bridles, with one apparently covered in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\nA number of prestigious army cavalry regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said it was called at 8:25 am (0725 GMT) to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nNo details were released on the injured people or the exact circumstances of their injuries.\n\nThe driver of a Mercedes car told LBC radio he had been waiting outside a hotel in Buckingham Palace Road when he felt something smash into his car.\n\nHe said he saw three or four horses near the vehicle, and that an army rider had been thrown off and injured.\n\nOne horse also reportedly crashed into a parked double-decker tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nOne commuter shared a video on social media platform X, formerly Twitter, showing a black horse and a white horse being pursued by a black car.\n\n\"It was the street from Tower Bridge toward Limehouse Tunnel... just running past cars and an unmarked Range Rover following them,\" the person said.\n\nUp to seven horses initially got loose, Britain's domestic Press Association news agency reported, with police working with the army to recapture them.\n\nThe army said in a statement that \"a number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\"\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and
