All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nHere is the full timeline of the horses' movements:\n\nBelgravia, between 8am and 8.25am\n\nFour soliders are dismounted after five horses are spooked during a rehearsal in Belgravia, central London.\n\nThis area is located between Hyde Park Barracks, which hosts the stables where most of the Household Cavalry horses are kept, and the Horse Guard near Whitehall.\n\nAn army spokesperson has said that one serviceman was responsible for two horses, explaining the additional horse.\n\nJust before 8.25am, one serviceman is severely injured after his horse collides with a car on Buckingham Palace Road, throwing him to the ground. The London Ambulance service arrives on the scene promptly.\n\nAt least two horses, one white and one black, then begin to run towards Buckingham Palace.\n\nOn the way, one collides with a parked tour bus, causing serious damage. It is thought this is how the white horse sustained the injury seen in footage and images.\n\nThe Strand, between 8.30am and 8.35am\n\nAfter running past Buckingham Palace, the two horses speed down The Mall towards The Strand, covering nearly 2 miles in around five minutes.\n\nMaking their way around Aldwych, the black horse collides with a taxi outside of a coffee shop.\n\nBoth continue down Fleet Street, when one hits a person on the corner of Chancery Lane. An ambulance is called and the person has been taken to hospital.\n\nShadwell, 8.55am\n\nBoth horses run without reported incident for around 20 minutes, covering 2.6 miles as they head into East London. The most likely route would have seen them pass landmarks such as St. Paul's Cathedral and Tower Hill.\n\nThey are spotted again at 8.55am, near St. George's Leisure Centre, Shadwell. They travel only a little further into the Tower Hamlets neighbourhood until they stop on Glamis Road, near the Rotherhithe Tunnel.\n\nIt is here that police are able to capture the two horses, with footage showing the white horse being ushered into a mobile horsebox, seemingly with a broken leg.\n\nThe total distance the two horses covered is an estimated five miles, with police confirming that All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a British army spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nMedical authorities said four people had been taken to hospital after being injured.\n\nTelevision images showed one saddled white horse seemingly covered in blood running through the street alongside another, black one.\n\nLondon's Metropolitan Police had said initially that authorities were working to locate \"a number of horses that are currently loose in central London\", before confirming later that the animals had been all been accounted for.\n\nThe horses belong to the Household Cavalry, which acts as the British monarch's official bodyguard and takes part in ceremonial duties. {"uri": "8096195252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:59:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:59:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:58:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/army-blood-soaked-horses-running-32666168", "title": "Army blood-soaked horses running wild in London were spooked due to construction", "body": "The army has confirmed that the blood-soaked horses spotted running through central London this morning, causing havoc in the nation's capital, are \"safe\" and undergoing veterinary care.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an exercise in Belgravia when chaos erupted on the streets. The powerful animals were scared when concrete was dropped by builders and landed next to them, causing four service personnel to be thrown from their steeds, reports the Mirror.\n\nFive of the horses got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries. They were pictured running through busy areas of the city, one of them bloodied, before they were finally stopped and brought under control.\n\nIn an update on X, formerly Twitter, Lieutenant Colonel Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said: \"This morning, a small group of horses were spooked by construction works on a quiet side road where building materials were dropped from height next to them.\n\n\"The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders. Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses. Our horses have all returned to Hyde Park Barracks and are undergoing veterinary care. Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and number of horses involved this type of incident is extremely rare.\"\n\nThree soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, but they were not thought to be serious. A white horse collided with a Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood splattered down the side. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen in the process.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by London cops and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nIn a Tweet, the British Army said: \"Thank you to Met Police, City of London Police, London Ambulance Service, London Fire Brigade and members of the public for reacting as quickly as they did. This enabled the swift treatment of our soldiers and helped us to bring our injured horses to safety.\"\n\nWitness Tula, a management consultant from south London, said: \"I got off the 172 bus which ends at Aldwych and two horses went flying past. One black, one white. The white one was drenched in blood from the chest down and they were galloping through the traffic at speed.\n\n\"People were stopping in the street shocked. The horses were running into fast-moving traffic and seemed terrified. Some unmarked police cars were chasing after them, which didn't seem to be helping. I felt shocked. It was pretty gruesome. Felt like a weird dream.\"\n\nInspector Myles Hilbery, City of London Police added: \"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public.\n\n\"Police Constables Lucy Hawes and Daniel McKeown risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses. They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive.\n\n\"PCs Brett Daniels and Chris Wilson took over management of traffic control on the busy arterial road enabling PCs Rob Bray and Shaun Gurney on motorbikes to create a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care. Our thoughts are with those people and horses injured in the incident.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond. They stopped all the traffic.\"\n\nPictures of the car show a large dent in a side door splattered in blood. At least two windows of the vehicle have been smashed.\n\nWitnesses spotted the animals running through central London with two horses being caught in Limehouse - five miles away from Buckingham Palace, where the incident began.\n\nFootage shared on social media showed two of the animals being followed by an unmarked police car.\n\nOne witness told the Standard they saw the animals \"running past cars and an unmarked range rover following them\" near Tower Bridge.\n\nIt is understood one of the horses hit a taxi and a bus.\n\nBig Bus Tours confirmed that a horse ran into one of its parked buses. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a grey drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London(Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting "https://assets1.cbsnewsstatic.com/hub/i/r/2024/04/24/4dffb8eb-0728-4048-bab8-b0ddf601bc4a/thumbnail/1200x630/93ccaffd31822cedce720be59ea2c2df/london-horses-loose-2149382613.jpg?v=1da0267dcfd5e1d387d4678a648e733c", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9507834", "eventUri": "eng-9507834", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1607843137254902, "wgt": 197, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8097252383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "18:24:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T18:24:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T18:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://todayheadline.co/two-rampaging-horses-condition-running-loose-london-spooked-builders-dropping-rubble-htmlns_mchannelrssns_campaign1490ito1490/", "title": "Two 'seriously' injured runaway Household Cavalry horses undergo operations and are being 'closely observed', Army reveals - as it emerges white runaway 'Vida' has history of being spooked and 'kicked soldier in head during King's coronation'", "body": "Two horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition' and have undergone operations.\n\nHousehold Cavalry horses Vida and Quaker were two of five that were spooked as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am on Wednesday and heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor from a builder's travelator.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours.\n\nIt emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked white horse, reportedly has a history of being spooked and even allegedly kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nOne of the five tried to bolt but was caught in time, but horses Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson all joined Vida in running loose.\n\nArmy top brass told MailOnline the horses were given the best treatment possible by military vets, which saved their lives.\n\nA spokesman told MailOnline: 'Be in no doubt, had these not been military horses then their chances of survival would have been greatly reduced.'\n\nVida, a grey that was seen bleeding heavily after clattering into a parked minivan outside The Clermont Hotel near Victoria station, underwent surgery last night and is new recovering under observation at the Hyde Park barracks.\n\nQuaker, meanwhile, is the more seriously injured of the two and was transferred to an undisclosed equine hospital this morning after also undergoing surgery last night.\n\nIt is not yet known for sure if Quaker was the black horse captured on mobile phone footage moments after colliding into a parked tourist bus near Buckingham Palace.\n\nNeither horse is understood to have suffered any broken bones and have been treated for serious cuts and blood loss.\n\nAn Army spokesman told MailOnline: 'We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery. Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n'But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and had they not been attached to the army then I don't believe they would have made it this far.\n\n'Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying. Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n'Quaker is the most seriously injured and was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours.\n\n'The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones. The injuries are consistent with serious lacerations.'\n\nOn Wednesday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: 'Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n'All three soldiers involved are expected to recover fully and to return to duty.\n\n'Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n'Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\n'We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses.'\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said Vida and Quaker were 'in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive'.\n\nHe told Sky News today: '[They] are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.'\n\nThe military horses who ran loose through London was an 'exceptional' situation, the minister added, explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day.\n\nToday, members of the Household Cavalry are set to parade at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment.\n\nMr Cartlidge told LBC: 'Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n'You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n'So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.'\n\nAn Army source told The Sun that the white horse that was drenched in blood, Vida, was 'lively' and had a history of being spooked.\n\nVida is thought to have kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nUsually Household Cavalry horses are black, however the regiment's state trumpeters always ride white or grey horses such as Vida.\n\nFour soldiers were unseated as the spooked horses bolted and three servicemen were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nOnlookers yesterday said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today [Wednesday] to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Commanding Officer Matt Woodward said: 'Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before {"uri": "8094615328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:45:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:45:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:44:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3260207/escaped-army-horses-run-loose-central-london", "title": "Not a one horse town: escaped army horses run loose in central London", "body": "Footage posted by social media users showed a saddled white horse seemingly covered in blood running through the street alongside another, black one\n\nThe Daily Telegraph said up to five army horses had thrown their riders while they were being exercised, and at least one soldier was injured.\n\nTwo army horses that were seen galloping through central London at rush hour on Wednesday have been contained, police and media reports said.\n\nPhotos and video posted on social media and by British news outlets showed the horses running along busy roads, dodging buses, taxis and other traffic.\n\nBoth were wearing saddles and bridles, with one apparently covered in blood on its chest and forelegs.\n\nLondon\u2019s Metropolitan Police said it was \u201cworking with colleagues in the army to locate them\u201d.\n\nA number of prestigious army regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service was called at 08:25am local time to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road in Three soldiers were injured but are expected to recover fully and return to duty, the army added.\n\n\"What I can say is that five horses have been recovered to the army - three of those are fine, but unfortunately two of them are in quite a serious condition and we'll be continuing to monitor them,\" UK defense procurement minister James Cartlidge told local radio station LBC Thursday.\n\nHost Nick Ferrari asked if the pair would \"pull through,\" to which Cartlidge responded that he \"wouldn't want to speculate,\" but the animals were in a \"serious condition.\"\n\nCartlidge went on to emphasize that an incident like this is \"very exceptional,\" adding that the army has horses out on exercise in London every day.\n\nThe minister had separately told Sky News that the two horses are called Vida and Quaker.\n\n\"Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital,\" said the British Army on X Thursday.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\"\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. {"uri": "2024-04-334458560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:20:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:20:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T18:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.1news.co.nz/2024/04/25/rush-hour-chaos-in-london-as-five-military-horses-run-amok/", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as five military horses run amok", "body": "Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises near Buckingham Palace, throwing off four riders and causing chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighbourhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalised with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters. The horses were all captured shortly after and were taken to barracks in Hyde Park for medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial centre and the busy West End theatre district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses were from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added. He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.", {"uri": "8095502411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:21:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.wptv.com/spooked-military-horses-bolt-through-london-and-injure-at-least-4-people", "title": "Spooked military horses bolt through London and injure at least 4 people", "body": "Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off, and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of the injuries were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered was not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added. He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.\n\nThe {"uri": "8095495508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:15:18", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:15:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:15:07Z", "dataType": "news", "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13346553/Horses-Household-Cavalry-ran-riot-London-spooked-building-work-carried-15million-mansion-owned-former-West-Bromwich-Albion-chairman.html", "title": "Horses from the Household Cavalry ran riot through London", "body": "Building work on a \u00a315million Belgravia mansion owned by former West Bromwich Albion chairman Jeremy Peace spooked horses from the household cavalry, causing them to throw their riders and run amok through London, MailOnline can reveal.\n\nFive military horses bolted when a lump of concrete or a rock crashed onto the floor during renovation work on the multi-millionaire businessman's townhouse.\n\nThree soldiers and a cyclist were injured as the animals galloped through the streets smashing into cars, a taxi and a tourist bus.\n\nThe Ministry of Defence said six soldiers from the Life Guards and Blues & Royals were on their daily exercise this morning.\n\nAs they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia builders using a travelator accidentally dropped some rubble onto the floor as the horses passed, an MoD spokesman said.\n\nMailOnline can reveal that the building work was a basement extension that Mr Peace is currently having on his five-floor home close to the Bangladesh High Commission and the Argentine and Mexican Embassies.\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes this morning\n\nConstruction workers involved in the project said today that they had not seen the horses and heard no commotion. They said the travelator, which was being used to transfer excavated earth and soil from the basement onto a truck parked outside the building had been switched on just after 8am this morning.\n\nMr Peace, 67, joined the board of West Bromwich Albion as a non-executive director in 2000 and became chairman in June 2002.\n\nHe sold the club to Chinese businessman Guochuan Lai for \u00a3200million in 2016 when the club was still in the Premier League.\n\nHis role as chairman was taken up by former Blackburn Rovers chief, John Williams, although he agreed to stay at Albion until the end of the season as an advisor.\n\nMr Peace borrowed \u00a33.7million from the club and placed it in his own company, WBA Holdings, before the takeover.\n\nThe debt was inherited by Mr Lai and is now thought to total around \u00a35m, including interest.\n\nAn independent investigation into the 2014 loan was launched at the start of 2023 and expected to report its findings later this year.\n\nHe worked in accountancy before becoming a stockbroker and moving on to investment banking in 1983.\n\nOnlookers said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London. The injured horses saw a vet and all of the animals are now back at the Army's camp.\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nFive Household Cavalry horses ran loose in central London after throwing their military riders\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London this morning\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, this morning\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nOne of the horses also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nREAD MORE: LIVE: Horses covered in blood rampage through central London with one soldier left injured as five animals smash into oncoming traffic Advertisement\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nA white horse on the loose bolts through the streets of London near Aldwych\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was shocked when a horse collided with his car, lifting it up into the air on one side\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the startling incident (pictured: A crumpled police accident sign at the scene)\n\nPassersby were shocked to see the incident unfold\n\nThe horses were running at some pace after they became spooked while exercising\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nFootage of two horses being caught outside Gordon House on the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London, appeared to show that the white horse had broken its leg.\n\nStill drenched in blood, the horse's back left leg was bandaged and the animal seemed unwilling to walk on it.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nREAD MORE: Taxi driver reveals his 'shock' at the moment a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his Mercedes near Buckingham Palace and left the car splattered in blood Advertisement\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nAn Army Spokesperson said: 'A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n'All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n'A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.'\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes this morning\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it became apparent that the animal had injured its leg\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages stemming the bleeding\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household The chaos unfolded when two horses were spotted galloping along the road near Aldwych, with one appearing to be bloodstained.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News on Thursday morning: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Man, 65, in critical condition after 'sickening attack' by 'two teenagers' at Stockport Interchange\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\" The minister also confirmed the names of the two animals, Vida and Quaker.\n\nMr Cartilage said the situation was 'exceptional,' explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day. Pressed on the condition of the horses by LBC, he said he 'wouldn't want to say more' than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional. You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nA taxi driver, who was parked outside the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, had his Mercedes people carrier's windows shattered by one startled horse. Additionally, a double-decker tour bus parked nearby suffered a smashed windscreen after being hit by one of the horses.\n\nLBC interviewed Faraz, the Mercedes driver, who recounted the moment his vehicle was struck while he waited outside the Clermont Hotel. He witnessed three or four horses close to his car and saw a soldier being thrown off and hurt.\n\nAuthorities believe that seven horses initially escaped, with police collaborating with the Army to secure them. Social media was flooded with images and footage of two horses running wild through the streets of London, including one video showing a black 4x4 with blue lights in pursuit of the animals between Tower Bridge and Limehouse tunnel.\n\nCity of London Police officers managed to capture two horses that had broken loose and were wandering through the city. {"uri": "8095264575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:18:14", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:18:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:17:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/world/rush-hour-chaos-in-london-as-5-military-horses-run-amok-after-getting-spooked-during/article_1b00f7f0-6113-50bd-90f9-b0c66eee0568.html", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a nearby building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, unseating four riders and causing chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nIt is believed the chaos erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off with four soldiers thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries.\n\nThe riderless horses then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a regular feature of state functions in London.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an army spokesperson said. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the horses ran amok around 8:30 a.m.\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8095344110", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:13:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:13:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://6abc.com/horses-on-the-loose-in-central-london-5-military-run-amok-after-getting-spooked-during-exercise/14725828/", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "LONDON -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses - minus their riders - then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses - one white, one black - running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added., He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the incident erupted around 8:30 a.m.", "source": {"uri": Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nSeveral loose horses caused mayhem on the streets of London on Wednesday after becoming spooked during a routine rehearsal.\n\nFour people have been taken to hospital following the incident, as at least two of the horses running several miles across the capital.\n\nFootage shows the animals - one covered in blood - colliding with vehicles, with at least on report of a collision with a person.\n\nThe two horses are believed to have travelled from Belgravia, near Buckingham Palace, all the way to the East London area of Shadwell.\n\nAt around 11am, an Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nHere is the full timeline of the horses' movements:\n\nBelgravia, between 8am and 8.25am\n\nFour soliders are dismounted after five horses are spooked during a rehearsal in Belgravia, central London.\n\nThis area is located between Hyde Park Barracks, which hosts the stables where most of the Household Cavalry horses are kept, and the Horse Guard near Whitehall.\n\nAn army spokesperson has said that one serviceman was responsible for two horses, explaining the additional horse.\n\nJust before 8.25am, one serviceman is severely injured after his horse collides with a car on Buckingham Palace Road, throwing him to the ground. The London Ambulance service arrives on the scene promptly.\n\nAt least two horses, one white and one black, then begin to run towards Buckingham Palace.\n\nOn the way, one collides with a parked tour bus, causing serious damage. It is thought this is how the white horse sustained the injury seen in footage and images.\n\nThe Strand, between 8.30am and 8.35am\n\nAfter running past Buckingham Palace, the two horses speed down The Mall towards The Strand, covering nearly 2 miles in around five minutes.\n\nMaking their way around Aldwych, the black horse collides with a taxi outside of a coffee shop.\n\nBoth continue down Fleet Street, when one hits a person on the corner of Chancery Lane. An ambulance is called and the person has been taken to hospital.\n\nShadwell, 8.55am\n\nBoth horses run without reported incident for around 20 minutes, covering 2.6 miles as they head into East London. The most likely route would have seen them pass landmarks such as St. Paul's Cathedral and Tower Hill.\n\nThey are spotted again at 8.55am, near St. George's Leisure Centre, Shadwell. They travel only a little further into the Tower Hamlets neighbourhood until they stop on Glamis Road, near the Rotherhithe Tunnel.\n\nIt is here that police are able to capture the two horses, with footage showing the white horse being ushered into a mobile horsebox, seemingly with a broken leg.\n\nThe total distance the two horses covered is an estimated five miles, with police confirming that
