{"uri": "8095085163", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:25:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:25:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:22:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/four-injured-blood-covered-runaway-141950412.html", "title": "Four injured by blood-covered runaway horses in London", "body": "Runaway military horses charged through central London injuring four people during rush hour on Wednesday morning.\n\nFive horses from the Household Cavalry bolted after throwing off their riders during their morning exercise in Belgravia when they were spooked by nearby builders moving rubble.\n\nThe horses careered through the streets, smashing into a double-decker tour bus and a Mercedes-Benz people carrier.\n\nWitnesses on Buckingham Palace road recounted seeing a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel and shattering its windows.\n\nFootage captured by passersby showed a bloodstained gray horse galloping through the traffic around Tower Bridge and the Strand.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nHello, thank you for following our coverage of today's events.\n\nHere is a summary of what we know so far.\n\nA management consultant from London who saw two military horses bolt through the capital said it was \"gruesome\" and \"like a weird dream\".\n\nTula, 28, from south London, was on the 172 bus to Aldwych when she saw two horses gallop past her and said members of the public looked \"shocked\" at the incident.\n\nShe told the PA news agency: \"I got off the 172 bus which ends at Aldwych and two horses went flying past. One black, one white.\n\n\"The white one was drenched in blood from the chest down and they were galloping through the traffic at speed.\n\n\"People were stopping in the street shocked. The horses were running into fast-moving traffic and seemed terrified. Some unmarked police cars were chasing after them, which didn't seem to be helping.\n\n\"I felt shocked. It was pretty gruesome. Felt like a weird dream.\"\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, central London, on Wednesday when chaos erupted.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10\n\nBobbie Pryor, a travel presenter for BBC Radio Two, said she contemplated throwing herself in the path of two of the runaway horses\n\nShe recounted witnessing the horses charging through the street outside Charing Cross station as she was on her morning commute.\n\nShe told Jeremy Vine's lunchtime radio programme: \"As I looked to the left I saw two horses coming towards me, I ran just to get across the road.\n\n\"It was coming at such a speed, I thought, I need to stop those horses, I need to stop those horses but they are huge and coming at speed.\n\nAsked by Jeremy Vine how she would have attempted to stop them, she replied: \"I have been around horses before but normally you try and put yourself in the way, if it is safe to do so.\n\n\"There was a clear road ahead and I was thinking if I don't stop them they are going to go straight into those buses up there and that is really upsetting.\n\n\"Also you can't get in the way, in the fact at least they are running in a straight line, you have got people either side, you have got glass windows, you could create a worse situation.\n\n\"At least if they run for a bit they may be able to run out of breath.\"\n\nA photographer has said he was surprised to see a bloodstained riderless white horse charge past him in central London on Wednesday morning.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said: \"There were two horses which came hurtling past.\n\nThe horse on the right, as I was looking towards it, was jet black and had a saddle on it. The one to the left, which also had a saddle, was a really distinct white colour.\n\n\"It had a really distinct red underbelly which we later found out was blood but it was so sharp and vivid that it seemed unlike blood as it was so saturated and rich.\n\n\"It was just two bright colours hurtling down this road and it went straight past me.\n\n\"It is probably the most unusual thing I have seen in central London so far. Seeing two riderless horses bolting down an empty A road in London is certainly unique and took me very much by surprise today.\"\n\nAn eyewitness has described seeing one of the injured horses being restrained by police officers during her morning commute.\n\nMegan Maurer told BBC Radio 2: \"I saw three police officers or security guards running down the middle of Buckingham Palace Road, quite frantically, I would say.\n\n\"I looked up and I saw a horse being led in the direction coming towards me and the horse was very bloody. The poor thing looked like it was in really rough shape there was blood all over its legs and on its head.\n\n\"There looked like there was some form of injury on its head but it had been captured.\"\n\nShe added: \"It was not completely incapacitated, it was walking but it was covered in blood, it was such a confusing sight to see, it looked like it had an injury above its right eye.\"\n\nHenry Bodkin, reporting from the eastern corner of Belgrave Square, said an electricity box has been knocked over along with three hire bikes and one hire scooter.\n\nThere are lots of metallic looking scuffs on the pavement in the size and shape of horse shoes as well as plenty of horse dung.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company, Toot Bus, said the scene was \"total mayhem\".\n\n\"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said.\n\n\"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nThe runaway horses are believed to have been first spooked by the sound of nearby builders moving concrete, according to reports.\n\nThe BBC said work being carried out by builders in Belgravia caused the horses from the Household Cavalry to bolt and unseat their riders while exercising this morning.\n\nA taxi driver said he worried for his passengers when the horses narrowly avoided hitting his cab.\n\nBlack cab driver Robbie told BBC Radio London: \"I was just outside Buckingham Palace on the Mall and heard loads of galloping and looked behind and there were about three or four horses.\n\n\"Two of them were sprinting up towards Trafalgar Square and there was a white one covered in blood as well.\n\n\"I looked in the rear mirror and saw them coming right up behind me, and at the time I had two punters in the back so I was worried about them,\" he added.\n\n\"Luckily they swerved towards the middle of the road and carried on, but they were going at some speed.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service has said it received three horse-related calls.\n\nThe first was at 8.25am about a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nThe patient was taken to hospital.\n\nTwo minutes later medics were called to nearby Belgrave Square and found two people injured by horses and took them to hospital.\n\nA further call was made at 8.35am at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street and a fourth person was taken to hospital\n\nThe owner of a silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier has said one of the horses cut itself when it smashed into the car's windscreen.\n\nFaraz, who was picking up a client outside the Clermont Hotel by Victoria Station, told LBC that a white horse was injured from the impact.\n\nPhotos of the car show droplets of blood across its side door.\n\nHe told LBC: \"I was just sitting by the car with my passenger.. I didn't see the horse hit my car, I was like, smashed senseless, the people just came by my car to check 'are you ok'.\n\n\"It was just like a smash, his head hit it very hard and then [went] down. I saw about three, four horses, and I think it was the white horse which hit my car.\"\n\nOne horse was captured near Limehouse, east London, at least five miles from Hyde Park Barracks where the incident began.\n\nFour people have been injured in three separate locations across central London.\n\nOne soldier was heard 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse outside the Clermont Hotel in Victoria.\n\nAnother man was seen lying on the pavement in Fleet Street after two horses were pictured galloping down the road.\n\nCity of London Police said two of the escaped horses have been contained.\n\nThe force said officers were waiting for an Army horse box to collect the animals and take them to a vet.\n\nThe Household Cavalry is made up of the two most senior units in the British army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nThe Regiment is divided between the operational unit, equipped with armoured vehicles, and the ceremonial mounted unit, the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, garrisoned at Hyde Park Barracks in London.\n\nAll members of the Household Cavalry are taught to ride as they will rotate between the operational and ceremonial units throughout their careers.\n\nThe Mounted Regiment is often seen in public performing ceremonial duties on State and Royal occasions.\n\nDuties include the provision of a Sovereign's Escort, most commonly seen on The King's Birthday Parade (better known as 'Trooping the Colour') which takes place in June each year.\n\nThe Mounted Regiment will also take part in other occasions including state visits by visiting heads of state, royal weddings and coronations.\n\nWhilst every soldier will have been taught to ride, the uniforms worn even when exercising the horses can be heavy and restrictive making control of the horse challenging for less experienced riders.\n\nBig Bus Tours has confirmed that a horse ran into one of its parked buses. The company said none of its staff were injured.\n\nThe horse that collided with the bus was calmed by pedestrians who petted its nose and led it away from the road.\n\nTyne Marie, 19, who works for Big Bus Tours, said: \"It completely smashed the windscreen while the driver was inside.\n\n\"He was not injured but he was very shocked. Apparently they lost control of the horses in Knightsbridge.\"\n\nCsilla, an employee at a coffee shop in central London's Strand, witnessed the horses running down Fleet Street, in the direction of St Paul's Cathedral.\n\n\"I saw a white horse running, he was bleeding all over his chest,\" she said.\n\n\"A few moments later I saw another horse - a black one - running after him. And then a police car went down the road after them.\"\n\nCsilla said the horses were running near the pavement and pedestrians were forced to jump out of the way to avoid injury.\n\nA witness to the incident on Buckingham Palace Road said a horse bolted across the street into a parked car before galloping away. Bystanders screamed and ran as the animal raced towards them, witnesses claimed.\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, said: \"I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\n\"The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.\n\n\"The horses come down this route every day, but today the horse looked stressed or panicked. I saw the horse run away after it hit a bus. People were screaming and running all over.\"\n\nMr Aden, who lives in Canary Wharf, east London, added: \"The injuries looked very serious he looked really hurt.\"\n\nPictures show a soldier lying in the street receiving treatment outside the Clermont Hotel in Victoria.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the incident with a cordon erected at the scene.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was erected while ambulance workers attended to the injured serviceman.\n\nA black horse was seen close to the incident in Victoria, and a silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier had suffered severe damage to its side panel with two of its rear windows smashed.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-335477735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:50:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:50:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:27:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://okcfox.com/news/nation-world/military-horses-break-free-run-loose-across-london-2-seriously-hurt-british-army-soldiers-military-animals-buckingham-palace-treatment-veterinary-care", "title": "Military horses break free, run loose across London; 2 seriously hurt", "body": "LONDON (TND) -- Two military horses were seriously hurt after they were spooked by a construction noise and broke free in London, galloping for miles across city streets.\n\nPhotos show one of the horses with blood on its chest and legs.\n\nThe British Army said seven horses were spooked during routine exercises Wednesday morning near Buckingham Palace in Belgravia when building materials at an area construction site were dropped right next to them.\n\nFour of the horses -- Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson -- ran and knocked some riders off the horses.\n\nThe ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders,\" Lt. Col. Matt Woodward, who is the commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment of the British Army, said in a video posted on X. \"Our immediate priority was the safety and well-being of all soldiers, members of the public, and our horses.\"\n\nWoodward said three soldiers who fell from their horses were treated for non-life-threatening injuries. He said all three soldiers involved are expected to recover fully and to return to duty.\n\nWith help from authorities, as well as the public, the horses were all returned to Hyde Park Barracks and received veterinary care.\n\nTwo of the horses underwent surgery and one was transferred to an equine hospital, the British Army posted on X.\n\nThree of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" Defense Minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nCartlidge identified Vida as the white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nVida ran alongside a black horse named Trojan that could be seen sideswiping a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection.\n\nWitnesses said they saw one of the animals crash into a taxi outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows. Another slammed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nThe British Army said all remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\nOur horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course,\" the British Army noted on X. \"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nWoodward said Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment exercises about 150 horses every morning in parks and along roads to keep them in shape, as well as acclimate them to city noise \"so they are less easily panicked\" during parades and other events. He said considering \"the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare and we continue to strive to minimize the risk of this recurring.\"\n\nA day after the incident, more than 150 horses and close to 200 participants took part in the regiment's annual inspection at Hyde Park to demonstrate readiness for summer pageantry including Trooping the Color and state visits.\n\nA small crowd gathered as mounted riders, dressed in black, red and gold uniforms with golden helmets, trotted to the beat of a brass band.", "source": {"uri": "okcfox.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KOKH"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jessica_a_botelho@okcfox.com", "name": "Jessica A. One of the horses was drenched in a red substance that looked like blood, but there was no immediate information from authorities about what was on the white animal, or how the pair escaped.\n\nLondon's Metropolitan Police and the British Army confirmed the horses had been recovered not long after they escaped from their handlers.\n\nA spokesperson for the London Ambulance Services told CBS News that four people were taken to area hospitals after being injured in three separate incidents involving the horses.\n\nMedical personnel arrived within five minutes after the first incident, which involved a person being thrown from a horse near Buckingham Palace, the spokesperson said.\n\nIn a statement emailed to news outlets, a spokesperson for the British Army said \"a number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\"\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. {"uri": "2024-04-334416221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:14:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:14:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:14:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://washingtonpost.com/world/2024/04/24/london-escaped-horses-household-cavalry/", "title": "Escaped army horses careen through London, crashing into vehicles", "body": "LONDON - Five horses from the king's mounted bodyguard were startled at a construction site and galloped riderless through central London during morning rush hour before being recovered Wednesday.\n\nOne of the horses appeared to have blood on its chest and legs after colliding with a vehicle. Three soldiers and one pedestrian were injured.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a military spokeswoman told The Washington Post. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nThe horses were from the Household Cavalry, which participates in the ceremonial Changing of the Guard and major royal celebrations. These horses are selected for their temperament and are trained to remain calm while working amid chaotic crowds and unexpected noises. Throwing their riders and bolting are highly unusual.\n\nAs statements from officials and eyewitnesses rolled in Wednesday, a picture of events began to emerge.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry had been engaged in what's known as a \"watering order,\" which serves as both exercise and training for the sorts of sights and sounds they might encounter when on parade. They were just a day away from the Major General's Inspection, an annual test of the regiment's ability to carry out ceremonial duties for the year ahead.\n\nThe group was passing through London's Belgravia neighborhood when builders dropped a load of concrete. Four of the horses unseated their riders, and a fifth, riderless, also bolted. Two of the soldiers managed to remain mounted. Three injured soldiers were taken to a hospital to be assessed.\n\nThe horses galloped through some of London's most famous streets. A spokesman for the London Ambulance Service said the first calls, around 8:25 a.m., reported a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road and other people injured in nearby Belgrave Square. Another injury was called in at the junction of Fleet Street and Chancery Lane, known for their associations with the media and the legal profession.\n\nPhotos shared on social media showed horses running by Victoria Station, one of the city's busiest rail hubs, and along the Strand, a major thoroughfare in the heart of the capital. Their reins dangling, stirrups swinging, they wove their way around cars, bicycles and double-decker buses. One of the horses was spotted near Tower Bridge, and at least two made it to Limehouse - about five miles from Buckingham Palace.\n\nMembers of the public were filmed calming a black horse standing close to a bus with a cracked windshield.\n\nA Mercedes van's windows were also smashed. The owner of the van, identified only as Faraz, told LBC radio that he saw \"three or four\" horses and that a soldier fell off his horse. He said a white horse hit his vehicle and was left bleeding.\n\nAround 10:30 a.m., two hours after the incident began, the London Metropolitan Police said that all five horses had been \"contained.\" They were returned to their stables at Hyde Park Barracks.\n\nBashir Aden, a construction worker, told the Daily Telegraph that he saw a rider thrown after the horse ran into a car. He said one of his colleagues called the police.\n\n\"The man hit the floor hard. He was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car,\" Aden said.\n\nThe Household Cavalry is made up of the two most senior regiments of the British army. Soldiers are trained to drive and operate armored vehicles in combat situations, as well as to take part in the meticulously choreographed ceremonial events on horseback. They played a starring role at King Charles III's coronation and at Queen Elizabeth II's funeral.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": {"uri": "8095755240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:37:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:37:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:37:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.virginislandsdailynews.com/ap/international/rush-hour-chaos-in-london-as-5-military-horses-run-amok-after-getting-spooked-during/article_3328011d-4df5-58db-9f8e-ed6952e4b56b.html", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "LONDON -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nLBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who said a white horse had collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nTwo loose horses bolt through the streets near Aldwych in central London (Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said a white horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nHe said: \"The A4 at the Aldwych is usually pretty busy and it suddenly just fell silent.\n\n\"There was no traffic on the roads and all of a sudden we could hear some clattering of hooves just at the top of the road. Then coming down the top of the road were these two horses.\n\n\"They were coming down at quite a speed. They bolted southbound down the A4.\n\n\"Then as they came past me at some speed, they went straight down to the bottom of the road where it meets Fleet Street.\n\n\"The traffic lights were at red with a few buses and some taxis waiting there. These horses came hurtling down past the pedestrian crossing at that moment. Then the black horse collided with a black taxi.\n\n\"It was not to a great degree of power but it hit it strongly enough that we could hear it at the top of the road. You could hear the contact. Then it veered behind the taxi, went past the bus and headed eastbound on Fleet Street.\n\n\"The white horse that was with it looked like it doubled back on itself and then followed the black one as it went eastbound.\"\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company Tootbus, described the chaotic scenes near Victoria.\n\n\"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said.\n\n\"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nA second tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, said: \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control.\n\n\"I saw two horses without riders gallop away. {"uri": "8096520951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:21:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:21:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:20:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/04/25/two-military-horses-undergo-operations-after-running-loose-in-london--army/", "title": "Two military horses undergo operations after running loose in London - Army", "body": "The Army named four animals who broke loose on Wednesday: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nTwo military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday have undergone operations, the Army has said.\n\nIt comes after defence minister James Cartlidge said the animals were in a \"serious condition\" on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Quaker.\n\nIn a statement on X, formerly Twitter, the Army said one of those operated on had been taken to an equine hospital.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nThe statement said: \"Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose. Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.", "source": {"uri": added.\n\nSeven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia, near the regiment's barracks off Hyde Park, when the chaos erupted on Wednesday morning.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses, with five of the animals bolting and four getting loose, reportedly after they were spooked by concrete being moved by builders They have all been recovered.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nOne of the horses was seen covered in blood as it ran through the capital.\n\n\"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n'So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.'\n\nAn Army source told The Sun that the white horse that was drenched in blood, Vida, was 'lively' and had a history of being spooked.\n\nVida is thought to have kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nUsually Household Cavalry horses are black, however the regiment's state trumpeters always ride white or grey horses such as Vida.\n\nFour soldiers were unseated as the spooked horses bolted and three servicemen were injured and taken to hospital. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of them were life-threatening.\n\nThe horses then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A fifth horse tried to bolt but couldn't break free.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nWatch the latest News on Channel 7 or stream for free on 7plus\n\nThree soldiers thrown from their steeds were hospitalised with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to work.\n\nThe British Army said three of the horses were expected to return to duty, but the fate of the two with the worst injuries was unclear.\n\nNeither was believed to have broken bones, but a horse named Quaker was transferred to an equine hospital for specialist care, an army spokesperson said.\n\nVida, a white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial centre and the busy West End theatre district, was treated for lacerations.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying,\" the army said in a statement.\n\nThe other loose horses from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, are named Trojan and Tennyson.\n\nDuring the wild spectacle captured by stunned commuters and shared on social media, the horses had near misses with cyclists and a rider on a motorbike at a traffic light.\n\nVida ran alongside Trojan, a black horse that could be seen sideswiping a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection.\n\nOne of the animals shattered the windows of a taxi it struck outside the Clermont Hotel and another smashed a windshield when it slammed into a tour bus.\n\nTwo of the horses were corralled at Limehouse about 5 miles (8km) from where they bolted. seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing ... no serious injuries to the public as far as we are aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation,\" he told All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a British army spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nMedical authorities said four people had been taken to hospital after being injured.\n\nTelevision images showed one saddled white horse seemingly covered in blood running through the street alongside another, black one.\n\nLondon's Metropolitan Police had said initially that authorities were working to locate \"a number of horses that are currently loose in central London\", before confirming later that the animals had been all been accounted for.\n\nThe horses belong to the Household Cavalry, which acts as the British monarch's official bodyguard and takes part in ceremonial duties. {"uri": "2024-04-333933460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:08:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:08:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:53:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/uk/army-horses-run-amok-in-london-after-being-spooked-by-falling-rubble-ECVBCZCYOVKJFATEPGMCMAH6RU/", "title": "Army horses run amok in London after being spooked by falling rubble", "body": "Four Household Cavalry soldiers were thrown from their mounts before the animals bolted on Wednesday.\n\nMilitary horses caused \"total mayhem\" in central London after they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nLBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who said a white horse had collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said a white horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nHe said: \"The A4 at the Aldwych is usually pretty busy and it suddenly just fell silent.\n\n\"There was no traffic on the roads and all of a sudden we could hear some clattering of hooves just at the top of the road. Then coming down the top of the road were these two horses.\n\n\"They were coming down at quite a speed. They bolted southbound down the A4.\n\n\"Then as they came past me at some speed, they went straight down to the bottom of the road where it meets Fleet Street.\n\n\"The traffic lights were at red with a few buses and some taxis waiting there. These horses came hurtling down past the pedestrian crossing at that moment. Then the black horse collided with a black taxi.\n\n\"It was not to a great degree of power but it hit it strongly enough that we could hear it at the top of the road. You could hear the contact. Then it veered behind the taxi, went past the bus and headed eastbound on Fleet Street.\n\n\"The white horse that was with it looked like it doubled back on itself and then followed the black one as it went eastbound.\"\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company Tootbus, described the chaotic scenes near Victoria.\n\n\"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said.\n\n\"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nA second tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, said: \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control.\n\n\"I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down.\n\n\"An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.\"\n\nAn Army spokesman said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course. We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horses on the loose on the streets of central London Jordan Pettitt / PA Images Jordan Pettitt / PA Images / PA Images\n\nCartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an The dramatic scenes started near Buckingham Palace Road where a serviceman was thrown from his horse and another of the animals smashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel and shattered its windows, reports The Mirror.\n\nTaxi driver Farez was in the Mercedes at the time and said he had just dropped off a passenger when he was suddenly confronted by a horse running into his car. \"I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see,\" he told LBC.\n\nREAD MORE: Killer whale dragged trainer underwater and scalped her - before grim 45 minutes\n\nClick for more of the latest news from across the world from the Daily Star.\n\n\"When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.\"\n\nFortunately Fares was unharmed in the incident. His taxi, on the other hand, was left with large dents and shattered windows. While Farez did not see the horses, he reckons it was a white horse covered in blood that hit his car.\n\nHe said how the force of the impact led to one side of the car being raised up. He continued: \"I saw about three, four horses which I see. I think the white horse hit my car.\"\n\nA tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, was also hit by the horses in the incident. \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control,\" he said.\n\n\"I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down. An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.\"\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nCity of London Police said on X: \"At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City. Our officers have contained two horses on the highway near Limehouse. An Army horse box collected the horses and transported them to veterinary care.\"\n\nThree Household Cavalry personnel are understood to have been assessed at hospital for non-serious injuries.\n\nFor {"uri": "8097189370", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:33:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:33:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.military.com/daily-news/2024/04/25/2-military-horses-broke-free-and-ran-loose-across-london-are-serious-condition.html", "title": "2 Military Horses That Broke Free and Ran Loose Across London Are in Serious Condition", "body": "LONDON -- Two military horses that bolted and ran miles through the streets of London after being spooked by construction noise and tossing their riders were in serious condition Thursday after undergoing operations, a U.K. government official said.\n\nThe animals were among a group of four horses that broke free during routine exercises Wednesday near Buckingham Palace and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London during morning rush hour. A fifth horse tried to bolt but couldn't break free.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defense minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nThree soldiers thrown from their steeds were hospitalized with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to work.\n\nThe British Army said three of the horses were expected to return to duty, but the fate of the two with the worst injuries was unclear.\n\nNeither was believed to have broken bones, but a horse named Quaker was transferred to an equine hospital for specialist care, an army spokesperson said.\n\nVida, a white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district, was treated for lacerations.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying,\" the army said in a statement.\n\nThe other loose horses from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, are named Trojan and Tennyson.\n\nDuring the wild spectacle captured by stunned commuters and shared on social media, the horses had near misses with cyclists and a rider on a motorbike at a traffic light.\n\nVida ran alongside Trojan, a black horse that could be seen sideswiping a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection.\n\nOne of the animals shattered the windows of a taxi it struck outside the Clermont Hotel and another smashed a windshield when it slammed into a tour bus.\n\nTwo of the horses were corralled at Limehouse about 5 miles (8 kilometers) from where they bolted. All the captured horses were taken back to barracks in Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge said the army trains with about 150 horses every day, so the incident was exceptionally rare.\n\n\"Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing ... no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation,\" he told LBC.\n\nThe horses had been training for an upcoming military parade and were spooked by the crashing sound of construction materials at a work site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace, said Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nA day after the incident, more than 150 horses and close to 200 participants took part in the regiment's annual inspection at Hyde Park to demonstrate readiness for summer pageantry including Trooping the Color and state visits.\n\nA small crowd gathered as mounted riders, dressed in black, red and gold uniforms with golden helmets, trotted to the beat of a brass band.", "source": {"uri": "military.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Military"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096250143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:35:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:35:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:35:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/two-household-cavalry-horses-serious-072833412.html", "title": "Two Household Cavalry horses in 'serious condition' after bolting through central London", "body": "Two out of five Household Cavalry horses who panicked and bolted through central London are in a \"serious condition\", a minister said on Thursday.\n\nDefence Procurement Minister James Cartlidge said there were no serious injuries to members of the military and public during Wednesday's drama.\n\nThree soldiers were taken to hospital and a fourth person was injured after the horses rampaged for six miles through central London, smashing into cars, a taxi and a bus before they were finally caught and calmed in Limehouse.\n\n\"Five horses have been recovered to the Army. Three of those are fine, but unfortunately two of them are in quite a serious condition, and we'll be continuing to monitor that,\" he told LBC.\n\nThe injured horses were named as Quaker and Vida. One of them, a white horse, was seen covered in blood.\n\nAsked if they were going to pull through, Mr Cartlidge said: \"I wouldn't want to speculate on that. Unfortunately they in a serious condition.\"\n\nThe minister stressed that it was an \"exceptional\" incident, with 150 Army horses exercising in central London on average every day.\n\nThe animals were said to have been spooked by crashing building materials near Buckingham Palace.\n\nInspector Myles Hilbery, from City of London Police, described how two officers on motorbikes created a path for the horses to be steered into a horse box after they had careened across many busy roads.\n\nHe said: \"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public.\n\n\"Police Constables Lucy Hawes and Daniel McKeown risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses. They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive.\n\n\"PCs Brett Daniels and Chris Wilson took over management of traffic control on the busy arterial road enabling PCs Rob Bray and Shaun Gurney on motorbikes to create a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care.\"\n\nMr Cartlidge conceded meanwhile that \"it is a fact that there are more horses than tanks\".\n\n\"But of course, we do have hundreds of horses. Now, if you don't want that to be the case, you have two choices. You can either put down lots of those horses, or you can buy hundreds more tanks, which is extremely expensive,\" he said on Times Radio.\n\n\"Horses are a vital part of our armed forces, particularly They have all been recovered. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an {"uri": "8094686004", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:26:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:26:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:25:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/four-injured-runaway-military-horses-102313931.html", "title": "Four injured after runaway military horses on loose in central London", "body": "Four people have been taken to hospital after several runaway military horses raced through central London, some colliding with traffic.\n\nVideo on social media shows a grey and a black horse running through Aldwych with blood on its chest and legs.\n\nThe injured were treated in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street.\n\nThe Army said the \"working horses\" had been recovered and returned to camp.\n\nIt said they had escaped \"during routine exercise\".\n\nLondon Ambulance Service says four people were treated by paramedics at the three different locations, and taken to hospital.\n\nIt said all three incidents took place within 10 minutes, between 08:25 and 08:35 BST.\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp. A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nBBC staff member Tony Bonsignore witnessed the incident and told BBC Radio London he saw someone receiving treatment from paramedics.\n\n\"They were treating someone behind the blue cloth. That person has been taken away in an ambulance,\" he said.\n\nMr Bonsignore was on a bus near Victoria Station when the incident unfolded, and said: \"Everything came to a standstill. Right behind us a horse hit a tour bus, and you can see where it smashed the windscreen.\n\n\"There was blood on the floor as well.\"\n\nHe added: \"I saw a horse that was being led away, it wasn't clear whether that horse had been injured.\n\n\"A sort of taxi van is pretty badly smashed up on the side, again with some blood on the floor and evidence of where horses were behind it.\"\n\n\"You can imagine those horses will be spooked,\" he continued. \"This is an incredibly busy part of London at any time of day, but especially at half-past eight in the morning.\n\n\"It's pretty grim to be honest, you can see it on the roads where it happened. It's a pretty extraordinary thing.\"\n\nSean, a taxi driver in Blackfriars, told BBC Radio London: \"I was coming out of Victoria Station, and there's a little cabbie road that comes out into Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n\"The lights turned green for me to pull out. I could hear horses hooves very loudly and quickly coming along, so nudged out of the side road and had a look and then three horses went past me at full gallop without riders.\"\n\nHe added he \"nudged out a little bit more\" to check it was safe to pull out, and then \"another horse came round the corner with a rider on it and just missed my cab and then he disappeared off\".\n\nThe \"three horses went off towards Buckingham Palace\", before \"it sounded like a car crash, so it sounded like one had been hit\", the taxi driver added.\n\nHe said as he pulled out of Buckingham Palace Road, he could seen one of the riders \"on his back being tended to\".\n\nThere was also \"a Mercedes Vito parked outside the Grosvenor Hotel with its side smashed in, covered in blood, all the windows smashed\", he continued, and another rider on the ground at Belgrave Square.\n\nHe said he could also see \"two horses with the riders intact and a female rider from the cavalry standing there sobbing her eyes out, and a black BMW with its rear window, its boot smashed in\".\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said: \"We are aware of a number of horses that are currently loose in central London and are working with colleagues, including the Army, to locate them.\"\n\nA spokesperson for London Fire Brigade said crews had been called at 08:31 BST to \"reports of vehicles in collision with horses {"uri": "8095107868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:38:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:38:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:37:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/why-were-horses-running-loose-143245193.html", "title": "So Why Were Horses Running Loose Around London, Covered In Blood?", "body": "Several horses were seen running through central London on Wednesday morning, leaving the general public pretty mystified.\n\nUnfortunately, four people ended up being injured and taken to hospital, and the police had to try and track down the animals before they ended up causing even more harm.\n\nHere's why the horses were on the loose - and why one was covered in blood.\n\nThe five escapees came from the Household Cavalry, which is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army - the Life Guards and Blues & Royals.\n\nAccording to the Cavalry's website, these soldiers \"have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad\".\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers were out for their morning exercise in Hyde Park Barracks when the trouble began and four of the riders were thrown off their horses.\n\nFive horses ended up escaping, having been spooked by building work.\n\nMoving away from Hyde Park Barracks, the horses ran through Belgrave Square - injuring two people - then went down Lower Belgrave Street.\n\nPassers-by caught the first horse when it collided with a car on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nThe remaining four horses continued running, with one hitting a tour bus.\n\nWitnesses said one then crashed into a taxi outside Clermont Hotel and broke its windows - which is why it was covered in blood.\n\nThe blood was actually the animal's own; according to a driver who spoke to LBC, the horse had cut itself when it went careening into his car.\n\nThe owner of a silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier, Faraz, said a white horse smashed into his windscreen when he was picking up a client outside Clermont Hotel near Victoria Station.\n\nFour people were treated by ambulance workers in three separate incidents - Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street - triggered by the horses spread across just 10 minutes.\n\nAll five were caught pretty quickly, although the horses had run pretty far in that time - two of them were found in Limehouse, five miles away from the origin of the incident.\n\nWestminster Police posted on X (formerly Twitter): \"We're pleased to confirm that all of the horses have been accounted for. {"uri": "8094941659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:58:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:58:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:57:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/04/24/army-horses-run-amok-in-london-after-being-spooked-by-falling-rubble/", "title": "Army horses run amok in London after being spooked by falling rubble", "body": "Four Household Cavalry soldiers were thrown from their mounts before the animals bolted on Wednesday.\n\nMilitary horses caused \"total mayhem\" in central London after they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nLBC spoke to the driver, Faraz, who said a white horse had collided with his Mercedes people carrier, leaving blood spattered down the side.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nHe said: \"The A4 at the Aldwych is usually pretty busy and it suddenly just fell silent.\n\n\"There was no traffic on the roads and all of a sudden we could hear some clattering of hooves just at the top of the road. Then coming down the top of the road were these two horses.\n\n\"They were coming down at quite a speed. They bolted southbound down the A4.\n\n\"Then as they came past me at some speed, they went straight down to the bottom of the road where it meets Fleet Street.\n\n\"The traffic lights were at red with a few buses and some taxis waiting there. These horses came hurtling down past the pedestrian crossing at that moment. Then the black horse collided with a black taxi.\n\n\"It was not to a great degree of power but it hit it strongly enough that we could hear it at the top of the road. You could hear the contact. Then it veered behind the taxi, went past the bus and headed eastbound on Fleet Street.\n\n\"The white horse that was with it looked like it doubled back on itself and then followed the black one as it went eastbound.\"\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London Police and taken away to be assessed by Army vets.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company Tootbus, described the chaotic scenes near Victoria.\n\n\"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy,\" he said.\n\n\"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nA second tour bus worker, named only as Mr Mahmood, said: \"One of the horses bumped into a bus, then everything got out of control.\n\n\"I saw two horses without riders gallop away. One rider managed to calm his horse down.\n\n\"An ambulance went to assist another rider who had been injured.\"\n\nAn Army spokesman said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical {"uri": "2024-04-334117109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:41:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:41:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:40:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.britainnews.net/news/274305962/blood-covered-horses-run-amok-in-central-london-video", "title": "Blood-covered horses run amok in central London (VIDEO)", "body": "Several people have been injured after the Household Cavalry lost control of their animals in the center of the city\n\nSeveral military horses have been caught after going on a rampage in London; onlookers say they threw their riders and went galloping through the streets. At least four people have been hospitalized in the wake of the incident; users on social media have been sharing images of the blood-covered thoroughbreds crashing into cars and buses.\n\nThe incident occurred on Wednesday morning at 8:40am local time in the center of the British capital. Five horses belonging to the Household Cavalry were apparently spooked by noise coming from a construction site during their daily morning exercise on Horse Guards Parade, in Whitehall.\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, a total of five people were injured during the nearly two-hour-long rampage that spanned almost ten kilometers through central London. Of the four people who have been hospitalized, three are believed to be soldiers. None of the people who were hurt are reported to have sustained any life-threatening injuries.\n\nOne eyewitness recalled seeing one of the riders \"screaming in pain\" after he fell off his steed as it struck a car near the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n\"'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car,\" the witness told The Telegraph. \"The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.\"\n\nPhotos and videos shared online also show one of the horses ramming into a double-decker bus and smashing its windshield; another was seen crashing into a black taxicab. The frightened animals continued to run through the streets covered in blood after apparently being cut by the broken glass.\n\n\"They were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,\" another witness said, noting that \"It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\"\n\nIn some of the pictures, some members of the public could be seen trying to help calm down one of the shaken horses, whose legs could be seen covered in blood.\n\nBy 10:30am, Metropolitan Police reported that all of the horses had been caught and accounted for. After being transported to veterinary care via army horse boxes, all of the animals are reported to now be back at the army camp.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an army spokesperson said in a statement, adding that the horses and personnel who were injured in the incident were \"receiving the Both animals were observed wearing saddles and bridles, with one horse appearing to have bloodstains on its chest.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police of London quickly responded to the situation, putting efforts with the army to locate and capture the runaway horses. Given the potential danger posed by the animals during busy traffic, quick action was necessary for public safety.\n\nLondon is home to several army regiments, many of which maintain stables within the city. As a result, it's not surprising to see horses around key government and ceremonial locations such as Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall, and Hyde Park.\n\nThe City of London Police, responsible for patrolling the district, received reports around 8:40 am regarding the loose horses. Taking swift action, officers managed to capture the animals, who were near Limehouse on the Highway bleeding.\n\nIn addition to the police response, efforts were made to give necessary care for the horses. An Army horse box was arranged to transport the animals to veterinary facilities for any required treatment.\n\nAccording to accounts from The Daily Telegraph, the chaotic situation took place as several army horses threw their riders while being exercised. {"uri": "8097121346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:42:19", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:42:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:41:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.wowktv.com/news/u-s-world/ap-international/ap-2-military-horses-that-broke-free-and-ran-loose-across-london-are-in-serious-condition/", "title": "2 military horses that broke free and ran loose across London are in serious condition", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Two military horses that bolted and ran miles through the streets of London after being spooked by construction noise and tossing their riders were in serious condition Thursday after undergoing operations, a U.K. government official said.\n\nThe animals were among a group of four horses that broke free during routine exercises Wednesday near Buckingham Palace and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London during morning rush hour. A fifth horse tried to bolt but couldn't break free.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defense minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nThree soldiers thrown from their steeds were hospitalized with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to work.\n\nThe British Army said three of the horses were expected to return to duty, but the fate of the two with the worst injuries was unclear.\n\nNeither was believed to have broken bones, but a horse named Quaker was transferred to an equine hospital for specialist care, an army spokesperson said.\n\nVida, a white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district, was treated for lacerations.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying,\" the army said in a statement.\n\nThe other loose horses from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, are named Trojan and Tennyson.\n\nDuring the wild spectacle captured by stunned commuters and shared on social media, the horses had near misses with cyclists and a rider on a motorbike at a traffic light.\n\nVida ran alongside Trojan, a black horse that could be seen sideswiping a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection.\n\nOne of the animals shattered the windows of a taxi it struck outside the Clermont Hotel and another smashed a windshield when it slammed into a tour bus.\n\nTwo of the horses were corralled at Limehouse about 5 miles (8 kilometers) from where they bolted. All the captured horses were taken back to barracks in Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge said the army trains with about 150 horses every day, so the incident was exceptionally rare.\n\n\"Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing ... no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation,\" he told LBC.\n\nThe horses had been training for an upcoming military parade and were spooked by the crashing sound of construction materials at a work site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace, said Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nA day after the incident, more than 150 horses and close to 200 participants took part in the regiment's annual inspection at Hyde Park to demonstrate readiness for summer pageantry including Trooping the Color and state visits.\n\nA small crowd gathered as mounted riders, dressed in black, red and gold uniforms with golden helmets, trotted to the beat of a brass band.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to show that the black horse seen running with a bloody horse was named Trojan, not Quaker.", They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham {"uri": "8095364249", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:28:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:28:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:27:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.mylondon.news/news/zone-1-news/soldiers-thrown-saddles-household-cavalry-29055033", "title": "Soldiers thrown from saddles as horses 'spooked' by construction work", "body": "Soldiers were thrown from their saddles after a group of five horses were \"spooked\" by construction work in Central London this morning (Wednesday, April 24), the British Army has confirmed. The Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment have issued a statement following dramatic scenes this morning, where horses were photographed galloping down the streets of the city, with one visibly covered in blood.\n\nIn a video statement posted on X, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Lieutenant Colonel Matt Woodward said the unit exercises around 150 horses on the roads and in parks every morning, partly to help desensitise them to city noise. He said a small group of horses were spooked by construction work on a side road in Belgravia.\n\nLt Col Woodward said: \"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them. The ensuing shock caused all horses to bolt and unseated some riders.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Watch the moment armed robber points gun at shopkeeper's head before fleeing with cash drawer\n\nFour soldiers were thrown from their saddles in the ensuing chaos, and five horses became loose, the Press Association has reported. The horses then smashed into vehicles, causing several injuries.\n\nLieut Col Woodward said the four service personnel were receiving treatment in hospital. Ambulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nA management consultant from South London who saw two of the horses galloping near Aldwych said the sight was \"gruesome\" and \"like a weird dream\". The 28-year-old said: \"I got off the 172 bus which ends at Aldwych and two horses went flying past. One black, one white.\n\n\"The white one was drenched in blood from the chest down and they were galloping through the traffic at speed. People were stopping in the street shocked. The horses were running into fast-moving traffic and seemed terrified. Some unmarked police cars were chasing after them, which didn't seem to be helping.\n\n\"I felt shocked. It was pretty gruesome. Felt like a weird dream.\"\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nThe pair of horses was finally captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nAfter thanking the emergency services and the public for their help, Lt Col Woodward added: \"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare, we continue to strive to minimise the risk of this recurring. As ever we are grateful for due consideration given by the members of the public to not making loud noises around our horses.\"\n\nThe animals are all receiving care from vets at Hyde Park barracks.\n\nGot a story for us? He is military and was wearing a green uniform.\n\n\"The ambulance and police took 15 minutes to come. {"uri": "8095126583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:49:27", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:49:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:49:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.bbntimes.com/politics/chaos-ensues-as-household-cavalry-horses-bolt-through-london-s-streets", "title": "Chaos Ensues as Household Cavalry Horses Bolt Through London's Streets", "body": "The horses of the Household Cavalry, often seen in royal ceremonies in the UK, have recently caused chaos as they tore through the streets of London.\n\nThe incident occurred during a routine exercise, resulting in several injuries and damage to vehicles and property.\n\nAccording to forces.net, the horses selected for the Household Cavalry are chosen based on their height (at least 168cm) and strength, as they are required to carry a soldier and equipment for extended periods. These horses undergo rigorous training for several months to acclimate them to the bustling streets of London, including exposure to heavy traffic and loud noises such as gun salutes and military bands. Each horse is typically assigned to a specific soldier.\n\nThe commotion began when noise from a nearby building site in Belgravia startled the horses, causing them to bolt and unseat their riders. The horses, which belong to the Household Cavalry, were preparing for an inspection ahead of rehearsals for the King's birthday parade scheduled for June. As they raced through central London, they collided with traffic at various locations, with some running as far as Limehouse in east London.\n\nThe aftermath of the incident left four people hospitalized and numerous vehicles damaged. Witnesses described scenes of \"total mayhem,\" with horses racing through the streets and colliding with cars and buses. Two horses, still wearing saddles, were captured on camera galloping down Aldwych, followed closely by an unmarked police car.\n\nOne of the injured servicemen was found near Buckingham Palace Road, while another horse crashed into a taxi outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows and leaving blood stains. Emergency services rushed to the scene to attend to the injured and contain the situation.\n\nReports indicate that as many as seven horses from the Household Cavalry were involved in the incident. Some were spotted galloping past landmarks like Aldwych House in Holborn and Tower Bridge, causing pedestrians to flee in fear. Witnesses described seeing horses running with blood on their chests, indicating injuries sustained during the chaos.\n\nCity authorities and emergency services worked swiftly to contain the situation, with officers successfully capturing two runaway horses near Limehouse. The Metropolitan Police confirmed that all the horses had been \"accounted for\" and were being returned to camp. However, the incident raised concerns about the safety of both riders and pedestrians in central London.\n\nWhile the horses have since been recovered, questions remain about the circumstances leading to their escape and the welfare of those involved. The incident serves as a reminder of the unpredictability of working with animals in urban environments and the need for stringent safety measures to prevent such occurrences in the future.",
