{"uri": "8095103017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "14:35:02", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T14:35:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T14:34:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/596517-horses-rampage-through-london/", "title": "Blood-covered horses run amok in central London (VIDEO)  --  RT World News", "body": "Several military horses have been caught after going on a rampage in London; onlookers say they threw their riders and went galloping through the streets. At least four people have been hospitalized in the wake of the incident; users on social media have been sharing images of the blood-covered thoroughbreds crashing into cars and buses.\n\nThe incident occurred on Wednesday morning at 8:40am local time in the center of the British capital. Five horses belonging to the Household Cavalry were apparently spooked by noise coming from a construction site during their daily morning exercise on Horse Guards Parade, in Whitehall.\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, a total of five people were injured during the nearly two-hour-long rampage that spanned almost ten kilometers through central London. Of the four people who have been hospitalized, three are believed to be soldiers. None of the people who were hurt are reported to have sustained any life-threatening injuries.\n\nOne eyewitness recalled seeing one of the riders \"screaming in pain\" after he fell off his steed as it struck a car near the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n\"'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car,\" the witness told The Telegraph. \"The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.\"\n\nPhotos and videos shared online also show one of the horses ramming into a double-decker bus and smashing its windshield; another was seen crashing into a black taxicab. The frightened animals continued to run through the streets covered in blood after apparently being cut by the broken glass.\n\n\"They were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,\" another witness said, noting that \"It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\"\n\nIn some of the pictures, some members of the public could be seen trying to help calm down one of the shaken horses, whose legs could be seen covered in blood.\n\nBy 10:30am, Metropolitan Police reported that all of the horses had been caught and accounted for. After being transported to veterinary care via army horse boxes, all of the animals are reported to now be back at the army camp.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an army spokesperson said in a statement, adding that the horses and personnel who were injured in the incident were \"receiving the All remaining horses are being closely observed.\"\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course,\" the statement continued.\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. {"uri": "8097129502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:48:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:48:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:47:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13350561/Too-early-know-injured-military-horses-return-duty--Army.html", "title": "'Too early to know\u00b4 if injured military horses will return to duty...", "body": "It is \"too early to know\" whether two military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday will be able to return to official duties, the Army has said.\n\nThe animals underwent surgery overnight and were said to be in a \"serious condition\" by defence minister James Cartlidge on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nBoth Vida and Quaker were operated on overnight, with the latter being moved to an equine hospital in the early hours of Thursday morning for further specialist treatment, the Army said in a statement.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Trojan.\n\nTwo horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych (Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles, including a double-decker bus, and causing a number of injuries.\n\nA British Army spokesperson said: \"We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery.\n\n\"Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n\"But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and remain under close supervision.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying.\n\n\"Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n\"Quaker was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours for more specialist treatment.\n\n\"The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones.\n\n\"The blood seen on Vida (the grey horse) was consistent with lacerations.\"\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a grey drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London (Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week.\n\n\"It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\n\n\"Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we are aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London {"uri": "2024-04-335200666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:49:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:49:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:21:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-04-25/2-military-horses-that-broke-free-and-ran-loose-across-london-are-in-serious-condition", "title": "2 Military Horses That Broke Free and Ran Loose Across London Are in Serious Condition", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Two military horses that bolted and ran miles through the streets of London after being spooked by construction noise and tossing their riders were in serious condition after undergoing operations, a U.K. government official said Thursday.\n\nThe animals were among a group of four horses that broke free during routine exercises Wednesday near Buckingham Palace and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London during morning rush hour. A fifth horse that tried to bolt hadn't been able to break free.\n\nTwo of the horses underwent operations and one was transferred to an equine hospital, the British Army posted on X.\n\n\"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defense minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nThree soldiers thrown from their steeds were hospitalized with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to duty.\n\nThe loose horses from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, were named as Vida, Quaker, Trojan and Tennyson.\n\nCartlidge identified Vida as the white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nVida ran alongside a black horse named Quaker that could be seen sideswiping a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection.\n\nDuring the wild spectacle captured by stunned commuters and shared on social media, the horses had near misses with cyclists and a rider on a motorbike at a traffic light.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the animals crash into a taxi outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows. Another slammed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nTwo of the horses were corralled at Limehouse about 5 miles (8 kilometers) from where they bolted. All the captured horses were taken back to barracks in Hyde Park.\n\nCartlidge said the army trains with about 150 horses every day, so the incident was exceptionally rare.\n\n\"Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing ... no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation,\" he told LBC.\n\nThe horses had been training for an upcoming military parade and were spooked by the crashing sound of construction materials at a work site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace, said Matt Woodward, commanding officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nA day after the incident, more than 150 horses and close to 200 participants took part in the regiment's annual inspection at Hyde Park to demonstrate readiness for summer pageantry including Trooping the Color and state visits.\n\nA small crowd gathered as mounted riders, dressed in black, red and gold uniforms with golden helmets, trotted to the beat of a brass band.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. One of the animals crashed into a taxi outside of a hotel and shattered the windows, a witness told the outlet.\n\n\"I was just sitting by the car with my passenger ... {"uri": "8096359472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:50:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:50:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:46:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13348709/Two-horses-ran-loose-London-condition--minister-says.html", "title": "Two horses which ran loose in London 'in a serious condition\u00b4,...", "body": "Two of the horses who bolted and ran loose in London on Wednesday are in a \"serious condition\", a minister has said.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nTwo horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych (Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a white one drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge revealed their names were Quaker and Vida, with the Ministry of Defence confirming the black animal was Quaker, and the white one Vida.\n\nThe pair were captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nMr Cartlidge also told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a white one drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London(Jordan Pettitt/PA)\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge stressed that the situation was 'exceptional\u00b4 (UK Parliament/PA)\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the white horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he Their condition has been deemed not life threatening.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service treated patients with horse-related injuries in three different London locations: Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street. All three incidents took place within ten minutes, between 8.25am and 8.35am.\n\nVehicles were also damaged as the Household Cavalry galloped into them, with one colliding with a bus and the windows of a taxi being shattered. {"uri": "8097188106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:33:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:33:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:31:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13350535/Two-runaway-Household-Cavalry-steeds-never-serve-Black-horse-Quaker-recovering-equine-hospital-seriously-injured-blood-soaked-grey-Vida-following-London-rampage-Army-reveals.html", "title": "Two runaway Household Cavalry steeds 'may never serve again'", "body": "Army bosses have claimed it is 'too early to know' if two runaway Household Cavalry horses that rampaged through central London will ever return to active duty.\n\n'Seriously' injured Vida and Quaker were two of the five horses that were spooked as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am on Wednesday after they heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage that lasted two hours.\n\nIt emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked grey seen running down Fleet Street with Trojan, underwent surgery last night for injuries consitent with 'serious lacerations' and is now recovering in the Hyde Park Barracks.\n\nQuaker, a black stallion, was the more seriously injured of the four after it is believed he smashed into the side of a silver Mercedes Taxi, leading to a life-saving surgery at an undisclosed equine hospital last night.\n\nWhile a spokesperson for the MOD confirmed that it was Tenneyson, who collided with a bus, smashing its windscreen.\n\nAn Army spokesman told MailOnline in reference to Vida and Quaker: 'We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery. Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.'\n\nVida (white horse) and Trojan (black horse) on their rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'\n\nTennyson seen after smashing into the widow of a London bus\n\nTennyson who the horse who ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nQuaker smashed into a silver Mercedes taxi, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nHe added: 'But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and had they not been attached to the army then I don't believe they would have made it this far.\n\n'Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying. Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n'Quaker is the most seriously injured and was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours.\n\n'The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones. The injuries are consistent with serious lacerations.'\n\nTrojan and Tennyson are expected to make full reoveries and resting under the observation of Army veterinary officers.\n\nVida is believed to have a history of being spooked and even allegedly kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation, where he usually carries a trumpeter from the Household Cavalry.\n\nArmy top brass told MailOnline the horses were given the best treatment possible by military vets, which saved their lives.\n\nA spokesman told MailOnline: 'Be in no doubt, had these not been military horses then their chances of survival would have been greatly reduced.'\n\nNeither horse is understood to have suffered any broken bones and have been treated for serious cuts and blood loss.\n\nVida was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nOn Wednesday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: Horses from the Household Cavalry ran riot through London after being spooked by building work being carried out on a \u00a315million mansion owned by a former West Bromwich Albion chairman Advertisement\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nAn Army spokesperson said: 'Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n'All three soldiers involved are expected to recover fully and to return to duty.\n\n'Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n'Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\n'We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses.'\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said Vida and Quaker were 'in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive'.\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nVida (white horse) and Trojan (black horse) bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nHe told Sky News today: '[They] are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.'\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: What WAS wrong with the Household Cavalry's horses yesterday? New video shows animals spooked - with a rider thrown to the ground and injured - in SEPARATE incident to the one that saw runaway steeds careering through London Advertisement\n\nThe military horses who ran loose through London was an 'exceptional' situation, the minister added, explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day.\n\nToday, members of the Household Cavalry are set to parade at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment.\n\nMr Cartlidge told LBC: 'Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n'You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n'So this is extremely unlikely this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.'\n\nAn Army source told The Sun that the grey horse that was drenched in blood, Vida, was 'lively' and had a history of being spooked.\n\nVida is thought to have kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nUsually Household Cavalry horses are black, however the regiment's state trumpeters always ride white or grey horses such as Vida.\n\nFour soldiers were unseated as the spooked horses bolted and three servicemen were injured and taken to hospital. None are in a life-threatening condition.\n\nOnlookers yesterday said one of the Household Cavalry soldiers was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nMembers of the Household Cavalry prior to parading at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment today\n\nThe regiment will be hoping there is no repeat of the shocking scenes yesterday. Members of the regiment were in Hyde Park this morning (pictured) ahead of the inspection\n\nMajor General James Bowder during his annual inspection of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, in Hyde Park, London, today\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals are now waiting to be picked up by the Army\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, on Wednesday\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nThe horses rampaged for six miles before they were finally caught in Limehouse, east London.\n\nREAD MORE: Will runaway Household Cavalry horse ever return to active duty? Equine experts say steed with 'spooking' history may now suffer from PTSD-like symptoms from loud noise - with animals' 'prey' and 'herd' behaviour triggering their London rampage Advertisement\n\nEmergency services rushed to help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nConstruction worker Adejo Are said he saw one of the horses crash into the front of a Big Bus, which MailOnline now understands was Tennyson, as it fled down Buckingham Palace Road.\n\n'The were running down the street at a very high speed. It was very scary,' he said.\n\n'It's rare to see horses stampeding down the street like that.\n\n'I heard a big bang from further down the road as the horse ran into the bus. Two others then also hit it and fell to the ground before getting up and running off.\n\n'The first one just stood there like it was stunned and turned around and then back again.\n\n'A man from the street came over and guided it out of the road and calmed it down. I was very impressed because he wasn't in any uniform. He just knew how to deal with the horse.\n\n'The front of the bus was completely shattered from the impact.'\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place\n\nTwo of the horses were seen galloping through the streets of London covered in blood\n\nLondoners were seen avoiding one of the horses as it ran along the pavement. One horse reportedly ran into a black cab\n\nIt is unclear whose blood has covered the horses\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain.\n\n'You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz taxi was also hit by another horse, which MailOnline now understands was Quaker, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nThe Mercedes taxi driver spoke of his 'shock' after a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his car near Buckingham Palace.\n\nOne of the horses smashed into his people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents in his car.\n\nThere were also specks of blood splattered across the side.\n\nThe driver, called Farez, revealed how he was completely unaware of the horses until one slammed into his car.\n\nHe had been waiting for a passenger when the horse struck his car.\n\nHe told LBC: 'I was just sitting in the car to pick up my passenger, but on the other side there was a [horse] but I didn't see.'\n\n'When the horse hit my car then I saw, it was like a smash.'\n\nRecalling how bystanders came over to the car to check on his welfare, Farez added: 'I was ok, but it [the car] is damaged.\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nThen we stopped all the traffic and the one military guy fell down.'\n\nHe added: 'I saw about three, four horses. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - Trojan and Vida - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse, Vida, outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. 'But this was clearly very different just from the sound. And then I saw the horses charge past, one covered in blood.\n\n'I texted my friend immediately after at 8:39am.'\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nStartled taxi driver, Farez (pcit revealed he was shocked when a horse collided with his car, lifting it up into the air on one side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\nBuckingham Palace Road was closed following the startling incident (pictured: A crumpled police accident sign at the scene)\n\nPassersby were shocked to see the incident unfold\n\nThe horses were running at some pace after they became spooked while exercising\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nThe police worked with soldiers to contain the horses before moving them into an Army horsebox.\n\nThe animals were reportedly calm and stationary by the time the police reached them.\n\nREAD MORE: Taxi driver reveals his 'shock' at the moment a loose Household Cavalry horse smashed into his Mercedes near Buckingham Palace and left the car splattered in blood Advertisement\n\nHeld at the side of the road by several officers, the white horse bled all over the road and was treated by vets at the scene.\n\nFootage shows it bleeding profusely from its back leg as police gathered around to stem the flow.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army.\n\nHe said: 'The horses had stopped and the police caught up to them.\n\n'It looked like the white horse had broken its leg.\n\n'At first there were just a few police officers but then they called the army in.\n\n'After they took the horses away they were trying to clean up all the blood but they didn't have enough water.\n\n'There was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up.'\n\nMany people living in Gordon House saw the commotion as they left for the school run.\n\nJunaid Ahmed said he saw the scene from his bedroom window.\n\nHe said: 'It was so sad - I have pets myself and seeing all that blood dripping onto the street....I just hope he's alright.\n\n'I even saw some of the police officers crying as they were treating the horse.'\n\nBy this time, the horses were bloodied but calm and had stopped charging through the streets\n\nThey were kept calm by members of the police and the armed forces\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nPolice officers blocked off traffic while the two final horses were rescued\n\nSoldiers led both the black and white horses away to their waiting horseboxes on Wednesday\n\nThey white horse was taken towards the horsebox but it became apparent that the animal had injured its leg\n\nA soldier was seen bandaging its rear left leg in addition to other bandages stemming the bleeding\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today [Wednesday] to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Commanding Officer Matt Woodward said: 'Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household {"uri": "8096323597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:24:12", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:24:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:23:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.impartialreporter.com/news/national/24277333.two-horses-ran-loose-london-in-serious-condition-minister-says/", "title": "Two horses which ran loose in London 'in a serious condition', minister says", "body": "A group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a white one drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge revealed their names were Quaker and Vida, with the Ministry of Defence confirming the black animal was Quaker, and the white one Vida.\n\nThe pair were captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nMr Cartlidge also told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the white horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before "Household Cavalry soldiers hurt in horse rampage 'to recover fully'", "body": "Three soldiers injured when they were thrown from their Household Cavalry horses when the animals were spooked and rampaged through the capital are expected to recover fully and return to active duty.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours.\n\nHousehold Cavalry horses Vida and Quaker were two of five that were spooked as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am yesterday and heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor from a builder's travelator.\n\nBoth are in a 'serious condition' but have undergone operations.\n\nThis morning, the Army confirmed the soldiers were expected to be alright and would soon return to their normal duties.\n\nTwo horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise today (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nA spokesperson said: 'All three soldiers involved are expected to recover fully and to return to duty.\n\n'Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n'Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: Horses from the Household Cavalry ran riot through London after being spooked by building work being carried out on a \u00a315million mansion owned by a former West Bromwich Albion chairman Advertisement\n\n'Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\n'We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses.'\n\nIt emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked white horse, reportedly has a history of being spooked and even allegedly kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nOne of the five tried to bolt but was caught in time, but horses Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson all joined Vida in running loose.\n\nArmy top brass told MailOnline the horses were given the best treatment possible by military vets, which saved their lives.\n\nA spokesman told MailOnline: 'Be in no doubt, had these not been military horses then their chances of survival would have been greatly reduced.'\n\nVida, a grey that was seen bleeding heavily after clattering into a parked minivan outside The Clermont Hotel near Victoria station, underwent surgery last night and is new recovering under observation at the Hyde Park barracks.\n\nQuaker, meanwhile, is the more seriously injured of the two and was transferred to an undisclosed equine hospital this morning after also undergoing surgery last night.\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with was the black horse captured on mobile phone footage moments after colliding into a parked tourist bus near Buckingham Palace.\n\nNeither horse is understood to have suffered any broken bones and have been treated for serious cuts and blood loss.\n\nAn Army spokesman told MailOnline: 'We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery. Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n'But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and had they not been attached to the army then I don't believe they would have made it this far.\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: What WAS wrong with the Household Cavalry's horses yesterday? Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n'Quaker is the most seriously injured and was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours.\n\n'The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones. The injuries are consistent with serious lacerations.'\n\nYesterday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge said Vida and Quaker were 'in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive'.\n\nHe told Sky News today: '[They] are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.'\n\nThe military horses who ran loose through London was an 'exceptional' situation, the minister added, explaining more than 150 animals are on exercise in the capital each day.\n\nToday, members of the Household Cavalry are set to parade at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment.\n\nMr Cartlidge told LBC: 'Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\nMembers of the Household Cavalry prior to parading at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment today\n\nThe regiment will be hoping there is no repeat of the shocking scenes yesterday. The think the white horse hit my car.'\n\nAnother man was trampled by one of the horses as he cycled to work along Fleet Street.\n\nOnlookers say they saw two horses - one black and one white - charging down the street towards Ludgate at around 8.30am.\n\nThe man, described as in his late 30s to early 40s, was knocked off his bike by the white horse outside of the International Arbitration Centre (IAC) in Fleet Street.\n\nWhat drivers should do if they see wild horses on roads?\n\nNextbase head of road safety Bryn Brooker told MailOnline: 'Never rev your engine or toot your horn near a horse as this could cause them to bolt.\n\n'If you are passing a horse, slow down to 10mph at the absolute maximum and give them at least two metres of space.\n\n'If the road is blocked, stop your car and turn off your engine. If you see a horse that appears to be in distress, call the police and provide as much detail as you can about its location.\n\nCall the police if you hit an animal. You by law have to call the police. The RSPCA will also help with an injured animal.'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe horse continued galloping down the street after the collision, shedding a horseshoe further down the busy road.\n\nMark Camps, who works at the IAC, said he saw the cyclist lying on the street in front of the building.\n\n'He was conscious and lying flat on his back in the road, but wasn't able to speak,' he explained.\n\n'Some passersby ran over to help him and carried him to the pavement. He still had his helmet on, luckily.\n\n'The ambulance eventually came around 9am and were able to move him.'\n\nPolice were reportedly in hot pursuit of the escaped horses, flying down the street five minutes behind the horses.\n\nA shopkeeper on Fleet Street said she heard the noise of the horses first as they galloped down the road at high speed, before hearing a commotion quickly followed by sirens.\n\n'There are usually police on horses around here,' she said. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nREAD MORE: London's Cavalry chaos: Moment-by-distressing moment - how five army horses threw off their riders and rampaged for six miles across capital Advertisement\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W.\n\n'We sent resources to the scene including ambulance crews, a paramedic in a fast response car, and an incident response officer.\n\n'Our first paramedic was on the scene in five minutes.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment Commanding Officer Matt Woodward said: 'Our immediate priority was the safety and wellbeing of our soldiers, members of the public and our horses.'\n\nThe Household Cavalry - the regiment the horses were from - guards the monarch at Buckingham Palace and acts as the Sovereign's mounted escort on state occasions.\n\nIt also provides reconnaissance support to airborne forces on operations and has seen more than a few famous faces among its ranks.\n\nPopstar James Blunt served in the regiment in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were also soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals.\n\nPrince Harry was commissioned as a second lieutenant in the regiment in 2006 before being joined by Prince William later that year.\n\nJames Blunt served in the Life Guards in the 1990s after training at Sandhurst military academy and went on to see active service in Kosovo. Above: Blunt in the Life Guards\n\nYou're Beautiful singer Blunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. Above: Blunt serving in Kosovo in 1999\n\nJames Blunt live in concert at The AO Arena in Manchester earlier this month\n\nBlunt, 50, served in the Armed Forces for six years. As a Household Cavalry Life Guard, he stood sentry as the Queen Mother's body lay in state and rode as the Queen's Sovereign Escort on ceremonial escort.\n\nHe was also one of the first peacekeepers to enter Pristina, Kosovo's capital, where he encountered chilling evidence of ethnic cleansing. This experience inspired his song No Bravery.\n\nSpeaking of his time in Kosovo in 2021, he told of a tense encounter with Russian forces.\n\nHe said: 'I was the lead officer of 30,000 NATO troops.\n\n'We got to an airport where the Russians were there already. I was given instruction to overrun and overpower them.\n\n'Fortunately, a general who had been given that instruction was confronted by our own general who said, 'I'm not having my soldiers start World War III and told us to pull back'.'\n\nMeanwhile, Harry, the Duke of Sussex, rose to the rank of lieutenant in the Blues and Royals before he retrained as an Apache helicopter co-pilot in 2012 for his second tour of Afghanistan.\n\nBoth Prince Harry and Prince William were soldiers in the Household Cavalry's other regiment, the Blues and Royals. Above: Harry with William in the uniform of the Household Cavalry's Blues and Royals regiment on his wedding day in May 2018\n\nPrince Harry wearing the tropical dress of the Blues and Royals as he attends the Anzac Memorial service in Hyde Park in October 2018\n\nHe chose to wear his regimental uniform when he married Meghan Markle at Windsor's St George's Chapel in 2018.\n\nThe duke had been expected to follow his father King Charles and grandfather Prince Philip into the Welsh Guards after graduating from Sandhurst.\n\nHe was said to have opted for the Household Cavalry so he could pursue his love of horses.\n\nWilliam, who passed out of Sandhurst military academy after his younger brother, joined his brother in the Household Cavalry because of the variety of roles that the regiment undertakes.\n\nThe Palace said that William was attracted by the regiment's record in recent conflicts, including the Falklands War, the 1991 Gulf War and operations in Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Blue and Royals and the Life Guards are the oldest and most senior regiments in the Army.\n\nPrincess Diana's former lover, James Hewitt, served as a captain in the Life Guards.\n\nHarry left the Army in March 2015 and then had to give up his honorary military appointments after ending his role as a working royal.\n\nPrince William went on to serve with the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy before leaving active service in 2013.\n\nWhat is the Household Cavalry?\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is an elite cavalry unit, taking part in every major conflict since 1660.\n\nIt is made up of the two most senior regiments in the British Army: The Life Guards and The Blues & Royals.\n\nIt is divided into the Household Cavalry Regiment and the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Regiment is the operational unit, providing an armoured reconnaissance capability with the state-of-the-art AJAX armoured fighting vehicle.\n\nSoldiers are first are foremost armoured reconnaissance experts but also specialise in other battle winning capabilities, including snipers, anti-tanks, remotely piloted air systems, and information activity.\n\nThe Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment is the ceremonial face of the regiment, conducting mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSince 1660, the soldiers of Household Cavalry have acted as the monarch's trusted guardians, as well as being the public face of the British Army both at home and abroad.\n\nTheir prestige and horsemanship takes them across the UK and the rest of the world on key international events, all whilst representing the Monarch and the Nation.\n\nThe mounted regiment is based at Hyde Park barracks in Knightsbridge, London.\n\nSource: Army/Household {"uri": "8096229691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "07:26:56", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T07:26:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T07:21:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/loose-horses-make-for-rush-hour-chaos-in-london/article_0b50a970-b8c2-593d-9c60-e01fc4b9e45b.html", "title": "Loose horses make for rush-hour chaos in London", "body": "PAN PYLAS\n\nAssociated Press\n\nLONDON -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site NCHS placed on 'hold' Wednesday morning; students and staff safe Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway District 87 teachers get first look at newly purchased Oakland Avenue Building Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Coroner: Pekin woman dead after forklift accident in Goodfield Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection Illinois State basketball adds former Northern Iowa guard\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added., He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the incident erupted around 8:30 a.m.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 {"uri": "8096965681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:57:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:57:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:55:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/horses-household-cavalry-escaped-injured-rehome-b2534771.html", "title": "'We'll rehome Household Cavalry horses,' says UK's oldest equine charity", "body": "The UK's oldest equine charity has offered to rehome the runaway Household Cavalry horses should they be unable to return to military duty, The Independent can reveal.\n\nFive people were injured after seven service horses -- one of which was covered in blood -- ran riot through central London on Wednesday, smashing into cars, buses and bringing parts of the capital to a standstill.\n\n\"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" the defence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News this morning.\n\nNow The Horses Trust has volunteered to rescue the injured pair, who are thought to have been \"spooked by builders\" while having their morning exercise, with the charity adding that they have many retired military horses\" residing at their sanctuary already.\n\nJessica Tallman, Director of Fundraising and Communications, told The Independent: \"If the decision was made for them not to return to work, we would always welcome them into the care of our charity.\n\n\"The Horse Trust are experts in research and the care of service horses, and we have many retired military horses residing at our sanctuary.\"\n\nThe Independent has put this offer to the Household Cavalry directly.\n\nThe revelation comes after Redwings Horse Sanctuary explained why the situation, which required two of the horses to be operated on, may have escalated so quickly.\n\n\"The incident that spooked those horses must have been fairly dramatic for them to have taken off like that,\" Nic De Brauwere, Head of Behaviour, at the charity told The Independent.\n\n\"When horses are in flight or fight mode, they will continue to run away from what they think could be a dangerous situation until they feel calm enough to relax.\n\n\"I imagine that they probably felt disorientated when they started to calm down and they didn't have a solution as to how to find their way back home until they were caught.\n\n\"They probably would have known how to get back to the barracks and walked to that place if they were along their normal route. Horses are pretty good at recognising where they are,\n\n\"But in the heat of the moment, they quite possibly went off on a route they'd never been down before.\"\n\nWhile a petition has now been created to retire the horses to a sanctuary following the incident, De Brauwere said that it is too early to say whether or not that will be necessary.\n\nHe admitted: \"I can understand that people would think maybe the horses would want to put their feet up and retire as they may be traumatised from it, but it's really too early to tell.\n\n\"I have no doubt that they will be in the best of hands.\n\n\"If they [recover physically and] can't cope going back into a formal environment gradually, that's when I think the decision can be made [that] they need to stop working.\"\n\n\"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course,\" the British army said in a statement on Twitter (X).\n\n\"We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses. We will provide more updates soon.\"\n\nAn RSPCA spokesperson told The Independent: \"We wish all the horses and people injured in this sad and shocking episode a very speedy recovery - particularly those which have undergone surgery.\n\n\"It's heartening to see the deep levels of care and concern people have expressed for these horses and their riders.\"", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", Three of them were hospitalised with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.bucksfreepress.co.uk/news/24278263.horses-loose-london-defended-bucks-charity-boss/", "title": "Bucks Horse Trust boss responds to horse incident in London: 'nothing cruel'", "body": "A horse charity boss from Buckinghamshire has defended Household Cavalry horses after four horses were on the loose in central London yesterday (April 24).\n\nJeanette Allen, the head of The Horse Trust based in Princes Risborough, insists there's \"nothing cruel\" about their training methods following an unsettling incident where several horses threw their riders off and rampaged across six miles.\n\nIn an interview with Good Morning Britain this morning (April 25) Allen debunked the idea of mistreatment, assuring that the occurrence was nothing but a \"one-off.\"\n\nShe said: \"All the service horses that come here to retire are still really happy to work with really strong bonds with their riders.\n\n\"99.9 per cent of the time no incidents like this ever happen.\"\n\nShedding light on why such mishaps can happen, she elaborated that horses are a prey and herd animal, programmed naturally to sense danger and act on it.\n\n\"With all the training in the world, you can't predict.\n\n\"They are very big horses, with enormous amounts of adrenaline running through them at that point,\" she explained.\n\nDue to their large size, an average of 550 to 750 kg each, she mentioned that it's challenging for them to turn quickly when panicked.\n\nAs a result, she said members of the public did the right thing remaining distant as these are \"dangerous animals.\"\n\nAllen praised the police saying they \"acted appropriately\" by letting the horses slow down due to fatigue.\n\nNow, she anticipates that these horses, back at Hyde Park barracks, will receive the best care from their outstanding vet team in a calm environment.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals {"uri": "8096337803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:33:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:33:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:33:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/04/25/two-horses-which-ran-loose-in-london-in-a-serious-condition-minister-says/", "title": "Two horses which ran loose in London 'in a serious condition', minister says", "body": "James Cartlidge also revealed the black horse was named Quaker, while the white animal seen drenched in blood was named Vida.\n\nTwo of the horses who bolted and ran loose in London on Wednesday are in a \"serious condition\", a minister has said.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nTwo of the animals, a black horse and a white one drenched in blood, were seen galloping through central London.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge revealed their names were Quaker and Vida, with the Ministry of Defence confirming the black animal was Quaker, and the white one Vida.\n\nThe pair were captured on the Highway near Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nMr Cartlidge also told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario. Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering the windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the white horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before The group comprised six soldiers and seven horses.\n\nEvery military unit participating in the King's birthday parade must successfully undergo a Major General's Inspection beforehand.\n\nDuring the exercise, the horses became startled by noise from nearby construction activities. As a result, four soldiers were dislodged from their saddles, and five horses bolted through the streets.\n\nAt least two of the horses were injured after colliding with traffic.\n\nParamedics responded to incidents at three different locations across London, and four individuals were subsequently transported to the hospital, according to the ambulance service.\n\nAll five horses were located and returned to a military base. They are currently being assessed by a veterinarian.\n\nBobbie Pryor, BBC's Radio 2 travel presenter, said she contemplated throwing herself in the path of two of the runaway horses, reports The Telegraph.\n\nShe told Jeremy Vine's lunchtime radio programme: \"As I looked to the left I saw two horses coming towards me, I ran just to get across the road.\n\n\"It was coming at such a speed, I thought, I need to stop those horses, but they are huge and coming at speed.\"\n\nAsked by Jeremy Vine how she would have attempted to stop them, she replied: \"I have been around horses before, but {"uri": "8095420767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "18:12:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T18:12:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T18:12:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/london-cavalry-horses-rampage-police-army-b2534073.html", "title": "How five Household Cavalry horses wreaked havoc across six miles of central London", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nPanicked one-tonne cavalry horses threw off their army riders before smashing into a tour bus and taxis, leaving a 5-mile-long bloody trail in their wake through the city of London.\n\nPolice followed two of the five Household Cavalry Mounted regiment horses for more than five miles as tourists fled in terror to escape their path of destruction, while the other three were quickly caught.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road at 8am where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse after falling concrete spooked the animals whilst on an exercise session.\n\nThree soldiers were left injured before one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi shattering the windows.\n\nWorkers near the Clermont Hotel in central London described the \"total mayhem\" when the horses galloped through the packed street in morning rush hour.\n\nRoland, a worker for tour bus company, Toot Bus, said: \"I saw horses come from the bus station in front of Victoria run around in a frenzy.\n\n\"People were running around to avoid them - it was total mayhem.\"\n\nDarren Brookes, a site manager, who was working opposite the four-star hotel in Victoria, told The Independent: \"They ran past us towards hotel, and smashed into a van parked outside.\n\n\"The serviceman was thrown off the white horse and hit the ground with a massive bang. He was shouting in pain.\n\n\"Everyone at the bus stop outside the hotel started screaming and shouting - there was so much panic.\n\n\"People ran over to help the fallen soldier, but other people were just too scared and were running away.\n\nMr Brookes said the serviceman was on the ground for about 30 minutes before paramedics took him to the hospital.\n\n\"The black horse then ran into a tour bus and smashed the windscreen,\" he added.\n\n\"That's when I saw the blood - the horse was cut across its chest.\n\n\"I could see the blood everywhere. It was on the bus and the van.\"\n\nThe two horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych with medics called two minutes later to Belgrave Square surrounded by Grade I-listed international embassy buildings.\n\nThe bolting horses ploughed through an electricity box and destroyed multiple rental bikes left near the 19th-century garden square.\n\nOne of the damaged bikes was covered in blood which dripped onto the walkway beneath it.\n\nA witness in Belgrave Square told The Independent: \"There was horse blood all over the bikes and the pavement. I saw the white horse run past covered in blood.\n\n\"It all happened in the blink of an eye.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe pair fled in fear down the Strand, past the Tower of London storming through traffic and onto the congested Highway at Limehouse, more than five miles from where they first bolted.\n\nThe adrenaline-fuelled chase came to an end with the white horse struggling to move its badly injured leg as it bled heavily on the pavement of the dual carriageway.\n\nOne gas engineer saw the soldiers try and lead the white horse into the back of a horsebox after police finally caught up to them at 8.55am.\n\nSoldiers in camouflage were seen stroking the horses' faces and talking to them in a bid to soothe the pair and get them safely back to their base in a mobile horse box.\n\nThe engineer told The Independent: \"We heard police sirens then saw the officers stopping the traffic. We saw blood all over the horses. It was heartbreaking to see a one-tonne horse like that in so much pain.\n\n\"I used to own horses. He was holding his leg up - that is telling you it is painful in some way.\n\n\"With leg damage on the horse, it will not heal. If a tendon is broken he will be put down. Horses are very sensitive to any damage to the leg.\n\n\"I love horses. A beautiful horse like that, he needs to be run. If he just sits and eats he goes crazy. And then when he goes and gets frightened he runs even more.\n\nHe added: \"It is so upsetting. If a one-tonne horse is in London however much he is run that is only a quarter of how much exercise he should get otherwise he goes ballistic.\n\n\"I hope he is going to be alright but I don't think he will be.\"\n\nTom Cahill, 21, saw the injured horse struggling in pain as police closed The Highway to traffic an hour after they escaped.\n\nHe told The Independent: \"The army were trying to calm it down. It is nuts how it ran all the way from Buckingham Palace through the traffic lights to here.\n\n\"I have never seen something like it before. All the blood is just being cleaned up now.\"\n\nHe added: \"I don't think horses like that should be in London, it's too busy. Back in the day people would drive slowly around them but now no-one cares.\n\n\"It is just really sad. I don't think horses should be on the streets. They are so aware of what is happening.\"\n\nOne street cleaner tasked with cleaning up the large pool of blood said it was the worst thing he had seen since the Vauxhall helicopter crash in 2013 which claimed the lives of two people.\n\nHe told The Independent: \"It is the strangest job I have been called to in a long time. It's crazy you don't expect it.\n\n\"The last big accident I can remember working on like this is the Vauxhall air disaster that was the last major thing.\n\n\"Every day is different in this job. When we got here there was lots of horse manure and blood it was a horrid mess.\n\n\"Of course we hope the horse is ok. But if its leg is broken that is it for him, sadly.\"\n\nThe two street cleaners flagged down a passing fire engine who offered to hose down the large pool of blood left behind.\n\nHe added: \"We had to ask the firefighters to give us a hand otherwise we would be here until dark.\"\n\nAn Army spokesman said: \"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"", "source": {"uri":
