Two horses were located and stopped by City of London Police and Metropolitan Police officers on The Highway near Limehouse.\n\nInspector Myles Hilbery, City of London Police said:\n\n\"This was a dynamic incident and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our Roads Policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public. Police Constables Lucy Hawes and Daniel McKeown risked their own safety to provide first aid to the injured and anxious horses. They kept the horses calm while waiting for a horse box and veterinary team to arrive.\n\n\"PCs Brett Daniels and Chris Wilson took over management of traffic control on the busy arterial road enabling PCs Rob Bray and Shaun Gurney on motorbikes to create a clear path for the horses to be safely led into the horse box and escorted back to the Army barracks for urgent medical care.\"\n\n\"Our thoughts are with those people and horses injured in the incident.\"\n\nA London Ambulance Service spokesperson said:\n\n\"We responded to several calls regarding an incident with horses on the loose in central London this morning (24 April).\n\n\"We sent multiple resources to the three scenes including ambulance crews, paramedics in response cars, and an incident response officer.\n\n\"We treated four patients in total and took them all to hospital and have now been stood down.\"\n\nAll further media enquiries should be directed to the Ministry of Defence.", "source": {"uri": "8096783764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:03:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:03:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:02:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/green/2024/04/25/an-exceptional-situation-two-of-londons-escaped-horses-undergo-operations", "title": "Escaped army horses undergo operations following London rampage", "body": "Officials say that two of the horses who escaped on Wednesday, now named as Vida and Quaker, have undergone operations as result of their injuries.\n\nTwo of the military horses that bolted through London on Wednesday have undergone operations to get back to full health.\n\nFour runaway animals tore through rush hour traffic in the capital city, colliding with vehicles and causing four people to be rushed to hospital.\n\nOne of the horses, a white now named as Vida, was covered in blood, horrifying onlookers.\n\nVida and the other badly injured horse, Quaker, were said to be in a \"serious condition\" following the incident.\n\nThe four escaped horses are all members of the Household Cavalry, an army regiment which is part of the Household Division and one that acts as the King's official bodyguard.\n\nDuring a routine exercise at Hyde Park barracks in central London at 8.40am local time, five of the horses are said to have been spooked by crashing building materials near Buckingham Palace.\n\nChaos ensued, with four service personnel thrown from their horses and five of the animals bolting. Four successfully broke loose and spread out across the city.\n\nOne of the horses struck a taxi with a passenger inside, leaving an enormous dent and shattering several of the vehicle's windows.\n\nOthers smashed into a parked tourist bus and bumped into cabs and private cars.\n\nVida and Quaker were finally caught, much later, in Limehouse in east London - nearly 10 kilometres from where they set off.\n\nThe white horse, Vida, is said to have a history of being spooked and, reportedly, kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation last May.\n\nAnimal rights organisations have spoken out about the shocking incident, saying the animals have no place in military roles in modern society.\n\n\"Horses are sensitive and become spooked easily, so forcing them to partake in drills, whether ceremonial or for crowd control, can upset them deeply,\" PETA's Vice President of Programmes Elisa Allen tells Euronews Green.\n\n\"Horses don't choose to be fitted with bits and reins, subjected to loud noises, or used to carry humans on their backs,\" she adds.\n\n\"Images of blood-soaked horses running, scared, through the streets should serve as a stark reminder that animals are not military equipment and that it's high time the Ministry of Defence put its use of sentient beings out to pasture.\"\n\nThe British Army has rebutted criticism, though. \"Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course,\" it stated on X - formerly Twitter.\n\nBritish defence minister James Cartlidge told radio station LBC the affair was a shock to all involved, emphasising that it was an \"exceptional situation\".\n\n\"You are probably aware that the army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week. It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day,\" Cartlidge said. \"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\"\n\nThe minister added that, although there were no serious injuries among the public, two of the three cavalry officers who were hurt in the incident are still in hospital under observation.\n\nOne of the soldiers was discharged overnight and the others are said to be in a stable condition. All are expected to \"recover fully and return to duty\", according to the Ministry of Defence.\n\nCartlidge said he was glad there were no serious injuries, but said the ministry will be \"keeping an eye on the situation.\"", "source": {"uri": "euronews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euronews English"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quakers", "type": {"uri": "8095503734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "19:22:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T19:22:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T19:22:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/rush-hour-chaos-in-london-as-5-military-horses-run-amok-after-getting-spooked-during/article_dbff866e-ebbc-5626-88bc-67813c7328c0.html", "title": "Rush hour chaos in London as 5 military horses run amok after getting spooked during exercise", "body": "By PAN PYLAS - Associated Press\n\nLONDON (AP) -- Five military horses spooked by noise from a building site bolted during routine exercises on Wednesday near Buckingham Palace, threw off four riders and caused chaos as they galloped loose through central London streets and collided with vehicles during the busy morning rush hour.\n\nThe commotion erupted when the horses from the Household Cavalry, which were conducting an extended exercise for an upcoming military parade, presumably became alarmed by the sound of concrete falling off a moving walkway at a construction site in Belgravia, a swanky neighborhood just to the west of the palace.\n\nFive of the seven horses ran off and four soldiers were thrown off. Three of them were hospitalized with injuries. None of them were deemed to be life-threatening.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Bloomington man pleads guilty in multiple DUI cases Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection\n\nThe horses -- minus their riders -- then ran through main roads in central London, hitting vehicles and stunning commuters as they headed to work. The horses were all captured shortly after and are back at the barracks in Hyde Park undergoing medical tests.\n\nWitnesses saw one of the loose animals crashing into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel nearby, shattering windows. Another of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windshield.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media show two of the horses -- one white, one black -- running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nThe white horse's face and legs were soaked in blood. A British Army spokesperson was not able to confirm what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw the striking image of the white horse with a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor horse.\"\n\nThe horses are from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London.\n\nThe extent of the injuries the horses suffered were not immediately known.\n\nIn a video statement on X, formerly Twitter, Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, said around 150 horses are exercised every morning in parks and on the roads to keep them fit and get them used to the surroundings and the noise so they are less easily panicked during parades.\n\n\"This morning, however, a small group of horses were spooked by some construction works on a quiet side road in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them,\" he said.\n\n\"Thankfully, considering the frequency of exercise and numbers of horses involved, this type of incident is extremely rare,\" Woodward added., He thanked the emergency responders and members of the public for reacting quickly.\n\n\"This enabled swift treatment of our soldiers and helped bring our injured horses to safety,\" he added.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service said it treated four people across three separate incidents in the space of 10 minutes after the incident erupted around 8:30 a.m.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/uk/too-early-to-know-if-injured-military-horses-will-return-to-duty-army-XBFZX3NLKJND3OURXNHKYFBNUM/", "title": "'Too early to know' if injured military horses will return to duty - Army", "body": "The Army named four animals who broke loose on Wednesday: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nIt is \"too early to know\" whether two military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday will be able to return to official duties, the Army has said.\n\nThe animals underwent surgery overnight and were said to be in a \"serious condition\" by defence minister James Cartlidge on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nBoth Vida and Quaker were operated on overnight, with the latter being moved to an equine hospital in the early hours of Thursday morning for further specialist treatment, the Army said in a statement.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Trojan.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles, including a double-decker bus, and causing a number of injuries.\n\nA British Army spokesperson said: \"We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery.\n\n\"Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n\"But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and remain under close supervision.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying.\n\n\"Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n\"Quaker was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours for more specialist treatment.\n\n\"The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones.\n\n\"The blood seen on Vida (the grey horse) was consistent with lacerations.\"\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week.\n\n\"It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\n\n\"Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we are aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a spokesperson for the British Army said in a statement obtained by PEOPLE.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" they added.\n\nThe Household Cavalry is the most senior regiment in the British Army and regularly takes part in major state occasions, such as the coronation of King Charles and the funeral of Queen Elizabeth.\n\nRelated: King Charles' Guard Breaks Protocol to Allow Elderly Veteran to Pet His Horse\n\nThe London Ambulance Service told the BBC that patients with horse-related injuries had been treated on Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street all within 10 minutes of each other from when paramedics were first called.\n\nThe Ambulance Service confirmed four people had been taken to hospital after receiving treatment at the three locations, the BBC reported. Per The Telegraph, at least one soldier was hurt after one of the five horses hit cars outside the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service and the Metropolitan Police didn't immediately respond when contacted by PEOPLE.\n\nA black cab driver named Robbie recalled seeing one of the horses covered in blood. \"I was just outside Buckingham Palace on the Mall and heard loads of galloping and looked behind and there were about three or four horses,\" he told BBC Radio London.\n\nRelated: Princess Anne Shouts Out Daughter Zara's Equestrian Success as She Opens Competition in Germany\n\n\"Two of them were sprinting up towards Trafalgar Square and there was a white one covered in blood as well,\" Robbie added.\n\n\"I looked in the rear mirror and saw them coming right up behind me, and at the time I had two punters (passengers) in the back so I was worried about them,\" he continued. \"Luckily they swerved towards the middle of the road and carried on, but they were going at some speed.\"\n\nRobbie said, \"Nobody knew what was going on because there wasn't any police presence or anyone chasing the horses. We knew something had happened because they both had saddle gear on. I was worried about the horse because it looked like it was injured quite badly.\"\n\nImages also showed damage done to a Big Bus Tours vehicle. {"uri": "8096628169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:25:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:25:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:25:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/bloodied-horse-seriously-injured-but-alive-army-says", "title": "Bloodied Horse Seriously Injured But Alive, Army Says", "body": "The blood-stained horse charged through London scattering pedestrians Wednesday.\n\nThe white horse which charged through London streaked crimson by blood is in a serious condition but still alive, British military officials said Thursday.\n\nVida, technically known as a grey horse, is in an equine hospital after the dramatic incident in Central London Wednesday. Up to five horses either bolted or threw their riders after builders working on a construction site dropped a heavy load of concrete and rubble from height on an otherwise quiet street the horses were being ridden on.\n\nThe horses are all part of the Household Cavalry, a regiment closely associated with the king which provides ceremonial escorts at state occasions such as the monarch's birthday parade.\n\nVida and another horse, Quaker, were operated on after they were recaptured by the army after sowing chaos and panic as they charged through the city for over an hour.\n\nDefence minister James Cartlidge told Sky News: \"There were five horses, they have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two are unfortunately in a relatively very serious condition and, obviously, we will be monitoring their situation.\"\n\nAsked by host Kay Burley if they were still alive, he replied, \"As I understand it they are in a serious condition but still alive.\"\n\nA British army spokesperson said yesterday that three soldiers were injured after being thrown from their horses. A fourth soldier who fell was unharmed and did not need treatment.\n\nMeanwhile the spectacle of the injured and panicked animals clattering through London streets has prompted animal rights activists to criticize the army's practice of keeping horses.\n\nAnimal Rising launched a petition on the matter saying: \"These magnificent animals were so frightened that they ran through the streets of London, injuring both people and themselves. It is clear that these horses do not belong in the army, and they deserve a better life.\n\n\"We need your help to get these horses to safety. Please sign and share this petition as widely as possible so that we can get them to a sanctuary where they can live out the rest of their lives in peace.\"\n\nHowever Jeanette Allen, head of charity the Horse Trust, told Good Morning Britain: \"All the service horses that come here to retire come still really happy to work, with really strong bonds with their riders. 99.9 per cent of the time no incidents like this ever happen.\"\n\nAn Army source told the Sun that Vida, was \"lively\" and had a history of being spooked. {"uri": "2024-04-335432490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:06:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:06:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:00:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://lavocedinewyork.com/en/news/2024/04/25/2-military-horses-that-broke-free-and-ran-around-london-in-critical-condition/", "title": "2 Military Horses That Broke Free and Ran Around London in Critical Condition", "body": "They were part of a group of four stallions that escaped the Royal Guard near Buckingham Palace\n\nA group of four UK military horses had a hay day and broke loose during routine exercises near Buckingham Palace, causing a stir as they galloped across London, which unfortunately resulted in two of them getting injured.\n\nThe horses initially escaped after getting startled by construction noises, causing them to toss their riders and run miles through the streets of the city during the morning rush hour. A fifth horse also tried to break free but wasn't able to escape.\n\nOn Thursday, a UK official reported that two of the creatures were in serious condition after undergoing operations.\n\nTwo of the horses underwent operations and one was transferred to an equine hospital, according to a post by the British Army on X.\n\nThe stallions that broke loose from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, were named Vida, Quaker, Trojan, and Tennyson.\n\nThree soldiers thrown from their steeds were also hospitalized with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to their duties.\n\nAs the incident ensued, commuters captured the chaos on their phones and shared on social media, while the horses almost collided with cyclists and a rider on a motorbike at a traffic light.\n\nWitnesses reported they saw one of the horses crash into a taxi outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows. Another slammed into a tour bus, breaking the windshield.\n\nCartlidge identified Vida as the white horse seen drenched in blood as it galloped down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district. Alongside Vida was Quaker, who was seen sideswiping a taxi as they ran into oncoming traffic after galloping through a red light at an intersection.\n\nTwo of the horses were corralled at Limehouse about 5 miles from where they initially ran. All of the captured horses were taken back to barracks in Hyde Park.\n\nIn response to the incident, several animal rights organizations, including PETA, have spoken out against keeping horses in captivity, arguing the animals have no place in military roles anymore.\n\n\"Images of blood-soaked horses running, scared, through the streets should serve as a stark reminder that animals are not military equipment and that it's high time the Ministry of Defence put its use of sentient beings out to pasture,\" PETA's Vice President of Programs, Elisa Allen, reported to Euronews Green.", The Horses were all captured shortly after and are undergoing medical tests.\n\nPictures and videos shared widely across social media showed two of the Horses running at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district.\n\nOne of the Horses had its front covered by what appeared to be blood or red paint. The Army has not yet confirmed whether it was blood or what caused the injury.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told the BBC that she saw one of the horses had a head injury.\n\n\"There was a lot of blood,\" she said. \"I was a bit distressed to be honest, looking at the poor Horse.\"\n\nA taxi waiting near Buckingham Palace appeared to have a car window smashed by a spooked horse, while London.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an Army spokesperson said.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate It remains unclear whether the horses who bolted were among those filmed.\n\n8.20 to 8.25 AM\n\nFive riders lose control of their animals after leaving Hyde Park Barracks. The horses bolt into Wilton Crescent and then into Belgrave Square, leaving hoof marks in the tarmac and damaging parked hire bikes and an electricity junction box.\n\n8.25 to 9 AM\n\nFour horses are seen running down Lower Belgrave Street and into Buckingham Palace Road. One hits a parked tourist Big Bus coach and is calmed by members of the public, while another canters along Spur Road towards the front of Buckingham Palace.\n\nAnother horse hits a parked Mercedes-Benz people carrier outside the Clermont Hotel, on Buckingham Palace Road, and its rider is thrown to the ground and injured. The injured rider is tended to by London Ambulance crews, who were being helped by the fire service.\n\n8.30 AM\n\nTwo of the horses are seen cantering up The Mall towards Trafalgar Square, before being filmed running through morning traffic on the Strand. {"uri": "8097059144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:58:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:58:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:58:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/uk/too-early-to-know-if-injured-military-horses-will-return-to-duty-army/a9343766.html", "title": "'Too early to know' if injured military horses will return to duty - Army", "body": "The animals underwent surgery overnight and were said to be in a \"serious condition\" by defence minister James Cartlidge on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nBoth Vida and Quaker were operated on overnight, with the latter being moved to an equine hospital in the early hours of Thursday morning for further specialist treatment, the Army said in a statement.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Trojan.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles, including a double-decker bus, and causing a number of injuries.\n\nA British Army spokesperson said: \"We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery.\n\n\"Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n\"But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and remain under close supervision.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying.\n\n\"Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n\"Quaker was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours for more specialist treatment.\n\n\"The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones.\n\n\"The blood seen on Vida (the grey horse) was consistent with lacerations.\"\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nMr Cartlidge had earlier told Sky News: \"There were five horses. They have all been recovered. Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition.\"\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week.\n\n\"It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\n\n\"Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we are aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing the windscreen.\n\nTwo horses were then seen running in the road near Aldwych, one of which appeared to be covered in blood.\n\nJordan Pettitt, 26, who works for the PA news agency, said the grey horse was \"vividly\" stained red with blood and he heard a black horse collide with a taxi.\n\nThe animals were later seen near the Limehouse Tunnel, before they were recaptured by City of London {"uri": "8094620245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:48:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:48:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:47:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/runaway-horses-london-blood-household-cavalry-army-rcna149113", "title": "Runaway military horses race through London, with one covered in blood", "body": "LONDON -- Two British military horses -- one of them apparently covered in blood -- were seen Wednesday galloping loose and riderless through central London.\n\nThe animals broke free during regular exercises, and a number of people and horses were injured during the incident at the heart of the British capital, according to a statement from the British Army.\n\nA person was thrown from one of the horses not far from St. Paul's Cathedral and was receiving treatment from first responders, the London Ambulance Service said.\n\n\"The incident is still ongoing and we are working with our emergency services partners,\" the ambulance service said.\n\nThe animals were filmed and photographed careening past downtown landmarks and running into several vehicles during the morning rush hour.\n\nThe horses bolted around 8 a.m. (3 a.m. ET) and by 10:30 a.m. the Army said the animals had been contained and returned to camp.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" it said in a statement.\n\nLocal police said in a statement that they were \"pleased to confirm that all of the horses have been accounted for. We are continuing to liaise with the Army.\"\n\nEarlier, the city's Metropolitan Police said it was working with the Army to locate the animals. collect them.\n\nThe exact origin of the horses could not be immediately confirmed but the area they were roaming is one regularly patrolled by the Household Guards, an elite unit of the British Army that participates in royal ceremonial displays.\n\nSome users on social media reflected that the dramatic scenes resembled a portent for some apocalyptic event, though it was unclear whether their {"uri": "8095760254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:44:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:44:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:44:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/uk/its-wild-wild-west-horses-run-loose-through-london-in-surreal-spectacle/articleshow/109576529.cms", "title": "It's wild, wild west: Horses run loose through London in surreal spectacle - Times of India", "body": "Galloping past some of London's most famous sites, the horses left a trail of damaged vehicles and shocked pedestriansFive runaway military horses galloped through the streets of London on Wednesday, alarming pedestrians, sideswiping cars and buses, and turning an ordinary rush hour into a frightening, almost surreal spectacle. Four people were treated for injuries, including a soldier who was thrown from one of the horses, according to the London ambulance service.The horses, which belong to the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, a unit that parades in royal pageants, are normally well-trained symbols of London's regal past.\n\nOn Wednesday, however, they broke into a panicked stampede that had more in common with the Wild West. Galloping past some of London's most famous sites - from Buckingham Palace to Tower Bridge - they left a trail of damaged vehicles and shocked pedestrians, some of whom had to dart out of their way.\n\nBy 10.30am, the Metropolitan Police said all the horses had been recovered and were back in their barracks in Hyde Park. But some had suffered injuries, including a white horse that had blood splashed on its neck, chest and forelimbs. The drama began shortly after 8am when the horses, apparently spooked by the noise from a nearby construction site, threw off the military riders who were taking them out for routine exercises. Photos showed one of the soldiers being treated while lying on the ground on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nVideo footage captured a pair of riderless horses galloping in Aldwych, a stately area in central London. Their hooves clattered in the shadow of grand stone buildings as passers-by scattered, buses jerked to a stop and cars honked. The white horse, wearing a saddle and stirrups with its reins flying behind it, was caught on video later galloping in the vicinity of Tower Bridge. Other pictures showed the result of unexpected encounters between animals and a busy urban landscape: a double-decker tour bus with a smashed windshield and a gray Mercedes van with a dented door and smashed rear windows.\n\nAs the incident unfolded, the media began carrying live coverage, briefly riveting much of the city. Shortly before 10am, the London police reported that its officers had corralled two of the horses near Limehouse, a neighbourhood adjacent to the city's docklands. That indicated they had made their way across Central London, from Westminster through Covent Garden and past the financial district.\n\nMegan Morra, who was on her way to work, told BBC that she saw one of the horses had a head injury. \"There was a lot of blood. I was a bit distressed looking at the poor horse.\" The horses are trained to be comfortable in busy streets and around people, which made the episode extraordinarily unusual.", "source": {"uri": They were racing down Eastwards. At first, it was difficult to see if someone was riding them.\n\n\"It was only when they approached me that I saw that they were alone. The white horse has blood all over and they both looked spooked.\"\n\nAnother witness who saw the animals told the Standard they saw the animals \"running past cars and an unmarked range rover following them\" near Tower Bridge.\n\nIt is understood one of the horses hit a taxi and a bus.\n\nA Met Police spokesperson told the Standard: \"We are aware of a number of horses that are currently {"uri": "8095764020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:49:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:49:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:49:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.sunjournal.com/2024/04/24/loose-military-horses-stampede-through-central-london/", "title": "Loose military horses stampede through central London", "body": "Two horses on the loose bolt through the streets of London near Aldwych, on Wednesday April 24, 2024. Jordan Pettitt/Associated Press\n\nFive military horses, including one that appeared to be covered in blood, stomped through central London Wednesday, where they ran into a double-decker bus, a taxi and other vehicles, according to the BBC.\n\nThe spooked animals reportedly got loose when building materials were dropped next to them during a rehearsal for The King's Birthday Parade in June. Four soldiers from the Household Cavalry, which patrols the grounds outside Buckingham Palace, were thrown from their saddles.\n\nThe BBC said three military members and a civilian riding a bicycle were hospitalized as a result of the chaos. Officials said the troops' injuries were deemed non-life-threatening.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" an official told the BBC. \"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said paramedics treated human victims around 8:30 a.m. on Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the area between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street.\n\nThe horses were reportedly rounded up, including a pair that traveled more than 5 miles from where the incident began. They were treated by a veterinarian.\n\nThe unit involved in the incident was composed of seven horses and six soldiers, according to the BBC. They were slated to participate in a mandatory Thursday inspection in Hyde Park ahead of The King's Birthday Parade. That annual event, also known as Trooping the Colour, involves 1,400 military members and 200 horses.\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" {"uri": "8097103241", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:28:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:28:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:28:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/blood-soaked-horse-serious-condition-075901260.html", "title": "Blood-soaked horse Vida may never serve again after London rampage injuries", "body": "Two ceremonial Army horses seriously injured after bolting through central London on Wednesday may never be able to perform their duties again.\n\nVida, a grey pictured covered in blood as it charged through the streets, has undergone surgery and is resting under observation in Hyde Park Barracks.\n\nAnother horse with worse injuries, named Quaker, was transferred to an equine hospital after undergoing surgery.\n\nBoth Quaker and Vida are being closely monitored, and doubts remain as to whether they will recover enough to resume active duties.\n\nThe other two Household Cavalry horses that bolted, named Trojan and Tennyson, are resting under the observation of Army veterinary officers, but are expected to make full recoveries and resume their duties shortly.\n\nTrojan was the horse seen running with Vida through Aldwych, along Fleet Street and past St Paul's before the pair were finally stopped at Limehouse, east London.\n\nArmy vets are still trying to establish whether Quaker was the horse seen crashing into a tour bus on Buckingham Palace Road or whether Trojan recovered enough from the impact to be able to race on for several more miles.\n\n\"I'm afraid we simply don't know at this stage who was the one who hit the bus,\" said an Army source. \"It was quite a confusing and fast-moving sequence of events to piece together.\"\n\nSpeaking about Vida and Quaker, an Army spokesman said: \"We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery. Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n\"But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and remain under close supervision.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured, and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying. Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n\"Quaker was also operated on overnight, but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours for more specialist treatment. The extent of the injuries is not completely clear, but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones. The blood seen on Vida was consistent with lacerations.\"\n\nAn Army source told The Sun that Vida was \"lively\" and had a history of being spooked. The horse is thought to have kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nThe spooking of the four horses coincided with a separate incident on Wednesday when another horse from the Household Cavalry was filmed rearing and throwing off a trooper during exercises on Horse Guards Parade\n\nA man filming is heard saying shortly before the incident: \"The horses are having a bit of a dance show this morning, they're not settling down as quick as they usually do.\"\n\nSeconds later, there is commotion among the crowd as a black horse appears unsettled and moves in a frantic manner. Several of the horses are seen tugging against their harnesses as the first horse bucks and throws the rider off.\n\nThe man filming then says: \"Oh a trooper has been thrown. What is going on with the horses today?\"\n\nAs a medic tended the fallen rider, his colleagues tried to calm their own steeds. Moments later, the crowd applauded as the fallen rider managed to get to his feet.\n\nIn the rush-hour incident, four pedestrians were injured after the horses careered through the streets, smashing into vehicles including a Mercedes-Benz people carrier.\n\nThe horses had initially been spooked by the noise of concrete being shifted by builders at a property in Belgravia.\n\nLt Col Matt Woodward, Commanding Officer, Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, later said: \"A small group of horses were spooked by construction work in a quiet side street in Belgravia where building materials were dropped from height right next to them.\"\n\nAfter bolting into Wilton Crescent, the horses ran to Belgrave Square, leaving hoof marks in the tarmac and damaging parked hire bikes and an electricity junction box.\n\nIn total, ambulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street in the space of 10 minutes.\n\nBy 10.30am, all horses had been recovered and returned to Hyde Park Barracks.\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nInspector Myles Hilbery, of City of London Police, said: \"This was a dynamic incident, and the courageous actions taken by police officers from our roads policing team prevented further harm and distress to the horses and members of the public.\"", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8094825040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:48:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:48:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:48:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://people.com/household-cavalry-horses-injure-four-loose-london-8637991", "title": "At Least 4 Injured After Runaway Horses from Household Cavalry Gallop Through Streets of Central London", "body": "Becca Longmire is a digital news writer-reporter at PEOPLE. She has been working at PEOPLE since 2024. Her work has previously appeared on ET Canada, Metro and the Mail Online.\n\nFour people have been injured after multiple horses belonging to the Household Cavalry got loose during a \"routine exercise\" on the morning of April 24.\n\nThe animals, stabled in Hyde Park Barracks, Knightsbridge, have now been returned and are being treated following the incident that occurred at approximately 8:25 a.m. local time, per the BBC.\n\n\"A number of military working horses became loose during routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a spokesperson for the British Army said in a statement obtained by PEOPLE.\n\n\"A number of personnel and horses have been injured and are receiving the appropriate medical attention,\" they added.\n\nThe Household Cavalry is the most senior regiment in the British Army and regularly takes part in major state occasions, such as the coronation of King Charles and the funeral of Queen Elizabeth.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service told the BBC that patients with horse-related injuries had been treated on Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and the junction between Chancery Lane and Fleet Street all within 10 minutes of each other from when paramedics were first called.\n\nThe Ambulance Service confirmed four people had been taken to hospital after receiving treatment at the three locations, the BBC reported. Per The Telegraph, at least one soldier was hurt after one of the five horses hit cars outside the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road.\n\nThe London Ambulance Service and the Metropolitan Police didn't immediately respond when contacted by PEOPLE.\n\nA black cab driver named Robbie recalled seeing one of the horses covered in blood. \"I was just outside Buckingham Palace on the Mall and heard loads of galloping and looked behind and there were about three or four horses,\" he told BBC Radio London.\n\n\"Two of them were sprinting up towards Trafalgar Square and there was a white one covered in blood as well,\" Robbie added.\n\n\"I looked in the rear mirror and saw them coming right up behind me, and at the time I had two punters (passengers) in the back so I was worried about them,\" he continued. \"Luckily they swerved towards the middle of the road and carried on, but they were going at some speed.\"\n\nRobbie said, \"Nobody knew what was going on because there wasn't any police presence or anyone chasing the horses. We knew something had happened because they both had saddle gear on. I was worried about the horse because it looked like it was injured quite badly.\"\n\nImages also showed damage done to a Big Bus Tours vehicle. The company didn't immediately respond when approached by PEOPLE.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"We confirm that one of our stationary buses sustained damage this morning during an incident involving horses from the Household Cavalry. One of the horses ran into the front of our parked vehicle,\" the company said in a statement, per The Telegraph.\n\n\"Fortunately, none of our team members were injured. Our primary concern lies with the welfare of the riders and animals involved in the incident,\" it added. \"We are currently coordinating closely with Emergency Services to assist in any way possible. At this stage, we have no further comments to provide.\"", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8095227038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:54:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:54:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:54:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.falmouthpacket.co.uk/news/24276568.household-cavalry-horses-careering-streets-london/", "title": "Horses running through London streets brings back memories of Household Cavalry", "body": "The horses caused \"total mayhem\" in central London this morning after they were spooked by builders moving rubble.\n\nA group of seven horses and six soldiers from the Household Cavalry were on an extended exercise in Belgravia on Wednesday when chaos erupted.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles and causing a number of injuries.\n\nIt is believed the animals were spooked when some concrete being moved by builders hit the ground.\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were assessed in hospital for their injuries, which were not thought to be serious.\n\nBelieve it or not troopers falling off their horses was not an uncommon thing to happen, sometimes in full regalia, and I'm sure it's not now.\n\nThe horses are exercised every morning through the streets of London with one trooper riding whilst leading another horse.\n\nIt was actually my favourite thing riding through Chelsea and Knightsbridge in the early hours of the morning before coming back to Hyde Park Barracks for a slap-up breakfast.\n\nOfficers would often take their own horses into Hyde Park to exercise them and sometimes we'd join them.\n\nWhile it is true that the horses are trained to not react to crowds and loud noises they are very strong and wilful animals and, if they decide to go, then they go. And did I mention they're pretty big? There's nothing more terrifying than clinging on for dear life to a bolting cavalry horse.\n\nThe sight of the white horse, probably an officers or bandsman, covered in blood was pretty upsetting though, for one simple reason.\n\nMy horse, ridden by Trooper Smith as I was recovering from appendicitis, was killed in the Hyde Park bombing in 1982 along with seven others and four of my colleagues, including my troop leader, some of whom I had chatted to just hours earlier.\n\nSeeing the damage the nail bombs did to their cuirasses, boots helmets made you realise how badly the poor horses must have suffered.\n\nA less horrific bolting, but no less frightening one, came during Charles and Diana's wedding.\n\nA friend of mine, who later turned out to be an adept conman stealing ceremonial kit and selling it to unscrupulous antique dealers, but that's another story, was unseated by his horse and preceded to bolt all along the parade. You can probably still see it on Youtube!\n\nI hope the guys who fell are alright though and, of course, that the horses make a full recovery, the bleeding is often worse than it looks!", "source": A fifth horse that tried to bolt had not been able to break free. Two of the horses required operations and one was transferred to an equine hospital, the British Army said on X, the social media platform. \"Three of them are fine, two of them are unfortunately in a relatively serious condition and obviously we will be monitoring that condition,\" defense minister James Cartlidge told Sky News. \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\" Three of soldiers thrown from their steeds were hospitalized with injuries, but were expected to fully recover and return to duty.\n\nThe loose horses from the Household Cavalry, the ceremonial guard of the monarch and a feature of state functions in London, were named as Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson. Cartlidge identified Vida as the white horse seen drenched in blood as it ran at speed down Aldwych, in between London's historic financial center and the busy West End theater district more than 5 miles (8 kilometers) from where it bolted. Vida ran alongside a black horse named Quaker that could be seen bumping into a taxi as it turned into oncoming traffic after running through a red light at an intersection. The horses were all captured shortly after and were taken back to barracks in Hyde Park. Cartlidge said the army trains with about 150 horses every day, so the incident was exceptionally rare. \"Unfortunately we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing ... no serious injuries to the public as far as we aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation,\" he told LBC.\n\nAMS\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is The British Army told USA TODAY three of its soldiers were among those requiring treatment at a hospital. The ambulance service did not immediately respond Wednesday morning to USA TODAY's request for comment.\n\nHorses were from Household Cavalry\n\nThe horses were from the Life Guards, the most senior regiment of the British Army and part of the Household Cavalry. The ceremonial face of the regiment, members of the prestigious Household Cavalry are tasked with mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSix soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were conducting exercises Wednesday morning when the animals were spooked by falling concrete from a nearby construction site in the Belgravia district, the British Army said.\n\nFive of the horses took off, while four of the soldiers were bucked from their mounts. Photos and videos shared online, showed a white horse covered in what appeared to be blood running alongside a black horses through the streets and sidewalks.\n\n\"All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a British Army spokesperson said in a statement.\n\nThree soldiers who were injured were treated at a hospital and will survive, the agency said.", "source": {"uri": It remains unclear whether the horses who bolted were among those filmed.\n\n8.20 to 8.25 AM\n\nFive riders lose control of their animals after leaving Hyde Park Barracks. The horses bolt into Wilton Crescent and then into Belgrave Square, leaving hoof marks in the tarmac and damaging parked hire bikes and an electricity junction box.\n\n8.25 to 9 AM\n\nFour horses are seen running down Lower Belgrave Street and into Buckingham Palace Road. One hits a parked tourist Big Bus coach and is calmed by members of the public, while another canters along Spur Road towards the front of Buckingham Palace.\n\nAnother horse hits a parked Mercedes-Benz people carrier outside the Clermont Hotel, on Buckingham Palace Road, and its rider is thrown to the ground and injured. The injured rider is tended to by London Ambulance crews, who were being helped by the fire service.\n\n8.30 AM\n\nTwo of the horses are seen cantering up The Mall towards Trafalgar Square, before being filmed running through morning traffic on the Strand. One appears to be covered in blood.\n\n8.35AM\n\nPolice are called to reports of an incident at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, after which the same two horses are seen running down Fleet Street, in the direction of St Paul's Cathedral. They are spotted moments later in Cannon Street heading east.\n\n8.39 AM\n\nThe two horses are captured on camera by a motorist in Shadwell, east London.\n\n8.45AM\n\nThe animals are seen running along the Limehouse Link near Tower Bridge, where they are stopped and contained by City of London Police.\n\n10.40\n\nAn Army spokesman says all the horses have been recovered and returned to camp.", {"uri": "2024-04-334248667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:44:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:44:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:44:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.sott.net/article/490873-Royal-Household-Calvary-horses-bolt-through-London-after-throwing-off-riders-off-just-as-Big-Ben-clock-stops-working", "title": "Royal Household Calvary horses bolt through London after throwing off riders off, just as Big Ben clock 'stops working'", "body": "\"A number of military working horses became loose during a routine exercise this morning. All of the horses have now been recovered and returned to camp,\" a British army spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n[...]\n\nThe horses belong to the Household Cavalry, which acts as the British monarch's official bodyguard and takes part in ceremonial duties. They are garrisoned at Hyde Park barracks, less than a mile away from Buckingham Palace.\n\nA number of prestigious army regiments have stables in the British capital and horses are a regular sight around government buildings on Whitehall, Buckingham Palace, The Mall and in nearby Hyde Park. The\n\nFive people, including a soldier who was riding on of the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours.\n\nFour people were hospitalised. It is understood that three of them are soldiers who have not sustained life-threatening injuries.\n\nThe Household Cavalry soldier was left 'screaming in pain' after he was thrown from his horse when it struck a car by the Clermont Hotel on Buckingham Palace Road, Victoria.\n\nCommuters said they heard the soldier screaming in pain after they saw him fall from his horse when the animal ran into a car.\n\nThe horses were spooked during their daily morning exercise on Horse Guards Parade, in Whitehall, at around 8.40am.\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen, while another reportedly crashed into a black cab.\n\nEmergency services rushed to the help the injured soldier, who was seen being treated on the road.\n\nBashir Aden, 48, a construction worker, told The Telegraph: 'I saw a soldier falling down into the street after the horse ran into a car. One of my colleagues called the police.\n\n'The man hit the floor hard, he was screaming in pain. You could see blood all over the parked car.'\n\nA silver Mercedes-Benz people carrier was also hit by another horse, with damage to its side and two rear windows broken.Buckingham Palace Road was closed after the shocking incident and a cordon was put in place.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent has been put up around the injured soldier.\n\nThe horses ran through the streets of Victoria and got as far east as Aldwych before they were calmed and contained by police on the Highway near Limehouse.\n\nOfficers are now waiting for Army horseboxes to take the animals away.\n\nA woman who saw the horse crash into the Mercedes told LBC: 'One of the horses hit the Mercedes van and the rider was on it, fell back on this little middle bit of the road and the other woman lost control of her horse and she managed to grab the railings.\n\n'The horses were injured obviously from the glasses that they had broken. [The injured soldier] was laying there on the ground. He looked like he hurt himself pretty bad. It was terrible.'\n\nThe horses were all caught and accounted for by 10.30am, the Met Police said.\n\nThe Met Police said: 'We are aware of a number of horses that are currently loose in central London and are working with colleagues, including the Army, to locate them.'\n\nThe City of London Police said: 'At around 8.40am, we were called about horses that had became loose and were travelling through the City.\n\n'Our officers have contained two horses on the Highway near Limehouse. We're waiting for an Army horse box to collect the horses and transport them to veterinary care.'\n\nLondon Ambulance Service said: 'We were called at 8.25am today to reports of a person being thrown from a horse on Buckingham Palace Road, SW1W. Oddly, the horse incident occurred today at 8:25am, and 35 minutes\n\nTeams drafted in to fix Big Ben clock after it stops working - The Standard, 24 April 2024\n\nEngineers were drafted in to fix Westminster's famous Big Ben clock after it stopped on Wednesday morning.\n\nAn incorrect number of bongs also sounded at the wrong time when the Elizabeth Tower clock appeared to stop for about an hour at 9am.\n\nBig Ben's iconic bongs rang out at 10:06am instead of on the hour.\n\nOne interesting detail\n\n'The Big Ben clock stopped on Wednesday morning with the hands stuck at 9am and the wrong number of bongs sounded.\n\nThe Elizabeth Tower clock appeared to stop for about an hour, before showing the correct time again at 10:15am. Big Ben's bongs also sounded 11am at 10:06am despite the hands of at least two of the clock faces showing 9am.' Here's footage of Big Ben malfunctioning:\n\n\"We are aware that the clock dials on the Elizabeth Tower were temporarily displaying the incorrect time this morning [Wednesday April 24].\n\n\"Teams worked quickly to rectify the issue and carried out servicing to the mechanism, which has now completed.\n\n\"The clock dials of the Elizabeth Tower are currently functioning as normal and no risks to the integrity of the mechanism have been identified.\"\n\nFollowing the historic refurbishment of the Great Clock, rigorous and regular servicing takes place in line with horological industry standards, to ensure the clock can continue to function correctly.\" The\n\nThe clock was showing the correct time again at 10:15am.\n\nOccasional stoppages are part of the \"bedding in\" process for the clock, as the mechanism wears in.\n\nThe hourly strikes of the bells are expected to resume at midday on Wednesday after the system is reset.\n\nBig Ben was silenced between August 2017 and November 2022 during restoration work to the Elizabeth Tower, estimated to have cost around \u00a380million.\n\nThe clock stopped working twice in one week last July, a year after the completion. The\n\n'Big Ben's timekeeping is strictly regulated by a stack of coins placed on the huge pendulum.\n\nBefore 2009, timekeepers kept 10 old pennies beside the mechanism, using the coins to keep the clock accurate. It now also uses special \u00a35 coins created especially for the 2012 Olympics.\n\nAdding or taking away coins affects the pendulum's centre of mass and the rate at which it swings, Mike McCann, the clock's keeper told Reuters news service at the time.\n\nThe clock has rarely stopped - even after a bomb destroyed the Commons chamber during the Second World War, the clock tower survived and Big Ben continued to strike the hours.'\n\nThe Great Bell, commonly called Big Ben, weighs 13.7 tonnes and strikes every hour, to the note of E natural.\n\nIt is accompanied by four quarter bells that chime every 15 minutes. {"uri": "8096736362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:33:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:33:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:33:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13349159/Household-Cavalry-horse-return-active-duty-Equine-experts-PTSD-like-symptoms-prey-herd-behaviour-triggering-London-rampage.html", "title": "Will runaway Household Cavalry horse ever return to active duty?", "body": "Equine experts have cast doubt on whether the Household Cavalry horse that bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through London yesterday will ever return to active duty.\n\nHousehold Cavalry horses Vida and Quaker were two of five that were spooked as they passed through Wilton Crescent in Belgravia at 8.40am yesterday and heard a loud noise from concrete dropping on the floor from a builder's travelator.\n\nFive people, including three soldiers riding the horses, were injured in three separate incidents during the six-mile rampage on Wednesday that lasted two hours. The soldiers are all set to make a full recovery.\n\nIt emerged that Vida, the blood-soaked white horse, reportedly has a history of being spooked and even allegedly kicked a soldier in the head during the King's Coronation.\n\nAlthough one of the five that tried to bolt was caught in time, horses Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson all joined Vida in running loose.\n\nDr Claire Corridan is a veterinary surgeon with a doctorate in animal behaviour and welfare.\n\nShe told MailOnline that Vida may have been suffering from PTSD-like behaviour because of a past trauma and tragically those symptoms would likely now worsen.\n\nOther experts said horses were 'prey' animals that had a natural instinct to escape threats and that 'herd' mentality meant the other horses had followed in panic.\n\nTwo horses that ran rampage through London after being 'spooked by builders moving rubble' are in a 'serious condition'\n\nThis blood-soaked Household Cavalry horse was one of five that bolted during a morning exercise on Wednesday (pictured between Tower Bridge and the Limehouse tunnel after a six-mile rampage)\n\nThe horse was seen galloping through the streets of London in terrifying scenes on Wednesday morning\n\nThe last two horses were finally caught near a patch of grass outside the Glamis Estate in Limehouse\n\nDr Claire Corridan (pictured) is a veterinary surgeon with a doctorate in animal behaviour and welfare. She told MailOnline that Vida may have been suffering from PTSD-like behaviour because of a past trauma and tragically those symptoms would likely now worsen\n\nThe horses bolted and went on a six-mile rampage through central London on Wednesday\n\nDr Corridan told MailOnline: 'That particular horse may have been injured previously.\n\n'Then anything that triggers that memory would override [their training].\n\n'[It's] PTSD-like behaviour. If that horse has been in an incident, that sound triggered a memory in its head.\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: Horses from the Household Cavalry ran riot through London after being spooked by building work being carried out on a \u00a315million mansion owned by a former West Bromwich Albion chairman Advertisement\n\n'All that horse was thinking was about finding somewhere safe to be.\n\n'All they are thinking about is getting away. They will injure themselves in a blind panic - they are frantic.\n\n'When there is a history, I would think that animal wouldn't be suitable for working.\n\n'There's a million things that could cause a loud bang. Once they have reacted once, they are more likely to do that again.\n\n'With a period of time with a trainer they might be able to be desensitized but it depends what the incident was in terms of the emotional damage in the horse's head.\n\n'There's training programs and in extreme cases, if there's ongoing anxiety there's medical management.\n\n'Everything is a potential trigger - smells, sounds, sights, people. That horse needs to be taken out of that scenario. They can be rehabilitated.\n\n'The scenario will have done its own damage. They need to be treated with kindness and empathy and be given time to recover.\n\n'It may be that that particular role in that built-up area - they may not be suitable for that.'\n\nIs is believed that the five horses were spooked when some cement was dropped by the travelator onto the ground\n\nRubble being moved from a building on Wilton Crescent Wilton Crescent, a street in the Belgravia area, where builders using a travelator with concrete are believed to have spooked the horses\n\nIt is understood that three soldiers were injured after the horses spooked and smashed into cars and a bus\n\nMembers of the Household Cavalry prior to parading at the Major General's annual inspection of the Mounted Regiment today\n\nThe regiment will be hoping there is no repeat of the shocking scenes yesterday. Members of the regiment were in Hyde Park this morning (pictured) ahead of the inspection\n\nMajor General James Bowder during his annual inspection of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, in Hyde Park, London, today\n\nConcrete rubble allegedly fell from the conveyor belt onto the floor\n\nIt is believed this is what spooked the five horses and sparked their six-mile rampage through London\n\nVida, a grey that was seen bleeding heavily after clattering into a parked minivan outside The Clermont Hotel near Victoria station, underwent surgery last night and is new recovering under observation at the Hyde Park barracks.\n\nRED MORE: Social media users claim rampaging London horses are an 'omen' as frightening incident sparks viral memes (and conspiracy theories!) Advertisement\n\nQuaker, meanwhile, is the more seriously injured of the two and was transferred to an undisclosed equine hospital this morning after also undergoing surgery last night.\n\nIt is not yet known for sure if Quaker was the black horse captured on mobile phone footage moments after colliding into a parked tourist bus near Buckingham Palace.\n\nNeither horse is understood to have suffered any broken bones and have been treated for serious cuts and blood loss.\n\nYesterday morning, six soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were on an extended Watering Order, an exercise to keep up the fitness of animals not involved in the public-facing King's Life Guard duties.\n\nThey are thought to have been spooked by the noise and five bolted, with two remaining in place.\n\nDr Corridan told MailOnline that Vida's PTSD-like symptoms may return due to 'trigger stacking', where triggers of one trauma that was sparked by a different incident are linked to the trigger of that original memory of pain or injury.\n\nMailOnline discovered one of the animal's horseshoes that was thrown off when they were on Fleet Street\n\nThe horses were pursued by a police car before they were finally caught by officers on the Highway near Limehouse\n\nThe distressed animals were seen covered in blood in east London on Wednesday\n\nOther horses were caught in Wapping (pictured), in east London, on Wednesday\n\nOne of the horses has also seemingly ran into a double-decker bus, smashing its windscreen\n\nBlood smeared on the road at the scene where a horse collided with a bus\n\nShe said: 'If one thing triggered the horse, the next time, anything they associate with that trigger becomes a trigger - a saddle, or uniforms.\n\nEXCLUSIVEREAD MORE: What WAS wrong with the Household Cavalry's horses yesterday? New video shows animals spooked - with a rider thrown to the ground and injured - in SEPARATE incident to the one that saw runaway steeds careering through London Advertisement\n\n'The number of triggers increases... to the point where you can't predict what will be a trigger.'\n\nShe said humans do the same thing. If a person afraid of flying goes to an airport they may become jumpy just by being in the terminal even though they have not yet taken off in a plane.\n\nDr Corridan added: '[The Household Cavalry horses] would have had extensive training. Normally they are supposed to be in London city centre but at the end of the day, they are still prey animals, so if they hear something they feel threatened by [they will bolt].\n\n'Once they dislodged their riders, they had no direction.\n\n'The noise must have been substantial. They are trained to override their normal instinct.'\n\nShe said that the horses yesterday would have been trying to find an 'open space' and somewhere with 'grass'.\n\nWhen Vida and Trojan were finally caught, they were pictured by a small green by the Glamis Estate in Limehouse, east London.\n\nMeanwhile, Horse Trust boss Jeanette Allen told Good Morning Britain: 'There are hundreds of service horse working and living in London every day.\n\nBuilder Tom Cahill saw the horses being collected by the army. After the horses were taken away, he said 'there was so much blood they had to call the fire department to clean it up'\n\nThe white horse seemingly had more injuries than the black one. Blood was splattered across the road\n\nThis horse was caught in Limehouse and had visible and bloodied injuries\n\nMembers of the public were seen comforting one of the horses after it ran loose. Blood was seen on the road\n\nOne of the horses smashed into a people carrier, shattering his windows and leaving deep dents with specks of blood splattered across the side\n\nThe taxi-driver's Mercedes people carrier was left with two obliterated rear windows, deep dents, as well as blood smeared on the side\n\n'There is nothing cruel about their training at all.\n\n'It's our culture, it's our heritage. Generally speaking, 99.9 per cent of the time no incidents like this ever happen. This is a one-off.\n\n'As a prey animal, [the noise] would have spooked one of them. As herd animals, the others will follow.'\n\nDr Corridan agreed. She said a herd mentality meant more of the horses may have bolted after just one was spooked.\n\nShe said: 'All it takes is for one to get upset and the rest of the group will be there.'\n\nREAD MORE: Three Household Cavalry soldiers who were injured when their horses were spooked by building work and rampaged through London are set to make a full recovery and will be returning to duty, Army reveals Advertisement\n\n'Horses are much more sensitive to anything threatening. Their normal response is to keep themselves safe.\n\n'I would be curious to see how they are going to manage that horse [Vida].\n\n'There will be a huge amount of trouble and fury after this. They will have to think how they are training all their horses.\n\n'It's very difficult when you ask animals to override their normal defence mechanisms.\n\n'There will be a point where they override that training and they just have to get to safety.'\n\nThis morning, the Army confirmed the soldiers were expected to be alright and would soon return to their normal duties.\n\nA spokesperson said: 'All three soldiers involved are expected to recover fully and to return to duty.\n\n'Of the seven horses which were spooked, five tried to bolt and four, Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson, broke loose.\n\n'Two of the injured horses were operated on last night, with one transferred to an equine hospital. All remaining horses are being closely observed.\n\n'Our horses receive the highest standards of care, and those that did not undergo surgery are expected to return to duty in due course.\n\n'We want to thank everyone who has shown such kindness and concern towards our soldiers and horses.'\n\nArmy top brass told MailOnline the horses were given the best treatment possible by military vets, which saved their lives.\n\nA blue tarpaulin tent was put up around the injured soldier\n\nThe serviceman was treated by paramedics on the road after the incident\n\nEmergency services rushed to the scene after shocking reports of the rampaging horses\n\nA spokesman told MailOnline: 'Be in no doubt, had these not been military horses then their chances of survival would have been greatly reduced.'\n\nREAD MORE: Escaped Household Cavalry horses that sparked panic in London are part of singer James Blunt's old regiment the Life Guards Advertisement\n\nNeither horse is understood to have suffered any broken bones and have been treated for serious cuts and blood loss.\n\nAn Army spokesman told MailOnline: 'We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery. Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n'But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and had they not been attached to the army then I don't believe they would have made it this far.\n\n'Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying. Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n'Quaker is the most seriously injured and was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours.\n\n'The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones. The ceremonial face of the regiment, members of the prestigious Household Cavalry are tasked with mounted state and public duties in London.\n\nSix soldiers and seven horses from the Life Guards were conducting exercises Wednesday morning when the animals were spooked by falling concrete from a nearby construction site in the Belgravia district, the British Army said.\n\nIn a post on social media site X, London police said the mayhem was reported around 8:40 a.m. local time.\n\nFive of the horses took off, while four of the soldiers were bucked from their mounts. {"uri": "8097071795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:06:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/04/25/too-early-to-know-if-injured-military-horses-will-return-to-duty--army/", "title": "'Too early to know' if injured military horses will return to duty - Army", "body": "The Army named four animals who broke loose on Wednesday: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nIt is \"too early to know\" whether two military horses seriously injured after running loose through London on Wednesday will be able to return to official duties, the Army has said.\n\nThe animals underwent surgery overnight and were said to be in a \"serious condition\" by defence minister James Cartlidge on Thursday morning.\n\nFour of the animals who broke loose have now been named: Vida, Trojan, Quaker and Tennyson.\n\nBoth Vida and Quaker were operated on overnight, with the latter being moved to an equine hospital in the early hours of Thursday morning for further specialist treatment, the Army said in a statement.\n\nVida was the grey horse seen in videos and images from Wednesday covered in blood galloping through central London, alongside black horse Trojan.\n\nFour service personnel were thrown from their horses and five of the animals got loose, smashing into vehicles, including a double-decker bus, and causing a number of injuries.\n\nA British Army spokesperson said: \"We are hoping that both these horses make a recovery.\n\n\"Whether they will recover enough to return to official duties, it's too early to know for sure.\n\n\"But they've been given the best veterinary treatment possible and remain under close supervision.\n\n\"Vida was the most visibly injured and the pictures of the horse running through London soaked in blood were horrifying.\n\n\"Vida was operated on overnight and is currently in stables at the Hyde Park Barracks under observation.\n\n\"Quaker was also operated on overnight but it was decided to move the horse to an equine hospital in the early hours for more specialist treatment.\n\n\"The extent of the injuries is not completely clear but we don't believe at this stage there are any broken bones.\n\n\"The blood seen on Vida (the grey horse) was consistent with lacerations.\"\n\nThe Army said three soldiers who were injured would \"recover fully and return to duty\".\n\nHe added: \"They are in a serious condition, but as I understand, still alive.\"\n\nAsked about the condition of two of the horses by LBC, the minister said he \"wouldn't want to say more\" than that they were in a serious condition.\n\nHe added: \"Obviously, we didn't want that situation to happen. What I would stress to you is that this is very exceptional.\n\n\"You are probably aware that the Army has horses out on exercise in central London every day of the week.\n\n\"It is about 150 horses on average exercising every day.\n\n\"So this is extremely unlikely, this scenario.\n\n\"Unfortunately, we have seen what has happened, but all I can say is the crucial thing, as you said yourself, no serious injuries to the public as far as we are aware, and of course we will be keeping an eye on the situation.\"\n\nAmbulance crews treated four people on Wednesday in three separate incidents in Buckingham Palace Road, Belgrave Square, and at the junction of Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, in the space of just 10 minutes.\n\nThe drama began near Buckingham Palace Road where witnesses saw a serviceman thrown from his horse, and one of the loose animals crashed into a taxi waiting outside the Clermont Hotel, shattering windows.\n\nAnother of the animals crashed into a tour bus, smashing
